Rapport DBank

Idx Question Instructions Answer Solution LLM (GPT4o) Answer Solution PyPDF Answer Solution Azure
E1-4

Quel est le plan de transition pour l'atténuation du changement climatique ? Pour répondre à cette question, nous souhaitons avoir une description brève des principaux leviers de décarbonation, du plan d'investissement et de financement du plan de transition, et de la comptabilité avec un scénario 1,5°C ou 2°C.

Parmi les informations que nous recherchons, nous pouvons lister les éléments suivants :

Plan de transition est aligné avec un scénario 1,5°C.

Leviers de décarbonation programmés.

Plan d'investissement et de financement des leviers de décarbonation.

Alignement de la stratégie et le plan de financement.

Suivi des progrès.

Je suis désolé, mais les informations spécifiques concernant un plan de transition pour l'atténuation du changement climatique, y compris les leviers de décarbonation, le plan d'investissement et de financement, et l'alignement avec un scénario 1,5°C ou 2°C, ne sont pas directement disponibles dans les documents fournis. Les documents mentionnent divers scénarios climatiques et des réductions d'émissions prévues pour différents secteurs, mais ne détaillent pas spécifiquement un plan de transition complet ou comment ces éléments sont financés ou suivis.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • The assessment of climate-transition risks is based on four scenarios: - The Stated Policies Scenario (STEPS) reflects current policy settings of the energy-related policies that are in place and those under development (lower transition). CO2 emissions fall only moderately and therefore global warming continues to worsen, with the temperature rise heading towards 2.4℃ in 2100 (IEA, 2023) causing high physical risks - The Announced Pledges Scenario (APS) assumes that all climate commitments made by governments (including Nationally Determined Contributions) and industries around the world will be met (moderate transition). If successfully fulfilled, this would be consistent with a temperature rise of 2.1ºC in 2100 (IEA, 2021) causing moderately high physical risks The assessment of climate-transition risks is based on four scenarios: - The Stated Policies Scenario (STEPS) reflects current policy settings of the energy-related policies that are in place and those under development (lower transition). CO2 emissions fall only moderately and therefore global warming continues to worsen, with the temperature rise heading towards 2.4℃ in 2100 (IEA, 2023) causing high physical risks - The Announced Pledges Scenario (APS) assumes that all climate commitments made by governments (including Nationally Determined Contributions) and industries around the world will be met (moderate transition). If successfully fulfilled, this would be consistent with a temperature rise of 2.1ºC in 2100 (IEA, 2021) causing moderately high physical risks
  • ## Environmental information Climate change In the medium term, higher impacts linked to climate transition risk drivers in the net-zero emission scenario materialize through credit, operational, strategic and reputational risks, driven by factors such as: - Deterioration in Oil and Gas and Coal credit risk profiles with larger impacts starting to emerge for corporate clients in other high carbon intensity sectors as well as for the most vulnerable sovereigns and financial institutions - Valuation pressure on less energy efficient real estate exposures due to a tightening of energy efficiency minimum standards and increased costs associated with energy consumption - Foregone revenues due to exit of carbon intensive clients with no credible transition strategy and higher competition for sustainable clients/financing ## Environmental information Climate change In the medium term, higher impacts linked to climate transition risk drivers in the net-zero emission scenario materialize through credit, operational, strategic and reputational risks, driven by factors such as: - Deterioration in Oil and Gas and Coal credit risk profiles with larger impacts starting to emerge for corporate clients in other high carbon intensity sectors as well as for the most vulnerable sovereigns and financial institutions - Valuation pressure on less energy efficient real estate exposures due to a tightening of energy efficiency minimum standards and increased costs associated with energy consumption - Foregone revenues due to exit of carbon intensive clients with no credible transition strategy and higher competition for sustainable clients/financing
  • - High climate change: Low mitigation scenario where total greenhouse gases (GHG) emissions triple by 2075 and global average temperatures rise by 3.3 to 5.7℃ by 2100 (acute physical risk) - Medium-High climate change: Limited mitigation scenario where total GHG emissions double by 2100 and global average temperatures rise by 2.8 to 4.6°C by 2100 - Medium climate change: Strong mitigation scenario where total GHG emissions stabilize at current levels until 2050 and then decline and global average temperatures rise by 1.3 to 2.4℃ by 2100 - Low climate change: Aggressive mitigation scenario where total GHG emissions reduce to net-zero by 2050 The assessment of climate-transition risks is based on four scenarios: - High climate change: Low mitigation scenario where total greenhouse gases (GHG) emissions triple by 2075 and global average temperatures rise by 3.3 to 5.7℃ by 2100 (acute physical risk) - Medium-High climate change: Limited mitigation scenario where total GHG emissions double by 2100 and global average temperatures rise by 2.8 to 4.6°C by 2100 - Medium climate change: Strong mitigation scenario where total GHG emissions stabilize at current levels until 2050 and then decline and global average temperatures rise by 1.3 to 2.4℃ by 2100 - Low climate change: Aggressive mitigation scenario where total GHG emissions reduce to net-zero by 2050 The assessment of climate-transition risks is based on four scenarios:
  • ### Summary of the Table: The table outlines sector-specific net-zero alignment targets based on various scenarios, scopes, and metrics, with baseline years ranging from 2021 to 2023. The sectors covered include Oil and Gas (Upstream), Power Generation, Automotives (Light Duty), Steel, Coal Mining, Cement, Shipping, and Commercial Aviation. 1. **Oil and Gas (Upstream)**: Scope 3 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario aim to reduce MtCO2/y from 23.4 in 2021 to 18.0 by 2030, a 23% reduction. 2. **Power Generation**: Scope 1 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario target kgCO2e/MWh reductions from 396 in 2021 to 124 by 2030, a 69% reduction. 3. **Automotives (Light Duty)**: Scope 3 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario aim to lower gCO2/vkm from 190 in 2021 to 77 by 2030, a 59% reduction. 4. **Steel**: Scope 1 and 2 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario target kgCO2e/t steel reductions from 1,519 in 2021 to 1,004 by 2030, a 34% reduction. 5. **Coal Mining**: Scope 3 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario aim to reduce MtCO2/y from 7.9 in 2022 to 4.0 by 2030, a 49% reduction. 6. **Cement**: Scope 1 and 2 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario target kgCO2e/t cement reductions from 731 in 2022 to 520 by 2030, a 29% reduction. 7. **Shipping**: Scope 1 emissions under the Revised IMO Strategy (Minimum and Striving scenarios) show a Portfolio Climate Alignment Score (%) baseline of 14.1 in 2022, with a striving target reduction of 18.3 percentage points. 8. **Commercial Aviation**: Scope 1 emissions under the MPP PRU scenario aim for a Portfolio Climate Alignment Score (%) reduction of 1.3 percentage points from 2023 to 2030. The table also includes total loan commitments (€ bn) for each sector, ranging from 0.3 to 12.4. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    0 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8

    Year Total loan commitment (€ bn) Metric value Dec 31, 2030 Baseline vs. target
    Oil and Gas (Upstream) Scope 3 IEA NZE MtCO2/y 2021 10.7 23.4 18.0 (23)%
    Power Generation Scope 1 IEA NZE kgCO2e/MWh 2021 12.4 396 124 (69)%
    Automotives (Light Duty) Scope 3 IEA NZE gCO2/vkm 2021 7.5 190 77 (59)%
    Steel Scope 1 and 2 IEA NZE kgCO2e/t steel 2021 2.1 1,519 1,004 (34)%
    Coal Mining Scope 3 IEA NZE MtCO2/y 2022 1.5 7.9 4.0 (49)%
    Cement Scope 1 and 2 IEA NZE kgCO2e/t cement 2022 0.3 731 520 (29)%
    Scope 1 Revised IMO Strategy - Minimum2 Portfolio Climate Alignment Score (%) 2022 0.9 14.1 N/A N/A
    Shipping Revised IMO Strategy - Striving2 18.3 0 (18.3)pp
    Commercial Aviation Scope 1 MPP PRU3 2023 1.7 1.3 0 (1.3)pp
  • - The Net Zero Emissions by 2050 scenario (NZE) sets out a pathway for the global energy sector to achieve net-zero CO2 emissions by 2050 and limits global warming to 1.5 ℃ (IEA, 2023) through stringent climate policies and innovation. In this scenario, physical risks are relatively low but transition risks are high - The Disorderly scenario (delayed transition) assumes that annual emissions do not decrease until 2030 with drastic policies needed thereafter to limit warming to below 2℃. This leads to high transition and physical risks than the NZE by 2050 scenario - The Net Zero Emissions by 2050 scenario (NZE) sets out a pathway for the global energy sector to achieve net-zero CO2 emissions by 2050 and limits global warming to 1.5 ℃ (IEA, 2023) through stringent climate policies and innovation. In this scenario, physical risks are relatively low but transition risks are high - The Disorderly scenario (delayed transition) assumes that annual emissions do not decrease until 2030 with drastic policies needed thereafter to limit warming to below 2℃. This leads to high transition and physical risks than the NZE by 2050 scenario
  • ## Environmental information Climate change The key levers to reduce the bank's emissions resulting from its own operations (Scope 1 and 2 emissions) include reducing energy consumption, sourcing more electricity from renewables, reducing business travel and using offsets for residual emissions. The associated targets to reduce Scope 1 and 2 emissions include: - Compensating for emissions from own operations (Scope 1 and 2) and business travel - Reducing total energy consumption by 30% by 2025 versus 2019 - Sourcing 100% renewable electricity by 2025 - Reducing fuel consumption of Deutsche Bank's car fleet by 30% by 2025 and reaching carbon zero in Germany by 2030 ## Environmental information Climate change The key levers to reduce the bank's emissions resulting from its own operations (Scope 1 and 2 emissions) include reducing energy consumption, sourcing more electricity from renewables, reducing business travel and using offsets for residual emissions. The associated targets to reduce Scope 1 and 2 emissions include: - Compensating for emissions from own operations (Scope 1 and 2) and business travel - Reducing total energy consumption by 30% by 2025 versus 2019 - Sourcing 100% renewable electricity by 2025 - Reducing fuel consumption of Deutsche Bank's car fleet by 30% by 2025 and reaching carbon zero in Germany by 2030
  • ### Climate Physical Risks :selected: :selected: Transition risks can arise from the transition towards a low-carbon economy. Examples include: Physical risks can arise from more frequent and severe extreme weather events ("acute") and gradual changes in the environment ("chronic") due to a changing climate. - Strategic risks such as potential loss of revenues from the withdrawal of financing to high-emitting counterparties - Credit risks from defaults or deterioration of credit ratings of clients unable to adapt their business models - Credit risks from defaults of clients directly/indirectly impacted by these events and depreciation of collateral values - Credit risks (collateral values) from depreciation of asset values driven by energy efficiency issues/CO2 pricing - Market risks from short-term market volatility as a result of physical risk events or fundamental re-pricing of asset values in regions/sectors impacted by chronic negative events ### Climate Physical Risks :selected: :selected: Transition risks can arise from the transition towards a low-carbon economy. Examples include: Physical risks can arise from more frequent and severe extreme weather events ("acute") and gradual changes in the environment ("chronic") due to a changing climate. - Strategic risks such as potential loss of revenues from the withdrawal of financing to high-emitting counterparties - Credit risks from defaults or deterioration of credit ratings of clients unable to adapt their business models - Credit risks from defaults of clients directly/indirectly impacted by these events and depreciation of collateral values - Credit risks (collateral values) from depreciation of asset values driven by energy efficiency issues/CO2 pricing - Market risks from short-term market volatility as a result of physical risk events or fundamental re-pricing of asset values in regions/sectors impacted by chronic negative events
  • ### Zusammenfassung der Tabelle: Umweltinformationen Klimawandel Die Tabelle zeigt klimabezogene Daten für verschiedene Sektoren im Jahr 2024, basierend auf dem Szenario "IEA NZE" (außer für Shipping und Commercial Aviation). Die Spalten umfassen "Sektor", "Szenario", "Maßeinheit", "Jahr", "Gesamtkreditverpflichtung (€ Mrd.)", "Metrikwert" und "Änderung gegenüber Basiswert (erreichte Reduktionen)". 1. **Oil and Gas (Upstream)**: 2024, 9,6 € Mrd., 19,2 MtCO2/y, Reduktion um (18)%. 2. **Power Generation**: 2024, 11,8 € Mrd., 312 kgCO2e/MWh, Reduktion um (21)%. 3. **Automotives (Light Duty)**: 2024, 7,7 € Mrd., 162 gCO2/vkm, Reduktion um (15)%. 4. **Steel**: 2024, 2,2 € Mrd., 1.234 kgCO2e/t Stahl, Reduktion um (19)%. 5. **Coal Mining**: 2024, 1,2 € Mrd., 4,6 MtCO2/y, Reduktion um (42)%. 6. **Cement**: 2024, 0,3 € Mrd., 781 kgCO2e/t Zement, Anstieg um 7%. 7. **Shipping**: 2023, 0,9 € Mrd., 14,2 (Maßeinheit nicht angegeben), Änderung um 0,1pp; Portfolio Climate Alignment Score: 19,7%, Änderung um 1,4pp. 8. **Commercial Aviation**: 2023, 1,7 € Mrd., 1,3 (Maßeinheit nicht angegeben), keine Änderung (N/A). and

Los activos sostenibles totales alcanzaron 490 millones de euros, con un GAR (flow) de 1,259 millones. Los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 0.2 y 0.4 respectivamente, con una cobertura del 17.6% sobre el total de activos. El porcentaje de activos excluidos del numerador del GAR fue del 82.4%, mientras que los excluidos del denominador fueron "N/M". En la categoría "Trading book", los valores son "N/A". En "Financial guarantees", los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 153 y 374 respectivamente, con valores de 0.5 y 1.3. Para "Assets under Management", los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 8,635 y 16,857 respectivamente, con valores de 0.8 y 1.6. Finalmente, en "Fees and commissions income", los valores son "N/A". and

Je suis désolé, mais je ne peux pas fournir de réponse complète à la question posée car elle nécessite des informations détaillées qui ne sont pas spécifiquement fournies dans les documents contextuels disponibles. Cependant, je peux vous donner un aperçu basé sur les informations disponibles :

  1. Leviers de décarbonation programmés : Deutsche Bank a mis en œuvre un cadre de décarbonation qui suit trois leviers principaux : (1) réduire l'utilisation des ressources, (2) substituer les ressources actuelles par des alternatives à faible émission de carbone, et (3) compenser les émissions résiduelles là où la réduction n'est pas faisable.

  2. Plan d'investissement et de financement des leviers de décarbonation : Le plan de transition initial publié en octobre 2023 inclut des informations prospectives et donne un aperçu de l'élargissement du champ d'application du plan de transition, notamment en ce qui concerne les émissions financées. Deutsche Bank continue de considérer les derniers scénarios de neutralité carbone et les voies économiques pour identifier les besoins d'investissement et leur influence sur le financement durable et le plan d'investissement de la banque.

  3. Alignement de la stratégie et le plan de financement : La stratégie de durabilité de Deutsche Bank, y compris le cadre de finance durable et l'engagement à aligner le portefeuille de la banque avec la neutralité carbone d'ici 2050, est en ligne avec les accords de Paris.

  4. Suivi des progrès : Le plan de transition initial décrit les progrès réalisés et la stratégie pour atteindre l'engagement de neutralité carbone. La banque continue de développer son plan de transition initial en tant qu'outils, méthodologies et structures pour répondre aux opportunités émergentes et aux risques potentiels.

Pour de plus amples informations, il serait nécessaire de consulter directement les rapports annuels détaillés de Deutsche Bank ou d'autres documents spécifiques sur leur plan de transition climatique.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • The assessment of climate-transition risks is based on four scenarios: - The Stated Policies Scenario (STEPS) reflects current policy settings of the energy-related policies that are in place and those under development (lower transition). CO2 emissions fall only moderately and therefore global warming continues to worsen, with the temperature rise heading towards 2.4℃ in 2100 (IEA, 2023) causing high physical risks - The Announced Pledges Scenario (APS) assumes that all climate commitments made by governments (including Nationally Determined Contributions) and industries around the world will be met (moderate transition). If successfully fulfilled, this would be consistent with a temperature rise of 2.1ºC in 2100 (IEA, 2021) causing moderately high physical risks
  • ## Environmental information Climate change In the medium term, higher impacts linked to climate transition risk drivers in the net-zero emission scenario materialize through credit, operational, strategic and reputational risks, driven by factors such as: - Deterioration in Oil and Gas and Coal credit risk profiles with larger impacts starting to emerge for corporate clients in other high carbon intensity sectors as well as for the most vulnerable sovereigns and financial institutions - Valuation pressure on less energy efficient real estate exposures due to a tightening of energy efficiency minimum standards and increased costs associated with energy consumption - Foregone revenues due to exit of carbon intensive clients with no credible transition strategy and higher competition for sustainable clients/financing
  • - High climate change: Low mitigation scenario where total greenhouse gases (GHG) emissions triple by 2075 and global average temperatures rise by 3.3 to 5.7℃ by 2100 (acute physical risk) - Medium-High climate change: Limited mitigation scenario where total GHG emissions double by 2100 and global average temperatures rise by 2.8 to 4.6°C by 2100 - Medium climate change: Strong mitigation scenario where total GHG emissions stabilize at current levels until 2050 and then decline and global average temperatures rise by 1.3 to 2.4℃ by 2100 - Low climate change: Aggressive mitigation scenario where total GHG emissions reduce to net-zero by 2050 The assessment of climate-transition risks is based on four scenarios:
  • ### Summary of the Table: The table outlines sector-specific net-zero alignment targets based on various scenarios, scopes, and metrics, with baseline years ranging from 2021 to 2023. The sectors covered include Oil and Gas (Upstream), Power Generation, Automotives (Light Duty), Steel, Coal Mining, Cement, Shipping, and Commercial Aviation. 1. **Oil and Gas (Upstream)**: Scope 3 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario aim to reduce MtCO2/y from 23.4 in 2021 to 18.0 by 2030, a 23% reduction. 2. **Power Generation**: Scope 1 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario target kgCO2e/MWh reductions from 396 in 2021 to 124 by 2030, a 69% reduction. 3. **Automotives (Light Duty)**: Scope 3 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario aim to lower gCO2/vkm from 190 in 2021 to 77 by 2030, a 59% reduction. 4. **Steel**: Scope 1 and 2 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario target kgCO2e/t steel reductions from 1,519 in 2021 to 1,004 by 2030, a 34% reduction. 5. **Coal Mining**: Scope 3 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario aim to reduce MtCO2/y from 7.9 in 2022 to 4.0 by 2030, a 49% reduction. 6. **Cement**: Scope 1 and 2 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario target kgCO2e/t cement reductions from 731 in 2022 to 520 by 2030, a 29% reduction. 7. **Shipping**: Scope 1 emissions under the Revised IMO Strategy (Minimum and Striving scenarios) show a Portfolio Climate Alignment Score (%) baseline of 14.1 in 2022, with a striving target reduction of 18.3 percentage points. 8. **Commercial Aviation**: Scope 1 emissions under the MPP PRU scenario aim for a Portfolio Climate Alignment Score (%) reduction of 1.3 percentage points from 2023 to 2030. The table also includes total loan commitments (€ bn) for each sector, ranging from 0.3 to 12.4.
  • - The Net Zero Emissions by 2050 scenario (NZE) sets out a pathway for the global energy sector to achieve net-zero CO2 emissions by 2050 and limits global warming to 1.5 ℃ (IEA, 2023) through stringent climate policies and innovation. In this scenario, physical risks are relatively low but transition risks are high - The Disorderly scenario (delayed transition) assumes that annual emissions do not decrease until 2030 with drastic policies needed thereafter to limit warming to below 2℃. This leads to high transition and physical risks than the NZE by 2050 scenario
  • ## Environmental information Climate change The key levers to reduce the bank's emissions resulting from its own operations (Scope 1 and 2 emissions) include reducing energy consumption, sourcing more electricity from renewables, reducing business travel and using offsets for residual emissions. The associated targets to reduce Scope 1 and 2 emissions include: - Compensating for emissions from own operations (Scope 1 and 2) and business travel - Reducing total energy consumption by 30% by 2025 versus 2019 - Sourcing 100% renewable electricity by 2025 - Reducing fuel consumption of Deutsche Bank's car fleet by 30% by 2025 and reaching carbon zero in Germany by 2030
  • ### Climate Physical Risks :selected: :selected: Transition risks can arise from the transition towards a low-carbon economy. Examples include: Physical risks can arise from more frequent and severe extreme weather events ("acute") and gradual changes in the environment ("chronic") due to a changing climate. - Strategic risks such as potential loss of revenues from the withdrawal of financing to high-emitting counterparties - Credit risks from defaults or deterioration of credit ratings of clients unable to adapt their business models - Credit risks from defaults of clients directly/indirectly impacted by these events and depreciation of collateral values - Credit risks (collateral values) from depreciation of asset values driven by energy efficiency issues/CO2 pricing - Market risks from short-term market volatility as a result of physical risk events or fundamental re-pricing of asset values in regions/sectors impacted by chronic negative events
  • ### Zusammenfassung der Tabelle: Umweltinformationen Klimawandel Die Tabelle zeigt klimabezogene Daten für verschiedene Sektoren im Jahr 2024, basierend auf dem Szenario "IEA NZE" (außer für Shipping und Commercial Aviation). Die Spalten umfassen "Sektor", "Szenario", "Maßeinheit", "Jahr", "Gesamtkreditverpflichtung (€ Mrd.)", "Metrikwert" und "Änderung gegenüber Basiswert (erreichte Reduktionen)". 1. **Oil and Gas (Upstream)**: 2024, 9,6 € Mrd., 19,2 MtCO2/y, Reduktion um (18)%. 2. **Power Generation**: 2024, 11,8 € Mrd., 312 kgCO2e/MWh, Reduktion um (21)%. 3. **Automotives (Light Duty)**: 2024, 7,7 € Mrd., 162 gCO2/vkm, Reduktion um (15)%. 4. **Steel**: 2024, 2,2 € Mrd., 1.234 kgCO2e/t Stahl, Reduktion um (19)%. 5. **Coal Mining**: 2024, 1,2 € Mrd., 4,6 MtCO2/y, Reduktion um (42)%. 6. **Cement**: 2024, 0,3 € Mrd., 781 kgCO2e/t Zement, Anstieg um 7%. 7. **Shipping**: 2023, 0,9 € Mrd., 14,2 (Maßeinheit nicht angegeben), Änderung um 0,1pp; Portfolio Climate Alignment Score: 19,7%, Änderung um 1,4pp. 8. **Commercial Aviation**: 2023, 1,7 € Mrd., 1,3 (Maßeinheit nicht angegeben), keine Änderung (N/A).

  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta datos en FTE al 31 de diciembre de 2023, desglosados por regiones: Alemania, Europa excluyendo Alemania, América, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África, y el Total. 1. **Número de empleados**: Alemania tiene 36,195, Europa excluyendo Alemania 18,103, América 8,232, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,601, con un total de 90,130. 2. **Número de empleados permanentes**: Alemania cuenta con 35,822, Europa excluyendo Alemania 18,066, América 8,232, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,584, sumando un total de 89,703. 3. **Número de empleados temporales**: Alemania tiene 373, Europa excluyendo Alemania 37, América no tiene empleados temporales, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 17, con un total de 427. 4. **Número de empleados con horas no garantizadas**: No hay empleados en esta categoría en ninguna región. 5. **Número de empleados (repetido)**: Alemania tiene 36,195, Europa excluyendo Alemania 18,103, América 8,232, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,601, con un total de 90,130. 6. **Número de empleados a tiempo completo**: Alemania cuenta con 28,686, Europa excluyendo Alemania 17,386, América 8,212, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,585, sumando un total de 81,869. 7. **Número de empleados a tiempo parcial**: Alemania tiene 7,509, Europa excluyendo Alemania 717, América 20, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 16, con un total de 8,261. ### END TABLE
  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla muestra la exposición de préstamos corporativos por tipo de pérdida de naturaleza al 31 de diciembre de 2023, con datos en € bn y porcentajes del portafolio. Los tipos de pérdida de naturaleza incluyen: "Water depletion" (17.3 € bn, 17.1% del portafolio, 2.2 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 12.7% de estos), "Terrestrial biodiversity and habitat loss" (11.6 € bn, 11.5% del portafolio, 4.6 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 39.2% de estos), "Ecosystem degradation from waste and pollution" (9.2 € bn, 9.1% del portafolio, 5.5 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 60.2% de estos), y "Marine ecosystem degradation" (6.4 € bn, 6.3% del portafolio, 4.7 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 74.0% de estos). La exposición total de préstamos corporativos por industria es de 101.2 € bn, representando el 100% del portafolio, sin datos específicos identificados a nivel de cliente.
  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta datos relacionados con activos sostenibles ambientalmente y KPIs de rendimiento, inversión (CapEx) y cobertura, con referencia al 31 de diciembre de 2023. Los encabezados incluyen: "Total environmentally sustainable assets (in € m)", "Turnover KPIs", "CapEx KPIs", "% coverage (over total assets)", "% of assets excluded from the numerator of the GAR (Article 7(2) and (3) and Section 1.1.2. of Annex V)", y "% of assets excluded from the denominator of the GAR (Article 7(1) and Section 1.2.4 of Annex V)". Los activos sostenibles totales alcanzaron 490 millones de euros, con un GAR (flow) de 1,259 millones. Los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 0.2 y 0.4 respectivamente, con una cobertura del 17.6% sobre el total de activos. El porcentaje de activos excluidos del numerador del GAR fue del 82.4%, mientras que los excluidos del denominador fueron "N/M". En la categoría "Trading book", los valores son "N/A". En "Financial guarantees", los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 153 y 374 respectivamente, con valores de 0.5 y 1.3. Para "Assets under Management", los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 8,635 y 16,857 respectivamente, con valores de 0.8 y 1.6. Finalmente, en "Fees and commissions income", los valores son "N/A".

Je suis désolé, mais les informations spécifiques concernant un plan de transition pour l'atténuation du changement climatique, y compris les leviers de décarbonation, le plan d'investissement et de financement, et l'alignement avec un scénario 1,5°C ou 2°C, ne sont pas directement disponibles dans les documents fournis. Les documents mentionnent divers scénarios climatiques et des réductions d'émissions prévues pour différents secteurs, mais ne détaillent pas spécifiquement un plan de transition complet ou comment ces éléments sont financés ou suivis.

  • Deutsche Bank’s ambition level includes clear, quantifiable targets — both for decarbonizing portfolios in high -carbon emission industries and for growing sustainable business. Transition Plan ESRS E1 -1 Since Deutsche Bank’s Management Board made sustainability a strategic priority in 2019, the bank has made significant progress toward achieving its interim targets for 2030. In October 2023, Deutsche Bank published its Initial Transition Plan, which outlines the progress made and the strategy to reach its net -zero commitment. This plan consolidates the bank’s definitions, methodologies, targets and achievements on its path. Th e progress is detailed in the respective chapters of this Sustainability Statement , including the “Sustainability Strategy” and “Client portfolios” chapters. The plan adopts a holistic approach to the bank’s net -zero transition to support the Paris Agreement climate targets by Deutsche Bank’s ambition level includes clear, quantifiable targets — both for decarbonizing portfolios in high -carbon emission industries and for growing sustainable business.   • The bank implemented a decarbonization framework to reduce emissions resulting from its supply chain (Scope 3, Categories 1 to 14). This framework follows three levers: (1) reducing resource use, (2) substituting current resources with lower -carbon alterna tives and (3) offsetting residual emissions where reduction is not feasible. In 2024, the bank’s Scope 1 and 2 emissions as well as Scope 3, Categories 1 to 14 emissions did not meet the double materiality threshold and are therefore not included in the disclosures of this Sustainability Statement . Instead, Deutsche Bank provides detailed information on its approach in the Initial Transition Plan. In 2024, the bank’s Scope 1 and 2 emissions as well as Scope 3, Categories 1 to 14 emissions did not meet the double materiality threshold and are therefore not included in the disclosures of this Sustainability Statement .   • these steps, Deutsche Bank plans to forge strategic partnerships with clients globally on their decarbonization paths, leveraging both strategic and financia l advantages. Furthermore, Deutsche Bank can exert positive impact on the environment and society in the short - and medium -term by catalyzing investments and mobilizing financing for climate adaptation measures and for supporting clients towards low -carbon business models, as well as applying strict due diligence policies for sustainable financing and ESG investment activities in carbon -intensive industries and locations severely exposed to climate impacts. Next to the Chief Sustainability Office, an additional enabler are ESG expert teams in the bank’s business divisions and infrastructure functions that foster the implementation of Deutsche Bank’s sustainability strategy and allow for a swift respo nse to emerging business opportunities and potential risks. In the years ahead, Deutsche Bank aims to broaden the scope of decarbonization, i.e., progressing from financed emissions to financed and facilitated emissions and capturing opportunities in the bank’s private clients’ assets under management. Moreover, De utsche Bank focuses on incorporating nature and biodiversity as well as just transition, which means to address the challenges of transitioning for developing economies.   • valuation, monitoring , and review over the life of the loan. Deutsche Bank’s underwriting standards require real estate collateral to be appropriately insured against relevant risks including applicable natural hazards. In some countries, supplemental insurance against natural hazards is provided by the government. The European residential real estate portfolio amounted to € 166.4 billion at year -end 2024. Residential mortgages for private clients in Germany represent approximately 92% of this amount and around 1.2 million German private residences financed by loans secured by immovable properties are insured appropriately against relevant risks including applicable natural hazards. The insurance cover by real estate owners is monitored and complemented or substituted by De utsche Bank´s own insurance. In addition, new valuations and re -valuations require the identification of material environmental physical and transition valuation, monitoring , and review over the life of the loan.   • Strategy ESRS 2 SBM -3 Deutsche Bank is committed to protecting its clients, society, and its own assets by taking an active role in the prevention, detection, and reporting of financial crime. Recognizing the material threats posed by financial crime, the Anti -Financial Crime f unction has defined a uniform strategy across financial crime risk prevention, detection, and reporting to ensure the highest level of protection for Deutsche Bank’s clients and stakeholders, while also supporting sustainable business practices. The Anti -Financial Crime strategy focuses on remediation, simplification, and consolidation of processes, and evolving the AFC Program across the areas of risk appetite, risk assessment, policy, training, assurance and reporting. The strategy serves to accelerate de cision -making around financial crime risks, enforce consistent standards, and foster Strategy ESRS 2 SBM -3 Deutsche Bank is committed to protecting its clients, society, and its own assets by taking an active role in the prevention, detection, and reporting of financial crime. Recognizing the material threats posed by financial crime, the Anti -Financial Crime f unction has defined a uniform strategy across financial crime risk prevention, detection, and reporting to ensure the highest level of protection for Deutsche Bank’s clients and stakeholders, while also supporting sustainable business practices. The Anti -Financial Crime strategy focuses on remediation, simplification, and consolidation of processes, and evolving the AFC Program across the areas of risk appetite, risk assessment, policy, training, assurance and reporting. The strategy serves to accelerate de cision -making around financial crime risks, enforce consistent standards, and foster
E1-5

Les objectifs de réduction fixés sont-ils alignés avec une trajectoire de 1,5°C conformément aux Accords de Paris ? L'entreprise mentionne-t-elle une trajectoire conforme aux objectifs SBTi ? Il convient également de noter que, si l'entreprise affiche des objectifs de neutralité carbone, cette neutralité doit nécessairement être alignée avec les recommandations de l'Accord de Paris.

Pour garantir la compatibilité avec un scénario de transition conforme à l'accord de Paris, l'entreprise doit fournir les informations suivantes :

- Un/des objectif(s) de réduction avec une trajectoire de réchauffement à 1,5°C grâce à une trajectoire de décarbonation sectorielle si disponible, soit grâce à une trajectoire d'émissions transsectorielle compatible avec la limitation de réchauffement de la planète à 1,5°C (cf. AR 26 et 27).

- Les facteurs de réduction des émissions évoluent et ne sont pas fixes encore. Par conséquent, les entreprises sont encouragées à n'utiliser que des informations actualisées et publiquement accessibles. L'EFRAG préconise Pathways to Net-Zero - SBTi Technical Summary). Les cibles de réduction doivent être fixées respectivement à 2030 et 2050, avec des échellons tous les 5 ans.

Deutsche Bank se fixe des objectifs de réduction des émissions alignés avec le scénario de Net-Zero Emissions (NZE) de l'Agence Internationale de l'Énergie (AIE) pour plusieurs secteurs, y compris le pétrole et le gaz, la production d'énergie, l'automobile, l'acier, le charbon, le ciment, le transport maritime et l'aviation commerciale. Ces objectifs sont basés sur des trajectoires de décarbonation sectorielles qui visent à atteindre la neutralité carbone d'ici 2050, avec des cibles intermédiaires pour 2030.

Cependant, Deutsche Bank n'a pas formellement rejoint l'initiative Science-Based Targets (SBTi), bien qu'elle ait adopté des cibles SBTi pour certaines de ses opérations, notamment une réduction de 46% des émissions opérationnelles de Scope 3 d'ici 2030 par rapport à 2019.

Il n'est pas explicitement mentionné que les objectifs de réduction de Deutsche Bank sont alignés avec une trajectoire de réchauffement à 1,5°C, conformément aux Accords de Paris. L'entreprise n'indique pas de manière claire si sa neutralité carbone est alignée avec les recommandations spécifiques de l'Accord de Paris.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • Deutsche Bank's targets are instrumental in the management of the bank's material climate change impacts and risks. The following decarbonization pathways are used: (i) the Net-Zero Emissions (NZE) by 2050 scenario of the International Energy Agency (IEA); (ii) Poseidon Principles (PP) pathways which are calibrated against the Revised International Maritime Organization (IMO) Strategy; and (iii) the Mission Possible Partnership Prudent Scenario for Commercial Aviation. Selected decarbonization pathways model changes in customer preferences, regulatory factors and emerging technologies to enable the modelling of sector-specific outcomes. The bank's decarbonization targets are fully integrated into Deutsche Bank's risk appetite and risk management framework. Deutsche Bank's targets are instrumental in the management of the bank's material climate change impacts and risks. The following decarbonization pathways are used: (i) the Net-Zero Emissions (NZE) by 2050 scenario of the International Energy Agency (IEA); (ii) Poseidon Principles (PP) pathways which are calibrated against the Revised International Maritime Organization (IMO) Strategy; and (iii) the Mission Possible Partnership Prudent Scenario for Commercial Aviation. Selected decarbonization pathways model changes in customer preferences, regulatory factors and emerging technologies to enable the modelling of sector-specific outcomes. The bank's decarbonization targets are fully integrated into Deutsche Bank's risk appetite and risk management framework.
  • ## Environmental information Climate change The key levers to reduce the bank's emissions resulting from its own operations (Scope 1 and 2 emissions) include reducing energy consumption, sourcing more electricity from renewables, reducing business travel and using offsets for residual emissions. The associated targets to reduce Scope 1 and 2 emissions include: - Compensating for emissions from own operations (Scope 1 and 2) and business travel - Reducing total energy consumption by 30% by 2025 versus 2019 - Sourcing 100% renewable electricity by 2025 - Reducing fuel consumption of Deutsche Bank's car fleet by 30% by 2025 and reaching carbon zero in Germany by 2030 ## Environmental information Climate change The key levers to reduce the bank's emissions resulting from its own operations (Scope 1 and 2 emissions) include reducing energy consumption, sourcing more electricity from renewables, reducing business travel and using offsets for residual emissions. The associated targets to reduce Scope 1 and 2 emissions include: - Compensating for emissions from own operations (Scope 1 and 2) and business travel - Reducing total energy consumption by 30% by 2025 versus 2019 - Sourcing 100% renewable electricity by 2025 - Reducing fuel consumption of Deutsche Bank's car fleet by 30% by 2025 and reaching carbon zero in Germany by 2030
  • - Deutsche Bank is committed to reduce its CO2 emissions (Scope 1 to 3) to net-zero by 2050Therefore, the bank has set net-zero targets for the eight most carbon-intensive sectors in its corporate loan book by end of 2030 (interim) and end of 2050 (final) and linked the Management Board compensation to adherence to these pathways - The bank aims to encourage as many of its high-emitting clients in the most carbon-intensive sectors to commit to net- zero. However, due to alternating dynamics internationally with regards to net-zero commitments, the bank no longer believes it is realistic to achieve the ambition of 90% from 2026 onwards. Nevertheless, Deutsche Bank will report annually on the progress regarding this ambition - Deutsche Bank aims to implement and publish its Transition Finance Framework in 2025 In 2024, Deutsche Bank continued to deliver on its environmental dimension. Key achievements include: - Deutsche Bank is committed to reduce its CO2 emissions (Scope 1 to 3) to net-zero by 2050Therefore, the bank has set net-zero targets for the eight most carbon-intensive sectors in its corporate loan book by end of 2030 (interim) and end of 2050 (final) and linked the Management Board compensation to adherence to these pathways - The bank aims to encourage as many of its high-emitting clients in the most carbon-intensive sectors to commit to net- zero. However, due to alternating dynamics internationally with regards to net-zero commitments, the bank no longer believes it is realistic to achieve the ambition of 90% from 2026 onwards. Nevertheless, Deutsche Bank will report annually on the progress regarding this ambition - Deutsche Bank aims to implement and publish its Transition Finance Framework in 2025 In 2024, Deutsche Bank continued to deliver on its environmental dimension. Key achievements include:
  • While Deutsche Bank has not formally joined the Science-Based Targets initiative (SBTi), Deutsche Bank has adopted SBTi targets and as such, commits to a reduction in operational Scope 3 emission (excluding financed emission - Category 15) of 46% by 2030 compared to the 2019 baseline, equivalent to 4.3% per year. While Deutsche Bank has not formally joined the Science-Based Targets initiative (SBTi), Deutsche Bank has adopted SBTi targets and as such, commits to a reduction in operational Scope 3 emission (excluding financed emission - Category 15) of 46% by 2030 compared to the 2019 baseline, equivalent to 4.3% per year.
  • ### Summary of the Table: The table outlines sector-specific net-zero alignment targets based on various scenarios, scopes, and metrics, with baseline years ranging from 2021 to 2023. The sectors covered include Oil and Gas (Upstream), Power Generation, Automotives (Light Duty), Steel, Coal Mining, Cement, Shipping, and Commercial Aviation. 1. **Oil and Gas (Upstream)**: Scope 3 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario aim to reduce MtCO2/y from 23.4 in 2021 to 18.0 by 2030, a 23% reduction. 2. **Power Generation**: Scope 1 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario target kgCO2e/MWh reductions from 396 in 2021 to 124 by 2030, a 69% reduction. 3. **Automotives (Light Duty)**: Scope 3 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario aim to lower gCO2/vkm from 190 in 2021 to 77 by 2030, a 59% reduction. 4. **Steel**: Scope 1 and 2 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario target kgCO2e/t steel reductions from 1,519 in 2021 to 1,004 by 2030, a 34% reduction. 5. **Coal Mining**: Scope 3 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario aim to reduce MtCO2/y from 7.9 in 2022 to 4.0 by 2030, a 49% reduction. 6. **Cement**: Scope 1 and 2 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario target kgCO2e/t cement reductions from 731 in 2022 to 520 by 2030, a 29% reduction. 7. **Shipping**: Scope 1 emissions under the Revised IMO Strategy (Minimum and Striving scenarios) show a Portfolio Climate Alignment Score (%) baseline of 14.1 in 2022, with a striving target reduction of 18.3 percentage points. 8. **Commercial Aviation**: Scope 1 emissions under the MPP PRU scenario aim for a Portfolio Climate Alignment Score (%) reduction of 1.3 percentage points from 2023 to 2030. The table also includes total loan commitments (€ bn) for each sector, ranging from 0.3 to 12.4. and

  • ### END TABLE 1.2 Deutsche Bank will publish year-end 2024 Portfolio Climate Alignment Scores in next year's Sustainability Statement. Change vs. baseline is N/A for Commercial Aviation as this is the first year of publication Achieved and expected emissions reductions are disclosed in the relevant columns of the above target table. For Oil and Gas (Upstream) and Coal Mining sectors, these reductions are expressed in absolute terms (i.e. Scope 3 End Use financed emissions). For the remaining sectors, they reflect a change in the physical intensity metric or climate alignment scores (which are expressed in percentages). The conversion of the relative or physical intensity metrics sectoral targets into absolute reductions of GHG emissions (ex. ESRS Requirement E1-4 34a/b) is not disclosed as the Transitional Provisions of ESRS1 par. 133b allows the bank to focus on the more established physical intensity metrics required by the Pillar 3 legislation. ### END TABLE 1.2 Deutsche Bank will publish year-end 2024 Portfolio Climate Alignment Scores in next year's Sustainability Statement. Change vs. baseline is N/A for Commercial Aviation as this is the first year of publication Achieved and expected emissions reductions are disclosed in the relevant columns of the above target table. For Oil and Gas (Upstream) and Coal Mining sectors, these reductions are expressed in absolute terms (i.e. Scope 3 End Use financed emissions). For the remaining sectors, they reflect a change in the physical intensity metric or climate alignment scores (which are expressed in percentages). The conversion of the relative or physical intensity metrics sectoral targets into absolute reductions of GHG emissions (ex. ESRS Requirement E1-4 34a/b) is not disclosed as the Transitional Provisions of ESRS1 par. 133b allows the bank to focus on the more established physical intensity metrics required by the Pillar 3 legislation.

    in FTE1 Dec 31, 2023
    Germany Europe excluding Germany Americas Middle East and Asia-Pacific, Africa Total

    Number of part-time employees 7,509 717 20 16 8,261

Je ne suis pas en mesure de confirmer si les objectifs de réduction de Deutsche Bank sont spécifiquement alignés avec une trajectoire de 1,5°C conformément aux Accords de Paris ou avec les objectifs SBTi (Science Based Targets initiative). Le contexte fourni mentionne que Deutsche Bank adopte une approche holistique pour soutenir les objectifs climatiques de l'Accord de Paris et qu'elle a fixé des cibles de neutralité carbone pour 2030 et 2050 pour les secteurs les plus intensifs en carbone. Cependant, il n'est pas explicitement indiqué si ces objectifs suivent une trajectoire conforme à un réchauffement limité à 1,5°C ni s'ils sont alignés sur les recommandations spécifiques de l'initiative SBTi.

Pour garantir la compatibilité avec un scénario de transition conforme à l'accord de Paris, l'entreprise doit fournir des objectifs de réduction spécifiquement alignés sur une trajectoire de réchauffement à 1,5°C, mais ces détails précis ne sont pas disponibles dans les documents fournis.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • Deutsche Bank's targets are instrumental in the management of the bank's material climate change impacts and risks. The following decarbonization pathways are used: (i) the Net-Zero Emissions (NZE) by 2050 scenario of the International Energy Agency (IEA); (ii) Poseidon Principles (PP) pathways which are calibrated against the Revised International Maritime Organization (IMO) Strategy; and (iii) the Mission Possible Partnership Prudent Scenario for Commercial Aviation. Selected decarbonization pathways model changes in customer preferences, regulatory factors and emerging technologies to enable the modelling of sector-specific outcomes. The bank's decarbonization targets are fully integrated into Deutsche Bank's risk appetite and risk management framework.
  • ## Environmental information Climate change The key levers to reduce the bank's emissions resulting from its own operations (Scope 1 and 2 emissions) include reducing energy consumption, sourcing more electricity from renewables, reducing business travel and using offsets for residual emissions. The associated targets to reduce Scope 1 and 2 emissions include: - Compensating for emissions from own operations (Scope 1 and 2) and business travel - Reducing total energy consumption by 30% by 2025 versus 2019 - Sourcing 100% renewable electricity by 2025 - Reducing fuel consumption of Deutsche Bank's car fleet by 30% by 2025 and reaching carbon zero in Germany by 2030
  • - Deutsche Bank is committed to reduce its CO2 emissions (Scope 1 to 3) to net-zero by 2050Therefore, the bank has set net-zero targets for the eight most carbon-intensive sectors in its corporate loan book by end of 2030 (interim) and end of 2050 (final) and linked the Management Board compensation to adherence to these pathways - The bank aims to encourage as many of its high-emitting clients in the most carbon-intensive sectors to commit to net- zero. However, due to alternating dynamics internationally with regards to net-zero commitments, the bank no longer believes it is realistic to achieve the ambition of 90% from 2026 onwards. Nevertheless, Deutsche Bank will report annually on the progress regarding this ambition - Deutsche Bank aims to implement and publish its Transition Finance Framework in 2025 In 2024, Deutsche Bank continued to deliver on its environmental dimension. Key achievements include:
  • While Deutsche Bank has not formally joined the Science-Based Targets initiative (SBTi), Deutsche Bank has adopted SBTi targets and as such, commits to a reduction in operational Scope 3 emission (excluding financed emission - Category 15) of 46% by 2030 compared to the 2019 baseline, equivalent to 4.3% per year.
  • ### Summary of the Table: The table outlines sector-specific net-zero alignment targets based on various scenarios, scopes, and metrics, with baseline years ranging from 2021 to 2023. The sectors covered include Oil and Gas (Upstream), Power Generation, Automotives (Light Duty), Steel, Coal Mining, Cement, Shipping, and Commercial Aviation. 1. **Oil and Gas (Upstream)**: Scope 3 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario aim to reduce MtCO2/y from 23.4 in 2021 to 18.0 by 2030, a 23% reduction. 2. **Power Generation**: Scope 1 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario target kgCO2e/MWh reductions from 396 in 2021 to 124 by 2030, a 69% reduction. 3. **Automotives (Light Duty)**: Scope 3 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario aim to lower gCO2/vkm from 190 in 2021 to 77 by 2030, a 59% reduction. 4. **Steel**: Scope 1 and 2 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario target kgCO2e/t steel reductions from 1,519 in 2021 to 1,004 by 2030, a 34% reduction. 5. **Coal Mining**: Scope 3 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario aim to reduce MtCO2/y from 7.9 in 2022 to 4.0 by 2030, a 49% reduction. 6. **Cement**: Scope 1 and 2 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario target kgCO2e/t cement reductions from 731 in 2022 to 520 by 2030, a 29% reduction. 7. **Shipping**: Scope 1 emissions under the Revised IMO Strategy (Minimum and Striving scenarios) show a Portfolio Climate Alignment Score (%) baseline of 14.1 in 2022, with a striving target reduction of 18.3 percentage points. 8. **Commercial Aviation**: Scope 1 emissions under the MPP PRU scenario aim for a Portfolio Climate Alignment Score (%) reduction of 1.3 percentage points from 2023 to 2030. The table also includes total loan commitments (€ bn) for each sector, ranging from 0.3 to 12.4.

  • ### END TABLE 1.2 Deutsche Bank will publish year-end 2024 Portfolio Climate Alignment Scores in next year's Sustainability Statement. Change vs. baseline is N/A for Commercial Aviation as this is the first year of publication Achieved and expected emissions reductions are disclosed in the relevant columns of the above target table. For Oil and Gas (Upstream) and Coal Mining sectors, these reductions are expressed in absolute terms (i.e. Scope 3 End Use financed emissions). For the remaining sectors, they reflect a change in the physical intensity metric or climate alignment scores (which are expressed in percentages). The conversion of the relative or physical intensity metrics sectoral targets into absolute reductions of GHG emissions (ex. ESRS Requirement E1-4 34a/b) is not disclosed as the Transitional Provisions of ESRS1 par. 133b allows the bank to focus on the more established physical intensity metrics required by the Pillar 3 legislation.

La exposición total de préstamos corporativos por industria es de 101.2 € bn, representando el 100% del portafolio, sin datos específicos identificados a nivel de cliente.

  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta datos relacionados con activos sostenibles ambientalmente y KPIs de rendimiento, inversión (CapEx) y cobertura, con referencia al 31 de diciembre de 2023. Los encabezados incluyen: "Total environmentally sustainable assets (in € m)", "Turnover KPIs", "CapEx KPIs", "% coverage (over total assets)", "% of assets excluded from the numerator of the GAR (Article 7(2) and (3) and Section 1.1.2. of Annex V)", y "% of assets excluded from the denominator of the GAR (Article 7(1) and Section 1.2.4 of Annex V)". Los activos sostenibles totales alcanzaron 490 millones de euros, con un GAR (flow) de 1,259 millones. Los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 0.2 y 0.4 respectivamente, con una cobertura del 17.6% sobre el total de activos. El porcentaje de activos excluidos del numerador del GAR fue del 82.4%, mientras que los excluidos del denominador fueron "N/M". En la categoría "Trading book", los valores son "N/A". En "Financial guarantees", los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 153 y 374 respectivamente, con valores de 0.5 y 1.3. Para "Assets under Management", los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 8,635 y 16,857 respectivamente, con valores de 0.8 y 1.6. Finalmente, en "Fees and commissions income", los valores son "N/A".
  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta datos en FTE al 31 de diciembre de 2023, desglosados por regiones: Alemania, Europa excluyendo Alemania, América, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África, y el Total. 1. **Número de empleados**: Alemania tiene 36,195, Europa excluyendo Alemania 18,103, América 8,232, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,601, con un total de 90,130. 2. **Número de empleados permanentes**: Alemania cuenta con 35,822, Europa excluyendo Alemania 18,066, América 8,232, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,584, sumando un total de 89,703. 3. **Número de empleados temporales**: Alemania tiene 373, Europa excluyendo Alemania 37, América no tiene empleados temporales, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 17, con un total de 427. 4. **Número de empleados con horas no garantizadas**: No hay empleados en esta categoría en ninguna región. 5. **Número de empleados (repetido)**: Alemania tiene 36,195, Europa excluyendo Alemania 18,103, América 8,232, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,601, con un total de 90,130. 6. **Número de empleados a tiempo completo**: Alemania cuenta con 28,686, Europa excluyendo Alemania 17,386, América 8,212, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,585, sumando un total de 81,869. 7. **Número de empleados a tiempo parcial**: Alemania tiene 7,509, Europa excluyendo Alemania 717, América 20, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 16, con un total de 8,261. ### END TABLE

Deutsche Bank se fixe des objectifs de réduction des émissions alignés avec le scénario de Net-Zero Emissions (NZE) de l'Agence Internationale de l'Énergie (AIE) pour plusieurs secteurs, y compris le pétrole et le gaz, la production d'énergie, l'automobile, l'acier, le charbon, le ciment, le transport maritime et l'aviation commerciale. Ces objectifs sont basés sur des trajectoires de décarbonation sectorielles qui visent à atteindre la neutralité carbone d'ici 2050, avec des cibles intermédiaires pour 2030.

Cependant, Deutsche Bank n'a pas formellement rejoint l'initiative Science-Based Targets (SBTi), bien qu'elle ait adopté des cibles SBTi pour certaines de ses opérations, notamment une réduction de 46% des émissions opérationnelles de Scope 3 d'ici 2030 par rapport à 2019.

Il n'est pas explicitement mentionné que les objectifs de réduction de Deutsche Bank sont alignés avec une trajectoire de réchauffement à 1,5°C, conformément aux Accords de Paris. L'entreprise n'indique pas de manière claire si sa neutralité carbone est alignée avec les recommandations spécifiques de l'Accord de Paris.


Afficher les sources Azure
Sources Azure :
  • as this is the first year of publication Achieved and expected emissions reductions are disclosed in the relevant columns of the above target table. For Oil and Gas (Upstream) and Coal Mining sectors, these reductions are expressed in absolute terms (i.e. Scope 3 End Use financed emissions). For the remaining sectors, they reflect a change in the physical intensity metric or climate alignment scores (which are expressed in percentages). The conversion of the relative or physical intensity metrics sectoral targets into absolute reductions of GHG emissions (ex. ESRS Requirement E1 -4 34a/b) is not disclosed as the Transitional Provisions of ESRS1 par. 133b allows the bank to focus on the mor e established physical intensity metrics required by the Pillar 3 legislation. Since the inception of net -zero targets, the bank is making considerable decarbonization progress across sectors which as this is the first year of publication Achieved and expected emissions reductions are disclosed in the relevant columns of the above target table.   • Deutsche Bank’s ambition level includes clear, quantifiable targets — both for decarbonizing portfolios in high -carbon emission industries and for growing sustainable business. Transition Plan ESRS E1 -1 Since Deutsche Bank’s Management Board made sustainability a strategic priority in 2019, the bank has made significant progress toward achieving its interim targets for 2030. In October 2023, Deutsche Bank published its Initial Transition Plan, which outlines the progress made and the strategy to reach its net -zero commitment. This plan consolidates the bank’s definitions, methodologies, targets and achievements on its path. Th e progress is detailed in the respective chapters of this Sustainability Statement , including the “Sustainability Strategy” and “Client portfolios” chapters. The plan adopts a holistic approach to the bank’s net -zero transition to support the Paris Agreement climate targets by Deutsche Bank’s ambition level includes clear, quantifiable targets — both for decarbonizing portfolios in high -carbon emission industries and for growing sustainable business.   • Strategy ESRS 2 SBM -3 Deutsche Bank is committed to protecting its clients, society, and its own assets by taking an active role in the prevention, detection, and reporting of financial crime. Recognizing the material threats posed by financial crime, the Anti -Financial Crime f unction has defined a uniform strategy across financial crime risk prevention, detection, and reporting to ensure the highest level of protection for Deutsche Bank’s clients and stakeholders, while also supporting sustainable business practices. The Anti -Financial Crime strategy focuses on remediation, simplification, and consolidation of processes, and evolving the AFC Program across the areas of risk appetite, risk assessment, policy, training, assurance and reporting. The strategy serves to accelerate de cision -making around financial crime risks, enforce consistent standards, and foster Strategy ESRS 2 SBM -3 Deutsche Bank is committed to protecting its clients, society, and its own assets by taking an active role in the prevention, detection, and reporting of financial crime. Recognizing the material threats posed by financial crime, the Anti -Financial Crime f unction has defined a uniform strategy across financial crime risk prevention, detection, and reporting to ensure the highest level of protection for Deutsche Bank’s clients and stakeholders, while also supporting sustainable business practices. The Anti -Financial Crime strategy focuses on remediation, simplification, and consolidation of processes, and evolving the AFC Program across the areas of risk appetite, risk assessment, policy, training, assurance and reporting. The strategy serves to accelerate de cision -making around financial crime risks, enforce consistent standards, and foster
  • continues to further devel op them. Next to the Chief Sustainability Office, an additional enabler are ESG expert teams in the bank’s business divisions and infrastructure functions that foster the implementation of Deutsche Bank’s sustainability strategy and allow for a swift respo nse to emerging business opportunities and potential risks. In the years ahead, Deutsche Bank aims to broaden the scope of decarbonization, i.e., progressing from financed emissions to financed and facilitated emissions and capturing opportunities in the bank’s private clients’ assets under management. Moreover, De utsche Bank focuses on incorporating nature and biodiversity as well as just transition, which means to address the challenges of transitioning for developing economies. To operationalize its commitments, the bank is further developing the Initial Transition Plan as tools, methodologies and continues to further devel op them.   • valuation, monitoring , and review over the life of the loan. Deutsche Bank’s underwriting standards require real estate collateral to be appropriately insured against relevant risks including applicable natural hazards. In some countries, supplemental insurance against natural hazards is provided by the government. The European residential real estate portfolio amounted to € 166.4 billion at year -end 2024. Residential mortgages for private clients in Germany represent approximately 92% of this amount and around 1.2 million German private residences financed by loans secured by immovable properties are insured appropriately against relevant risks including applicable natural hazards. The insurance cover by real estate owners is monitored and complemented or substituted by De utsche Bank´s own insurance. In addition, new valuations and re -valuations require the identification of material environmental physical and transition valuation, monitoring , and review over the life of the loan. In some countries, supplemental insurance against natural hazards is provided by the government. The European residential real estate portfolio amounted to € 166.4 billion at year -end 2024. Residential mortgages for private clients in Germany represent approximately 92% of this amount and around 1.2 million German private residences financed by loans secured by immovable properties are insured appropriately against relevant risks including applicable natural hazards. The insurance cover by real estate owners is monitored and complemented or substituted by De utsche Bank´s own insurance. In addition, new valuations and re -valuations require the identification of material environmental physical and transition
E1-6

Quels sont les leviers de décarbonation identifiés dans le plan de transition de l'entreprise ?

Pour répondre à cette question, nous souhaitons avoir la liste ou les noms des actions menées, accompagnées d'une description simple. Si possible, afficher les objectifs de réduction pour chacune des actions, avec l'année cible et l'année de référence.

1. Nom de l'action ou du projet de réduction.
2. Métrique.
3. Périmètre des émissions (Scope 1, 2 ou 3).
4. Année de référence.
5. Objectif de réduction.
6. Année cible. Des informations moins primordiales, mais souhaitables pourraient être :

- La méthodologie utilisée ou l'initiative correspondante.
- Les objectifs intermédiaires (2030, 2035, 2040, 2045).

Pour répondre à la question concernant les leviers de décarbonation identifiés dans le plan de transition de Deutsche Bank, voici les actions et objectifs mentionnés dans les documents :

  1. Réduction de la consommation énergétique

    • Métrique : Réduction de la consommation totale d'énergie.
    • Périmètre des émissions : Scope 1 et 2.
    • Année de référence : 2019.
    • Objectif de réduction : Réduire la consommation énergétique de 30%.
    • Année cible : 2025.

  2. Utilisation d'électricité renouvelable

    • Métrique : Sourcing d'électricité.
    • Périmètre des émissions : Scope 1 et 2.
    • Objectif de réduction : S'approvisionner à 100% en électricité renouvelable.
    • Année cible : 2025.

  3. Réduction de la consommation de carburant de la flotte automobile

    • Métrique : Consommation de carburant de la flotte automobile de Deutsche Bank.
    • Périmètre des émissions : Scope 1 et 2.
    • Année de référence : Non spécifiée.
    • Objectif de réduction : Réduire la consommation de 30% et atteindre la neutralité carbone en Allemagne.
    • Année cible : 2025 pour la réduction de carburant, et 2030 pour la neutralité carbone.

  4. Partenariat avec les clients pour la décarbonation

    • Métrique : Activités de financement et transition des modèles d'affaires des clients.
    • Périmètre des émissions : Scope 3, Category 15.
    • Méthodologie : Approche en trois volets - assistance aux entreprises pour la réduction des émissions, soutien à la transition des modèles d'affaires, et élimination progressive des affaires avec des industries difficiles à décarboner comme le charbon thermique.

  5. Décarbonation de la chaîne d'approvisionnement

    • Métrique : Réduction des émissions de la chaîne d'approvisionnement.
    • Périmètre des émissions : Scope 3, Categories 1 à 14.
    • Méthodologie : Réduction de l'utilisation des ressources, substitution par des alternatives à faible carbone, et compensation des émissions résiduelles.

Ces actions s'inscrivent dans le cadre de l'Initial Transition Plan de Deutsche Bank, qui vise à soutenir les objectifs climatiques de l'Accord de Paris en réduisant l'empreinte carbone de ses opérations et en influençant positivement ses clients et sa chaîne d'approvisionnement.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • ## Environmental information Climate change The key levers to reduce the bank's emissions resulting from its own operations (Scope 1 and 2 emissions) include reducing energy consumption, sourcing more electricity from renewables, reducing business travel and using offsets for residual emissions. The associated targets to reduce Scope 1 and 2 emissions include: - Compensating for emissions from own operations (Scope 1 and 2) and business travel - Reducing total energy consumption by 30% by 2025 versus 2019 - Sourcing 100% renewable electricity by 2025 - Reducing fuel consumption of Deutsche Bank's car fleet by 30% by 2025 and reaching carbon zero in Germany by 2030 ## Environmental information Climate change The key levers to reduce the bank's emissions resulting from its own operations (Scope 1 and 2 emissions) include reducing energy consumption, sourcing more electricity from renewables, reducing business travel and using offsets for residual emissions. The associated targets to reduce Scope 1 and 2 emissions include: - Compensating for emissions from own operations (Scope 1 and 2) and business travel - Reducing total energy consumption by 30% by 2025 versus 2019 - Sourcing 100% renewable electricity by 2025 - Reducing fuel consumption of Deutsche Bank's car fleet by 30% by 2025 and reaching carbon zero in Germany by 2030
  • ### Transition plan for climate change mitigation Deutsche Bank's initial transition plan for climate change mitigation is described in detail in the "Transition Plan" sub- chapter as part of the "Climate Change" chapter of this Sustainability Statement. ### Transition plan for climate change mitigation Deutsche Bank's initial transition plan for climate change mitigation is described in detail in the "Transition Plan" sub- chapter as part of the "Climate Change" chapter of this Sustainability Statement.
  • ### Decarbonization in the supply chain As part of its ongoing commitment to reduce the environmental impact of suppliers, the bank is an active participant in the Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP) Supply Chain program, where members can engage with the suppliers to identify risks and opportunities and share carbon emissions data. In 2023, Deutsche Bank published an Initial Transition Plan which outlines what the bank's overall approach to decarbonization looks like and the journey towards realizing net-zero. In 2024, Deutsche Bank expanded the scope of suppliers asked to share CDP data from 240 in the previous year to 400 suppliers. These represent 74% of the total supplier spend and are therefore critical in supporting Deutsche Bank realizing its net- zero ambition. ### Decarbonization in the supply chain As part of its ongoing commitment to reduce the environmental impact of suppliers, the bank is an active participant in the Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP) Supply Chain program, where members can engage with the suppliers to identify risks and opportunities and share carbon emissions data. In 2023, Deutsche Bank published an Initial Transition Plan which outlines what the bank's overall approach to decarbonization looks like and the journey towards realizing net-zero. In 2024, Deutsche Bank expanded the scope of suppliers asked to share CDP data from 240 in the previous year to 400 suppliers. These represent 74% of the total supplier spend and are therefore critical in supporting Deutsche Bank realizing its net- zero ambition.
  • In the years ahead, Deutsche Bank aims to broaden the scope of decarbonization, i.e., progressing from financed emissions to financed and facilitated emissions and capturing opportunities in the bank's private clients' assets under management. Moreover, Deutsche Bank focuses on incorporating nature and biodiversity as well as just transition, which means to address the challenges of transitioning for developing economies. To operationalize its commitments, the bank is further developing the Initial Transition Plan as tools, methodologies and data for assessing the climate impact of its own operations, supply chain and clients' activities continue to evolve. Therefore, Deutsche Bank includes forward-looking information and gives an outlook on how the bank will further broaden the scope of its transition plan, specifically concerning financed emissions. In the years ahead, Deutsche Bank aims to broaden the scope of decarbonization, i.e., progressing from financed emissions to financed and facilitated emissions and capturing opportunities in the bank's private clients' assets under management. Moreover, Deutsche Bank focuses on incorporating nature and biodiversity as well as just transition, which means to address the challenges of transitioning for developing economies. To operationalize its commitments, the bank is further developing the Initial Transition Plan as tools, methodologies and data for assessing the climate impact of its own operations, supply chain and clients' activities continue to evolve. Therefore, Deutsche Bank includes forward-looking information and gives an outlook on how the bank will further broaden the scope of its transition plan, specifically concerning financed emissions.
  • The bank implemented a decarbonization framework to reduce emissions resulting from its supply chain (Scope 3, Categories 1 to 14). This framework follows three levers: (1) reducing resource use, (2) substituting current resources with lower-carbon alternatives and (3) offsetting residual emissions where reduction is not feasible. In 2024, the bank's Scope 1 and 2 emissions as well as Scope 3, Categories 1 to 14 emissions did not meet the double materiality threshold and are therefore not included in the disclosures of this Sustainability Statement. Instead, Deutsche Bank provides detailed information on its approach in the Initial Transition Plan. The bank implemented a decarbonization framework to reduce emissions resulting from its supply chain (Scope 3, Categories 1 to 14). This framework follows three levers: (1) reducing resource use, (2) substituting current resources with lower-carbon alternatives and (3) offsetting residual emissions where reduction is not feasible. In 2024, the bank's Scope 1 and 2 emissions as well as Scope 3, Categories 1 to 14 emissions did not meet the double materiality threshold and are therefore not included in the disclosures of this Sustainability Statement. Instead, Deutsche Bank provides detailed information on its approach in the Initial Transition Plan.
  • While Deutsche Bank wants to lead by example in the decarbonization of its own operations, partnering with its clients to support them on the path toward net-zero is the main lever for decarbonizing its financing activities and thus contributing to the transition of the wider economy. This requires a continuous assessment of its clients and intensive engagements with them. Here, Deutsche Bank pursues a three-pronged approach: (1) assisting companies that enable emission reduction, (2) supporting them to transition their business models and (3) phasing out business with not-to-abate industries such as thermal coal. While Deutsche Bank wants to lead by example in the decarbonization of its own operations, partnering with its clients to support them on the path toward net-zero is the main lever for decarbonizing its financing activities and thus contributing to the transition of the wider economy. This requires a continuous assessment of its clients and intensive engagements with them. Here, Deutsche Bank pursues a three-pronged approach: (1) assisting companies that enable emission reduction, (2) supporting them to transition their business models and (3) phasing out business with not-to-abate industries such as thermal coal.
  • The initial Transition Plan was published in October 2023. The next iteration will focus on full alignment with ESRS requirements. During the annual planning process, Deutsche Bank continues to consider the latest net-zero scenarios and economy-wide pathways to identify investment needs and their influence on the bank's sustainable financing and investment plan. The Initial Transition Plan publication, along with the net-zero pathways and decarbonization targets were approved by the Group Sustainability Committee. The Management Board has delegated sustainability-related decisions to this committee. Therefore, the Group Sustainability Committee acts as the main governance and decision-making body for sustainability-related matters for Deutsche Bank Group. The initial Transition Plan was published in October 2023. The next iteration will focus on full alignment with ESRS requirements. During the annual planning process, Deutsche Bank continues to consider the latest net-zero scenarios and economy-wide pathways to identify investment needs and their influence on the bank's sustainable financing and investment plan. The Initial Transition Plan publication, along with the net-zero pathways and decarbonization targets were approved by the Group Sustainability Committee. The Management Board has delegated sustainability-related decisions to this committee. Therefore, the Group Sustainability Committee acts as the main governance and decision-making body for sustainability-related matters for Deutsche Bank Group.
  • The plan adopts a holistic approach to the bank's net-zero transition to support the Paris Agreement climate targets by focusing on three dimensions of decarbonization: the bank's own operations (Scope 1 and 2, including DWS); Deutsche Bank's supply chain (Scope 3, Categories 1 to 14, including DWS business travel emissions); and financing provided to clients (Scope 3, Category 15). In 2024, carbon emissions across these three areas were as follows: Carbon footprint 2024 in ktCO2e 427,803 64,742 32,750 undrawn 292,694 undrawn 31,993 drawn 135,108 drawn 33 1,078 2,233 Own operations Supply chain EU residential real estate exposure Corporate loan exposure (Scope 1&2; committed) Corporate loan exposure (Scope 3; committed) :unselected: Scope 1 and 2 Scope 3 (Category 1-14) :selected: Scope 3 (Category 15) Numbers may not add up due to rounding The plan adopts a holistic approach to the bank's net-zero transition to support the Paris Agreement climate targets by focusing on three dimensions of decarbonization: the bank's own operations (Scope 1 and 2, including DWS); Deutsche Bank's supply chain (Scope 3, Categories 1 to 14, including DWS business travel emissions); and financing provided to clients (Scope 3, Category 15).
