  • mapped to the bank’s loan commitments and clients’ EVIC to calculate financed emissions at the client and portfolio levels. For selected mortgage and commercial real estate portfolios, emissions are estimated using proxies which are based on Energy Performance Certificate rat ings and internal methodologies. The tables below show the overall corporate industry loan exposure and financed emissions broken down by the top ten sectors which contribute to the largest amount of the bank’s summed Scope 1, 2, and 3 financed emissions. Any differences in top ten sector rankings shown in the year -end 2024 and 2023 tables are due to changes in the bank’s portfolio composition of clients. The table also shows how much Scope 1, 2, and 3 financed emissions stem from clients which are also tracked in the NZ target framework. Lastly, the table shows total lending of the bank secured by real estate, as well as loan exposure and financed emissions of the EU residential real estate portfolio. 277 mapped to the bank’s loan commitments and clients’ EVIC to calculate financed emissions at the client and portfolio levels. For selected mortgage and commercial real estate portfolios, emissions are estimated using proxies which are based on Energy Performance Certificate rat ings and internal methodologies. The tables below show the overall corporate industry loan exposure and financed emissions broken down by the top ten sectors which contribute to the largest amount of the bank’s summed Scope 1, 2, and 3 financed emissions. Any differences in top ten sector rankings shown in the year -end 2024 and 2023 tables are due to changes in the bank’s portfolio composition of clients. The table also shows how much Scope 1, 2, and 3 financed emissions stem from clients which are also tracked in the NZ target framework. Lastly, the table shows total lending of the bank secured by real estate, as well as loan exposure and financed emissions of the EU residential real estate portfolio. 277
  • hence excluded fr om financed emissions calculations – Corporate lending is identified according to Deutsche Bank’s internal sectoral classifications. The bank excludes all lending to financial institutions, public sector, real estate, and securitizations – Scope 1, 2, and 3 financed emissions are calculated on a total loan commitment basis so as to align with the approach used for the bank’s decarbonization targets 280 Deutsche Bank Environmental information Annual Report 2024 Climate change – The financed emissions figures rely on client -specific data as well as proxy emissions factors. Scope 1 and 2 client - specific emissions data is sourced from MSCI and is always reported data from the client. Scope 3 client -specific emissions data is sourced from MSCI and can be either reported or estimated using MSCI’s proprie tary logic. Scope 1 and 2 proxy emission factors are sourced from PCAF and use the 2019 Exiobase dataset (Exiobase v3.7, base year 2015) hence excluded fr om financed emissions calculations – Corporate lending is identified according to Deutsche Bank’s internal sectoral classifications. The bank excludes all lending to financial institutions, public sector, real estate, and securitizations – Scope 1, 2, and 3 financed emissions are calculated on a total loan commitment basis so as to align with the approach used for the bank’s decarbonization targets 280 Deutsche Bank Environmental information Annual Report 2024 Climate change – The financed emissions figures rely on client -specific data as well as proxy emissions factors. Scope 1 and 2 client - specific emissions data is sourced from MSCI and is always reported data from the client. Scope 3 client -specific emissions data is sourced from MSCI and can be either reported or estimated using MSCI’s proprie tary logic. Scope 1 and 2 proxy emission factors are sourced from PCAF and use the 2019 Exiobase dataset (Exiobase v3.7, base year 2015)
  • aspects such as affordab le living, as well as customer protection schemes, client willingness and the client’s financial capacity play a decisive role. 275 Deutsche Bank Environmental information Annual Report 2024 Climate change 276 Deutsche Bank Environmental information Annual Report 2024 Climate change Financed Emissions: Scope 3 Category 15 ESRS E1 -6 The financed emissions calculations follow the Partnership for Carbon Accounting Financials (“PCAF”) Standard as detailed in the Methodological Notes in this section and are in line with the recommendations of the Task Force on Climate - related Financial Di sclosures (see their Guidance on Metrics, Targets, and Transition Plans). Financed emissions calculations are based on disclosed Scope 1, 2, and 3 emissions of Deutsche Bank’s clients. Such emission data is sourced from third -party providers, and if client -level data is not available, proxy data is used. This data is aspects such as affordab le living, as well as customer protection schemes, client willingness and the client’s financial capacity play a decisive role. 275 Deutsche Bank Environmental information Annual Report 2024 Climate change 276 Deutsche Bank Environmental information Annual Report 2024 Climate change Financed Emissions: Scope 3 Category 15 ESRS E1 -6 The financed emissions calculations follow the Partnership for Carbon Accounting Financials (“PCAF”) Standard as detailed in the Methodological Notes in this section and are in line with the recommendations of the Task Force on Climate - related Financial Di sclosures (see their Guidance on Metrics, Targets, and Transition Plans). Financed emissions calculations are based on disclosed Scope 1, 2, and 3 emissions of Deutsche Bank’s clients. Such emission data is sourced from third -party providers, and if client -level data is not available, proxy data is used. This data is
E1-133

Intensité des émissions totales du groupe :
Calculez l'intensité des émissions de gaz à effet total dans l'année 2024.

Le calcul consiste à diviser les émissions totales par le chiffre d'affaires.
Le calcul consiste à diviser les émissions totales par le chiffre d'affaires.
L'unité est tCO2e/€m.
Il faut présenter le total de chiffres d'affaires utilisé pour calculer l'intensité en GES.


Privilégier l'utilisation d'un tableau pour présenter les résultats.
Donner les années précédentes si l'information est disponible.

Je suis désolé, mais les informations nécessaires pour calculer l'intensité des émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GES) en 2024, telles que le chiffre d'affaires total, ne sont pas fournies dans les documents que vous avez partagés. Par conséquent, je ne peux pas réaliser ce calcul.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • Oil and Gas (Upstream): Scope 3 financed emissions stood at 19.2 MtCO2/y as of year-end 2024, 4% higher year-on-year but 18% below the 2021 baseline and below the NZ target pathway when linearly interpolating between 2021 and 2030. The temporary effects seen in the first year (year-end 2022) which led to a sharp decline in financed emissions are now being partially reversed as expected. Since target inception, the overall financed emissions reduced in line with the linear reduction pathway implied by the 2030 net zero target. Total loan commitments marginally increased year-on-year from € 9.4 billion to € 9.6 billion. The year-on-year increase in financed emissions can be explained by three factors: (i) client emission factors (tCO2/€ m) which led to an increase of 1.9 MtCO2/y; (ii) active management of the portfolio which led to a decrease of 0.8 MtCO2/y; and (iii) loan exposure FX translation effects from 2022 to 2023 predominantly driven by U.S. dollar depreciating versus the euro Oil and Gas (Upstream): Scope 3 financed emissions stood at 19.2 MtCO2/y as of year-end 2024, 4% higher year-on-year but 18% below the 2021 baseline and below the NZ target pathway when linearly interpolating between 2021 and 2030. The temporary effects seen in the first year (year-end 2022) which led to a sharp decline in financed emissions are now being partially reversed as expected. Since target inception, the overall financed emissions reduced in line with the linear reduction pathway implied by the 2030 net zero target. Total loan commitments marginally increased year-on-year from € 9.4 billion to € 9.6 billion. The year-on-year increase in financed emissions can be explained by three factors: (i) client emission factors (tCO2/€ m) which led to an increase of 1.9 MtCO2/y; (ii) active management of the portfolio which led to a decrease of 0.8 MtCO2/y; and (iii) loan exposure FX translation effects from 2022 to 2023 predominantly driven by U.S. dollar depreciating versus the euro
  • - For Scope 1 and 2 financed emissions, due to the general rise of Enterprise Values (including Cash) (EVICs) from 2022 to 2023, client-specific emission factors decreased which led to a financed emissions reduction of 1.4 MtCO2e/y. For Scope 3 financed emissions, the same effect also led to a financed emissions reduction of 2.1 MtCO2e/y - Data quality improved year-on-year which led to a financed emissions decrease of 0.1 MtCO2e/y for Scope 1 and 2 and an increase of 8.7 MtCO2e/y for Scope 3 financed emissions - Year-on-year FX translation effects of euro-equivalent loan exposures led to a financed emissions increase of 0.9 MtCO2e/y and 9.2 MtCO2e/y for Scope 1 and 2 versus Scope 3 financed emissions, respectively. This is due to the U.S. dollar strengthening against the euro between year-end 2023 and year-end 2024 - For Scope 1 and 2 financed emissions, due to the general rise of Enterprise Values (including Cash) (EVICs) from 2022 to 2023, client-specific emission factors decreased which led to a financed emissions reduction of 1.4 MtCO2e/y. For Scope 3 financed emissions, the same effect also led to a financed emissions reduction of 2.1 MtCO2e/y - Data quality improved year-on-year which led to a financed emissions decrease of 0.1 MtCO2e/y for Scope 1 and 2 and an increase of 8.7 MtCO2e/y for Scope 3 financed emissions - Year-on-year FX translation effects of euro-equivalent loan exposures led to a financed emissions increase of 0.9 MtCO2e/y and 9.2 MtCO2e/y for Scope 1 and 2 versus Scope 3 financed emissions, respectively. This is due to the U.S. dollar strengthening against the euro between year-end 2023 and year-end 2024
  • - The Oil and Gas (Upstream) sector follows a Scope 3 End Use financed emission approach which is expressed as MtCO2/y and covers upstream activities only. Oil and gas production values are converted into emissions by using combustion constants from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Per the PCAF approach, the denominator of the Attribution Factor is EVIC or total assets. The bank expects the Oil and Gas Scope 3 End Use financed emissions to remain volatile due to factors outside of its control such as the evolution of clients' EVIC or total assets which are key inputs into the financed emissions calculation. In order to reduce volatility, the latest (year-end 2024) loan exposure data is converted to EUR-equivalent loan exposures using 2023 FX rates such that is consistent with the bank's latest Scope 3 emission factors. The decarbonization pathway is calibrated from the IEA NZE (2021) datasets 272 - The Oil and Gas (Upstream) sector follows a Scope 3 End Use financed emission approach which is expressed as MtCO2/y and covers upstream activities only. Oil and gas production values are converted into emissions by using combustion constants from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Per the PCAF approach, the denominator of the Attribution Factor is EVIC or total assets. The bank expects the Oil and Gas Scope 3 End Use financed emissions to remain volatile due to factors outside of its control such as the evolution of clients' EVIC or total assets which are key inputs into the financed emissions calculation. In order to reduce volatility, the latest (year-end 2024) loan exposure data is converted to EUR-equivalent loan exposures using 2023 FX rates such that is consistent with the bank's latest Scope 3 emission factors. The decarbonization pathway is calibrated from the IEA NZE (2021) datasets 272
  • Steel: The Scope 1 and 2 physical emission intensity of Deutsche Bank's Steel portfolio was 1,234 kgCO2e/t steel as of year-end 2024, falling 10.8% year-on-year despite a marginal increase of loan commitments from € 2.0 billion to € 2.2 billion. The reduction in physical emission intensity has been predominantly driven by re-balancing towards lower intensity clients. 271 Steel: The Scope 1 and 2 physical emission intensity of Deutsche Bank's Steel portfolio was 1,234 kgCO2e/t steel as of year-end 2024, falling 10.8% year-on-year despite a marginal increase of loan commitments from € 2.0 billion to € 2.2 billion. The reduction in physical emission intensity has been predominantly driven by re-balancing towards lower intensity clients. 271

  • ## Environmental information Climate change ### Corporate Lending Portfolio On a loan outstanding basis, Scope 1 and 2 financed emissions increased year-on-year from 28.1 to 32.0 MtCO2e/y while Scope 3 financed emissions decreased year-on-year from 137.5 to 135.1 MtCO2e/y. On a total corporate lending basis, Scope 1 and 2 financed emissions increased year-on-year from 63.5 to 64.7 MtCO2e/y and Scope 3 financed emissions increased year-on-year from 392.0 to 427.8 MtCO2e/y. Despite Scope 1, 2, and 3 financed emissions increasing year-on- year, Scope 1, 2 versus 3 economic intensities have decreased by 8.3% and 1.9% respectively as total loan commitments have increased 11% year-on-year of which roughly one-quarter can be explained by FX translation effects from 2023 to 2024. ## Environmental information Climate change ### Corporate Lending Portfolio On a loan outstanding basis, Scope 1 and 2 financed emissions increased year-on-year from 28.1 to 32.0 MtCO2e/y while Scope 3 financed emissions decreased year-on-year from 137.5 to 135.1 MtCO2e/y. On a total corporate lending basis, Scope 1 and 2 financed emissions increased year-on-year from 63.5 to 64.7 MtCO2e/y and Scope 3 financed emissions increased year-on-year from 392.0 to 427.8 MtCO2e/y. Despite Scope 1, 2, and 3 financed emissions increasing year-on- year, Scope 1, 2 versus 3 economic intensities have decreased by 8.3% and 1.9% respectively as total loan commitments have increased 11% year-on-year of which roughly one-quarter can be explained by FX translation effects from 2023 to 2024.
  • ### Residential Real Estate Portfolio As of year-end 2024, financed emissions for the European residential real estate portfolio amounted from 2.5 to 2.2 MtCO2e/y with an energy intensity reduction from 13.7 to 13.04 kgCO2e/m2/y. The lower financed emissions in 2024 are mainly driven by the reduced volume size of the mortgage portfolio. The combination of regular repayment and lower loan-to-values reduce the bank's part of financed emissions. ### Residential Real Estate Portfolio As of year-end 2024, financed emissions for the European residential real estate portfolio amounted from 2.5 to 2.2 MtCO2e/y with an energy intensity reduction from 13.7 to 13.04 kgCO2e/m2/y. The lower financed emissions in 2024 are mainly driven by the reduced volume size of the mortgage portfolio. The combination of regular repayment and lower loan-to-values reduce the bank's part of financed emissions.

Je suis désolé, mais les documents fournis ne contiennent pas d'informations spécifiques sur le chiffre d'affaires total utilisé pour calculer l'intensité des émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GES) en 2024 ou les années précédentes. Par conséquent, je ne suis pas en mesure de calculer l'intensité des émissions totales du groupe pour l'année 2024.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • Oil and Gas (Upstream): Scope 3 financed emissions stood at 19.2 MtCO2/y as of year-end 2024, 4% higher year-on-year but 18% below the 2021 baseline and below the NZ target pathway when linearly interpolating between 2021 and 2030. The temporary effects seen in the first year (year-end 2022) which led to a sharp decline in financed emissions are now being partially reversed as expected. Since target inception, the overall financed emissions reduced in line with the linear reduction pathway implied by the 2030 net zero target. Total loan commitments marginally increased year-on-year from € 9.4 billion to € 9.6 billion. The year-on-year increase in financed emissions can be explained by three factors: (i) client emission factors (tCO2/€ m) which led to an increase of 1.9 MtCO2/y; (ii) active management of the portfolio which led to a decrease of 0.8 MtCO2/y; and (iii) loan exposure FX translation effects from 2022 to 2023 predominantly driven by U.S. dollar depreciating versus the euro
  • - For Scope 1 and 2 financed emissions, due to the general rise of Enterprise Values (including Cash) (EVICs) from 2022 to 2023, client-specific emission factors decreased which led to a financed emissions reduction of 1.4 MtCO2e/y. For Scope 3 financed emissions, the same effect also led to a financed emissions reduction of 2.1 MtCO2e/y - Data quality improved year-on-year which led to a financed emissions decrease of 0.1 MtCO2e/y for Scope 1 and 2 and an increase of 8.7 MtCO2e/y for Scope 3 financed emissions - Year-on-year FX translation effects of euro-equivalent loan exposures led to a financed emissions increase of 0.9 MtCO2e/y and 9.2 MtCO2e/y for Scope 1 and 2 versus Scope 3 financed emissions, respectively. This is due to the U.S. dollar strengthening against the euro between year-end 2023 and year-end 2024
  • - The Oil and Gas (Upstream) sector follows a Scope 3 End Use financed emission approach which is expressed as MtCO2/y and covers upstream activities only. Oil and gas production values are converted into emissions by using combustion constants from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Per the PCAF approach, the denominator of the Attribution Factor is EVIC or total assets. The bank expects the Oil and Gas Scope 3 End Use financed emissions to remain volatile due to factors outside of its control such as the evolution of clients' EVIC or total assets which are key inputs into the financed emissions calculation. In order to reduce volatility, the latest (year-end 2024) loan exposure data is converted to EUR-equivalent loan exposures using 2023 FX rates such that is consistent with the bank's latest Scope 3 emission factors. The decarbonization pathway is calibrated from the IEA NZE (2021) datasets 272
  • Steel: The Scope 1 and 2 physical emission intensity of Deutsche Bank's Steel portfolio was 1,234 kgCO2e/t steel as of year-end 2024, falling 10.8% year-on-year despite a marginal increase of loan commitments from € 2.0 billion to € 2.2 billion. The reduction in physical emission intensity has been predominantly driven by re-balancing towards lower intensity clients. 271
  • effects from 2022 to 2023 predominantly driven by U.S. dollar depreciating versus the euro which led to financed emissions decreasing by 0.4 MtCO2/y. The bank expects Oil and Gas financed emissions to remain volatile due to factors outside of its control such as the evolution of clients' EVIC or total assets which are key inputs into the calculation.

  • ## Environmental information Climate change ### Corporate Lending Portfolio On a loan outstanding basis, Scope 1 and 2 financed emissions increased year-on-year from 28.1 to 32.0 MtCO2e/y while Scope 3 financed emissions decreased year-on-year from 137.5 to 135.1 MtCO2e/y. On a total corporate lending basis, Scope 1 and 2 financed emissions increased year-on-year from 63.5 to 64.7 MtCO2e/y and Scope 3 financed emissions increased year-on-year from 392.0 to 427.8 MtCO2e/y. Despite Scope 1, 2, and 3 financed emissions increasing year-on- year, Scope 1, 2 versus 3 economic intensities have decreased by 8.3% and 1.9% respectively as total loan commitments have increased 11% year-on-year of which roughly one-quarter can be explained by FX translation effects from 2023 to 2024.
  • ### Residential Real Estate Portfolio As of year-end 2024, financed emissions for the European residential real estate portfolio amounted from 2.5 to 2.2 MtCO2e/y with an energy intensity reduction from 13.7 to 13.04 kgCO2e/m2/y. The lower financed emissions in 2024 are mainly driven by the reduced volume size of the mortgage portfolio. The combination of regular repayment and lower loan-to-values reduce the bank's part of financed emissions.
  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta datos relacionados con activos sostenibles ambientalmente y KPIs de rendimiento, inversión (CapEx) y cobertura, con referencia al 31 de diciembre de 2023. Los encabezados incluyen: "Total environmentally sustainable assets (in € m)", "Turnover KPIs", "CapEx KPIs", "% coverage (over total assets)", "% of assets excluded from the numerator of the GAR (Article 7(2) and (3) and Section 1.1.2. of Annex V)", y "% of assets excluded from the denominator of the GAR (Article 7(1) and Section 1.2.4 of Annex V)". Los activos sostenibles totales alcanzaron 490 millones de euros, con un GAR (flow) de 1,259 millones. Los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 0.2 y 0.4 respectivamente, con una cobertura del 17.6% sobre el total de activos. El porcentaje de activos excluidos del numerador del GAR fue del 82.4%, mientras que los excluidos del denominador fueron "N/M". En la categoría "Trading book", los valores son "N/A". En "Financial guarantees", los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 153 y 374 respectivamente, con valores de 0.5 y 1.3. Para "Assets under Management", los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 8,635 y 16,857 respectivamente, con valores de 0.8 y 1.6. Finalmente, en "Fees and commissions income", los valores son "N/A".

Los encabezados incluyen: "Total environmentally sustainable assets (in € m)", "Turnover KPIs", "CapEx KPIs", "% coverage (over total assets)", "% of assets excluded from the numerator of the GAR (Article 7(2) and (3) and Section 1.1.2. of Annex V)", y "% of assets excluded from the denominator of the GAR (Article 7(1) and Section 1.2.4 of Annex V)". 1. Los activos sostenibles totales son 820 millones de euros, con un GAR (flow) de 1,392 millones de euros. 2. Los KPIs de Turnover y CapEx son 0.2 y 0.4 respectivamente, con una cobertura del 21.4% sobre el total de activos. 3. El porcentaje de activos excluidos del numerador del GAR es 78.6%, mientras que el porcentaje excluido del denominador es 0.0%. 4. En el libro de trading y los ingresos por comisiones y tarifas, los valores son "N/A". 5. Los activos financieros tienen un Turnover de 783 millones de euros y un CapEx de 1,043 millones de euros, con KPIs de 2.4 y 3.2 respectivamente. 6. Los activos bajo gestión tienen un Turnover de 17,086 millones de euros y un CapEx de 26,933 millones de euros, con KPIs de 1.4 y 2.2 respectivamente. ### END TABLE
  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta datos al 31 de diciembre de 2023 sobre activos sostenibles ambientalmente y KPIs relacionados. Las etiquetas incluyen "Total environmentally sustainable assets (in € m)", "Turnover KPIs", "CapEx KPIs", "% coverage (over total assets)", "% of assets excluded from the numerator of the GAR (Article 7(2) and (3) and Section 1.1.2. of Annex V)", y "% of assets excluded from the denominator of the GAR (Article 7(1) and Section 1.2.4 of Annex V)". En la fila "Main KPI", el "Green asset ratio (GAR) stock" muestra valores de 7,546 millones de euros para "Turnover" y 8,928 millones de euros para "CapEx". Los KPIs de "Turnover" y "CapEx" son 1.3 y 1.5, respectivamente. El porcentaje de cobertura sobre activos totales es 44.2%. Además, el porcentaje de activos excluidos del numerador del GAR es 26.2%, mientras que el porcentaje de activos excluidos del denominador del GAR es 55.8%.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta información sobre la **exposición crediticia** y las **emisiones financiadas** del libro de préstamos corporativos y bienes raíces residenciales al 31 de diciembre de 2024. 1. **Exposición total a préstamos corporativos por industria**: - Total: **€117.7 mil millones** en préstamos pendientes (100% del total) y **€290.3 mil millones** en compromisos totales. - Principales sectores: - **Manufactura e Ingeniería**: €9.8 mil millones pendientes (8.3%), emisiones financiadas Scope 1&2: 1.0 MtCO2e/año. - **Automotriz**: €7.0 mil millones pendientes (5.9%), Scope 1&2: 0.6 MtCO2e/año. - **Petróleo y Gas**: €5.6 mil millones pendientes (4.8%), Scope 1&2: 9.9 MtCO2e/año. - **Servicios Públicos**: €5.2 mil millones pendientes (4.4%), Scope 1&2: 8.1 MtCO2e/año. 2. **Préstamos asegurados por bienes raíces**: - Total: **€240.6 mil millones** (100%), de los cuales **€171.5 mil millones** (71.3%) están asegurados por bienes raíces residenciales y **€69.1 mil millones** (28.7%) por bienes raíces no residenciales. - En la UE: **€166.4 mil millones** (97%), destacando Alemania con **€153.2 mil millones** (92.1%). 3. **Calidad de datos PCAF**: Las puntuaciones de calidad de datos (5 = más baja) varían entre sectores, con valores entre 2.2 y 4.8. 4. **Objetivos net-zero**: Se incluyen sectores como **Petróleo y Gas (Upstream)**, **Generación de Energía**, **Automotriz (vehículos ligeros)**, **Acero**, **Minería de Carbón**, y **Cemento**, con compromisos totales y emisiones financiadas detalladas. 5. **Exclusiones**: Los préstamos securitizados de aviación están excluidos debido a la imposibilidad de aplicar el estándar PCAF.

Je suis désolé, mais les informations nécessaires pour calculer l'intensité des émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GES) en 2024, telles que le chiffre d'affaires total, ne sont pas fournies dans les documents que vous avez partagés. Par conséquent, je ne peux pas réaliser ce calcul.


Afficher les sources Azure
Sources Azure :
  • € 9.4 billion to € 9.6 billion . The year -on-year increase in financed emissions can be explained by three factors: (i) client emission factors (tCO 2/€ m) which led to an increase of 1.9 MtCO 2/y; (ii) active management of the portfolio which led to a decrease of 0.8 MtCO 2/y; and (iii) loan exposure FX translation effects from 2022 to 2023 predominantly driven by U.S. dollar depreciating versus the euro which led to financed emissions decreasing by 0.4 MtCO 2/y. The bank expects Oil and Gas financed emissions to remain volatile due to factors outside of its control such as the evolution of clients’ EVIC or tot al assets which are key inputs into the calculation.   • 2024. The inclusion of the bank’s client’s Scope 3 emissions for the first time has changed the top three sector rankings - Manufacturing and Engineering, Automotives, and Oil and Gas - where for the first and second sectors, their high emissions are driven by t heir total expected lifetime emissions of their sold products. In terms of year -on-year changes, the Utilities sector has been notable as its Scope 1 and 2 financed emissions decreased by 2.7 MtCO 2e/y and its economic intensity decreased by 8.0% which was driven by the movement of a single large client. In terms of Scope 3 financed emissions, the Manufacturing and Engineering sector increased by 33 MtCO 2e/y year -on-year and its economic intensity increased by 22% year -on-year which was mainly driven by a single client with a high emission intensity due to the lifetime emissions of its products sold in the power generation sector.   • client position. The reduction in physical emission intensity came with total loan commitments decreasing year -on-year from € 13.3 billion to € 11.8 billion . Automotive (Light Duty): The Scope 3 physical emission intensity of Deutsche Bank’s Automotive portfolio was 162 gCO 2/vkm as of year -end 2024, 1.8% higher year -on-year but 15% below the 2021 baseline. The portfolio tailpipe emission intensity metric has marginally worsened due to a few material clients whose tailpipe emission intensities increased year -on-year caused by a relative decrease in their production of vehicles with lower emission internal combustion engines (ICE). All of the impacted clients have transition strategies in place. Total loan commitments have remained constant year -on-year. Steel: The Scope 1 and 2 physical emission intensity of Deutsche Bank’s Steel portfolio was 1,234 kgCO 2e/t steel as of client position. The reduction in physical emission intensity came with total loan commitments decreasing year -on-year from € 13.3 billion to € 11.8 billion . The portfolio tailpipe emission intensity metric has marginally worsened due to a few material clients whose tailpipe emission intensities increased year -on-year caused by a relative decrease in their production of vehicles with lower emission internal combustion engines (ICE). All of the impacted clients have transition strategies in place. Total loan commitments have remained constant year -on-year. E1-64

Quelles sont les valeurs liées aux objectifs de réduction du plan de transition. Plusieurs types de réponses sont possibles :

La valeur brute de réduction des gaz à effet de serre (GES), séparée par Scope (1, 2 et 3).
Les cibles de réduction des gaz à effet de serre (GES), exprimées en pourcentage par rapport à une année de référence, séparées par Scope (1, 2 et 3).
Les cibles de réduction en intensité monétaire, séparées par Scope (1, 2 et 3).
Il est important de distinguer les cibles par secteur d'activité.
Si les objectifs concernent les émissions financées, il est important de préciser le périmètre concerné (Scope 1, 2 ou 3).


Si possible, préciser la méthodologie utilisée pour fixer l'objectif de référence.
Si possible, préciser si l'objectif est conforme à un scénario de réduction aligné avec l'Accord de Paris.
Merci de bien indiquer les années de référence ainsi que les années cibles pour chaque objectif présenté.

Les objectifs de réduction des gaz à effet de serre (GES) pour Deutsche Bank sont définis pour plusieurs secteurs d'activité et différenciés par Scope 1, 2 et 3. Voici un résumé des valeurs et objectifs disponibles:

  1. Réductions Absolues de GES:

    • Scope 3 pour le secteur Pétrole et Gaz (Upstream) : Les émissions financées devraient diminuer de 23.4 MtCO2/y en 2021 à 18.0 MtCO2/y en 2030, soit une réduction de 23%.
    • Scope 1 pour le secteur de la Génération d'Énergie : Les émissions devraient se réduire de 396 kgCO2e/MWh en 2021 à 124 kgCO2e/MWh en 2030, soit une réduction de 69%.

  2. Réductions en Pourcentage:

    • Scope 3 pour le secteur Automobile (véhicules légers) : Les émissions devraient baisser de 190 gCO2/vkm en 2021 à 77 gCO2/vkm en 2030, soit une réduction de 59%.
    • Scope 1 et 2 pour le secteur Acier : Les émissions devraient diminuer de 1,519 kgCO2e/t d'acier en 2021 à 1,004 kgCO2e/t en 2030, soit une réduction de 34%.

  3. Réductions d'Intensité Monétaire:

    • Les détails spécifiques sur les réductions d'intensité monétaire ne sont pas fournis dans les documents disponibles.

  4. Conformité avec les Scénarios Alignés sur l'Accord de Paris:

    • Les réductions sont alignées sur le scénario NZE (Net Zero Emissions) de l'AIE (Agence Internationale de l'Énergie), ce qui est conforme aux objectifs de l'Accord de Paris pour limiter le réchauffement climatique.

  5. Années de Référence et Années Cibles:

    • Les années de référence varient par secteur, majoritairement 2021 ou 2022, avec des objectifs principalement fixés pour 2030.

  6. Méthodologie de Fixation des Objectifs:

    • La méthodologie inclut l'utilisation de scénarios de l'AIE et d'alignement climatique basé sur des scores d'alignement climatique de portefeuille.

Les informations précises sur les méthodologies supplémentaires ou les cibles de réduction en intensité monétaire ne sont pas fournies dans les documents disponibles.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • ### END TABLE 1.2 Deutsche Bank will publish year-end 2024 Portfolio Climate Alignment Scores in next year's Sustainability Statement. Change vs. baseline is N/A for Commercial Aviation as this is the first year of publication Achieved and expected emissions reductions are disclosed in the relevant columns of the above target table. For Oil and Gas (Upstream) and Coal Mining sectors, these reductions are expressed in absolute terms (i.e. Scope 3 End Use financed emissions). For the remaining sectors, they reflect a change in the physical intensity metric or climate alignment scores (which are expressed in percentages). The conversion of the relative or physical intensity metrics sectoral targets into absolute reductions of GHG emissions (ex. ESRS Requirement E1-4 34a/b) is not disclosed as the Transitional Provisions of ESRS1 par. 133b allows the bank to focus on the more established physical intensity metrics required by the Pillar 3 legislation. ### END TABLE 1.2 Deutsche Bank will publish year-end 2024 Portfolio Climate Alignment Scores in next year's Sustainability Statement. Change vs. baseline is N/A for Commercial Aviation as this is the first year of publication Achieved and expected emissions reductions are disclosed in the relevant columns of the above target table. For Oil and Gas (Upstream) and Coal Mining sectors, these reductions are expressed in absolute terms (i.e. Scope 3 End Use financed emissions). For the remaining sectors, they reflect a change in the physical intensity metric or climate alignment scores (which are expressed in percentages). The conversion of the relative or physical intensity metrics sectoral targets into absolute reductions of GHG emissions (ex. ESRS Requirement E1-4 34a/b) is not disclosed as the Transitional Provisions of ESRS1 par. 133b allows the bank to focus on the more established physical intensity metrics required by the Pillar 3 legislation.
  • - For Scope 1 and 2 financed emissions, due to the general rise of Enterprise Values (including Cash) (EVICs) from 2022 to 2023, client-specific emission factors decreased which led to a financed emissions reduction of 1.4 MtCO2e/y. For Scope 3 financed emissions, the same effect also led to a financed emissions reduction of 2.1 MtCO2e/y - Data quality improved year-on-year which led to a financed emissions decrease of 0.1 MtCO2e/y for Scope 1 and 2 and an increase of 8.7 MtCO2e/y for Scope 3 financed emissions - Year-on-year FX translation effects of euro-equivalent loan exposures led to a financed emissions increase of 0.9 MtCO2e/y and 9.2 MtCO2e/y for Scope 1 and 2 versus Scope 3 financed emissions, respectively. This is due to the U.S. dollar strengthening against the euro between year-end 2023 and year-end 2024 - For Scope 1 and 2 financed emissions, due to the general rise of Enterprise Values (including Cash) (EVICs) from 2022 to 2023, client-specific emission factors decreased which led to a financed emissions reduction of 1.4 MtCO2e/y. This is due to the U.S. dollar strengthening against the euro between year-end 2023 and year-end 2024
  • ## Environmental information Climate change The key levers to reduce the bank's emissions resulting from its own operations (Scope 1 and 2 emissions) include reducing energy consumption, sourcing more electricity from renewables, reducing business travel and using offsets for residual emissions. The associated targets to reduce Scope 1 and 2 emissions include: - Compensating for emissions from own operations (Scope 1 and 2) and business travel - Reducing total energy consumption by 30% by 2025 versus 2019 - Sourcing 100% renewable electricity by 2025 - Reducing fuel consumption of Deutsche Bank's car fleet by 30% by 2025 and reaching carbon zero in Germany by 2030 ## Environmental information Climate change The key levers to reduce the bank's emissions resulting from its own operations (Scope 1 and 2 emissions) include reducing energy consumption, sourcing more electricity from renewables, reducing business travel and using offsets for residual emissions. The associated targets to reduce Scope 1 and 2 emissions include: - Compensating for emissions from own operations (Scope 1 and 2) and business travel - Reducing total energy consumption by 30% by 2025 versus 2019 - Sourcing 100% renewable electricity by 2025 - Reducing fuel consumption of Deutsche Bank's car fleet by 30% by 2025 and reaching carbon zero in Germany by 2030
  • The bank implemented a decarbonization framework to reduce emissions resulting from its supply chain (Scope 3, Categories 1 to 14). This framework follows three levers: (1) reducing resource use, (2) substituting current resources with lower-carbon alternatives and (3) offsetting residual emissions where reduction is not feasible. In 2024, the bank's Scope 1 and 2 emissions as well as Scope 3, Categories 1 to 14 emissions did not meet the double materiality threshold and are therefore not included in the disclosures of this Sustainability Statement. Instead, Deutsche Bank provides detailed information on its approach in the Initial Transition Plan. The bank implemented a decarbonization framework to reduce emissions resulting from its supply chain (Scope 3, Categories 1 to 14). This framework follows three levers: (1) reducing resource use, (2) substituting current resources with lower-carbon alternatives and (3) offsetting residual emissions where reduction is not feasible. In 2024, the bank's Scope 1 and 2 emissions as well as Scope 3, Categories 1 to 14 emissions did not meet the double materiality threshold and are therefore not included in the disclosures of this Sustainability Statement. Instead, Deutsche Bank provides detailed information on its approach in the Initial Transition Plan.

The Environmental and Social Policy Framework is described in detail in the "ESG due diligence" chapter within this Sustainability Statement. - The establishment of Early Warning Indicators for concentrations of climate-transition, climate-physical and nature- related risks More information on the bank's metrics and targets, including achieved and expected emission reductions associated to the targets, is provided in the "Metrics and targets" sub-chapter of the "Climate change" chapter.   • ### Summary of the Table: The table outlines sector-specific net-zero alignment targets based on various scenarios, scopes, and metrics, with baseline years ranging from 2021 to 2023. The sectors covered include Oil and Gas (Upstream), Power Generation, Automotives (Light Duty), Steel, Coal Mining, Cement, Shipping, and Commercial Aviation. 1. **Oil and Gas (Upstream)**: Scope 3 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario aim to reduce MtCO2/y from 23.4 in 2021 to 18.0 by 2030, a 23% reduction. 2. **Power Generation**: Scope 1 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario target kgCO2e/MWh reductions from 396 in 2021 to 124 by 2030, a 69% reduction. 3. **Automotives (Light Duty)**: Scope 3 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario aim to lower gCO2/vkm from 190 in 2021 to 77 by 2030, a 59% reduction. 4. **Steel**: Scope 1 and 2 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario target kgCO2e/t steel reductions from 1,519 in 2021 to 1,004 by 2030, a 34% reduction. 5. **Coal Mining**: Scope 3 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario aim to reduce MtCO2/y from 7.9 in 2022 to 4.0 by 2030, a 49% reduction. 6. **Cement**: Scope 1 and 2 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario target kgCO2e/t cement reductions from 731 in 2022 to 520 by 2030, a 29% reduction. 7. **Shipping**: Scope 1 emissions under the Revised IMO Strategy (Minimum and Striving scenarios) show a Portfolio Climate Alignment Score (%) baseline of 14.1 in 2022, with a striving target reduction of 18.3 percentage points. 8. **Commercial Aviation**: Scope 1 emissions under the MPP PRU scenario aim for a Portfolio Climate Alignment Score (%) reduction of 1.3 percentage points from 2023 to 2030. The table also includes total loan commitments (€ bn) for each sector, ranging from 0.3 to 12.4. and

  • - Environmental target: The objective of driving climate risk-management is linked to the disclosed carbon reduction targets for defined carbon intensive sectors that were published when setting of CO2 reduction target pathways for key industries. This metrics measures performance against the published pathway plus an allowed deviation (risk appetite). - Social target: The objective of increasing gender diversity in accordance with the 2 German Gender Quota Law (Zweites Führungspositionen-Gesetzt - FüPoG II) focuses on female representation on the two levels below the Management Board (MB-1) and Management Board (MB-2) positions, which combates discrimination within the Management Board succession pipeline as well as to promote equal opportunity. - Environmental target: The objective of driving climate risk-management is linked to the disclosed carbon reduction targets for defined carbon intensive sectors that were published when setting of CO2 reduction target pathways for key industries.   • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta datos en FTE al 31 de diciembre de 2023, desglosados por regiones: Alemania, Europa excluyendo Alemania, América, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África, y el Total. 1. **Número de empleados**: Alemania tiene 36,195, Europa excluyendo Alemania 18,103, América 8,232, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,601, con un total de 90,130. 2. **Número de empleados permanentes**: Alemania cuenta con 35,822, Europa excluyendo Alemania 18,066, América 8,232, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,584, sumando un total de 89,703. 3. **Número de empleados temporales**: Alemania tiene 373, Europa excluyendo Alemania 37, América no tiene empleados temporales, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 17, con un total de 427. 4. **Número de empleados con horas no garantizadas**: No hay empleados en esta categoría en ninguna región. 5. **Número de empleados (repetido)**: Alemania tiene 36,195, Europa excluyendo Alemania 18,103, América 8,232, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,601, con un total de 90,130. 6. **Número de empleados a tiempo completo**: Alemania cuenta con 28,686, Europa excluyendo Alemania 17,386, América 8,212, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,585, sumando un total de 81,869. 7. **Número de empleados a tiempo parcial**: Alemania tiene 7,509, Europa excluyendo Alemania 717, América 20, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 16, con un total de 8,261. ### END TABLE and

Les objectifs de réduction du plan de transition de Deutsche Bank sont variés et concernent plusieurs secteurs d'activité, avec des cibles pour les émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GES) divisées par Scope et exprimées en termes absolus ou d'intensité. Voici un résumé des informations disponibles :

  1. Réduction des Émissions Brutes de GES :

    • Oil and Gas (Upstream) :
      • Scope 3 : Réduction de 23 % des émissions en MtCO₂/y de 23.4 en 2021 à 18.0 d'ici 2030.
    • Coal Mining :
      • Scope 3 : Réduction de 49 % des émissions en MtCO₂/y de 7.9 en 2022 à 4.0 en 2030.

  2. Réduction en Intensité Monétaire :

    • Power Generation :
      • Scope 1 : Réduction de 69 % en kgCO₂e/MWh de 396 en 2021 à 124 d'ici 2030.
    • Automotives (Light Duty) :
      • Scope 3 : Réduction de 59 % en gCO₂/vkm de 190 en 2021 à 77 d'ici 2030.
    • Steel :
      • Scope 1 et 2 : Réduction de 34 % en kgCO₂e/t steel de 1,519 en 2021 à 1,004 d'ici 2030.
    • Cement :
      • Scope 1 et 2 : Réduction de 29 % en kgCO₂e/t cement de 731 en 2022 à 520 d'ici 2030.

  3. Méthodologie :

    • Les objectifs sont alignés avec le scénario IEA NZE (Net Zero Emissions) qui est conforme à l'Accord de Paris.

  4. Emissions Financières :

    • La banque a également défini des objectifs de réduction pour ses émissions financées dans le cadre de son portefeuille de prêts, en se focalisant principalement sur les secteurs les plus intensifs en carbone.

Ces objectifs sont intégrés dans le cadre de gestion des risques de la banque et sont conformes aux meilleures pratiques de l'industrie, y compris des méthodologies telles que le Paris Agreement Capital Transition Assessment (PACTA).


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • ### END TABLE 1.2 Deutsche Bank will publish year-end 2024 Portfolio Climate Alignment Scores in next year's Sustainability Statement. Change vs. baseline is N/A for Commercial Aviation as this is the first year of publication Achieved and expected emissions reductions are disclosed in the relevant columns of the above target table. For Oil and Gas (Upstream) and Coal Mining sectors, these reductions are expressed in absolute terms (i.e. Scope 3 End Use financed emissions). For the remaining sectors, they reflect a change in the physical intensity metric or climate alignment scores (which are expressed in percentages). The conversion of the relative or physical intensity metrics sectoral targets into absolute reductions of GHG emissions (ex. ESRS Requirement E1-4 34a/b) is not disclosed as the Transitional Provisions of ESRS1 par. 133b allows the bank to focus on the more established physical intensity metrics required by the Pillar 3 legislation.
  • - For Scope 1 and 2 financed emissions, due to the general rise of Enterprise Values (including Cash) (EVICs) from 2022 to 2023, client-specific emission factors decreased which led to a financed emissions reduction of 1.4 MtCO2e/y. For Scope 3 financed emissions, the same effect also led to a financed emissions reduction of 2.1 MtCO2e/y - Data quality improved year-on-year which led to a financed emissions decrease of 0.1 MtCO2e/y for Scope 1 and 2 and an increase of 8.7 MtCO2e/y for Scope 3 financed emissions - Year-on-year FX translation effects of euro-equivalent loan exposures led to a financed emissions increase of 0.9 MtCO2e/y and 9.2 MtCO2e/y for Scope 1 and 2 versus Scope 3 financed emissions, respectively. This is due to the U.S. dollar strengthening against the euro between year-end 2023 and year-end 2024
  • ## Environmental information Climate change The key levers to reduce the bank's emissions resulting from its own operations (Scope 1 and 2 emissions) include reducing energy consumption, sourcing more electricity from renewables, reducing business travel and using offsets for residual emissions. The associated targets to reduce Scope 1 and 2 emissions include: - Compensating for emissions from own operations (Scope 1 and 2) and business travel - Reducing total energy consumption by 30% by 2025 versus 2019 - Sourcing 100% renewable electricity by 2025 - Reducing fuel consumption of Deutsche Bank's car fleet by 30% by 2025 and reaching carbon zero in Germany by 2030
  • The bank implemented a decarbonization framework to reduce emissions resulting from its supply chain (Scope 3, Categories 1 to 14). This framework follows three levers: (1) reducing resource use, (2) substituting current resources with lower-carbon alternatives and (3) offsetting residual emissions where reduction is not feasible. In 2024, the bank's Scope 1 and 2 emissions as well as Scope 3, Categories 1 to 14 emissions did not meet the double materiality threshold and are therefore not included in the disclosures of this Sustainability Statement. Instead, Deutsche Bank provides detailed information on its approach in the Initial Transition Plan.
  • - The establishment of Early Warning Indicators for concentrations of climate-transition, climate-physical and nature- related risks More information on the bank's metrics and targets, including achieved and expected emission reductions associated to the targets, is provided in the "Metrics and targets" sub-chapter of the "Climate change" chapter. The Environmental and Social Policy Framework is described in detail in the "ESG due diligence" chapter within this Sustainability Statement.
  • ### Summary of the Table: The table outlines sector-specific net-zero alignment targets based on various scenarios, scopes, and metrics, with baseline years ranging from 2021 to 2023. The sectors covered include Oil and Gas (Upstream), Power Generation, Automotives (Light Duty), Steel, Coal Mining, Cement, Shipping, and Commercial Aviation. 1. **Oil and Gas (Upstream)**: Scope 3 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario aim to reduce MtCO2/y from 23.4 in 2021 to 18.0 by 2030, a 23% reduction. 2. **Power Generation**: Scope 1 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario target kgCO2e/MWh reductions from 396 in 2021 to 124 by 2030, a 69% reduction. 3. **Automotives (Light Duty)**: Scope 3 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario aim to lower gCO2/vkm from 190 in 2021 to 77 by 2030, a 59% reduction. 4. **Steel**: Scope 1 and 2 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario target kgCO2e/t steel reductions from 1,519 in 2021 to 1,004 by 2030, a 34% reduction. 5. **Coal Mining**: Scope 3 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario aim to reduce MtCO2/y from 7.9 in 2022 to 4.0 by 2030, a 49% reduction. 6. **Cement**: Scope 1 and 2 emissions under the IEA NZE scenario target kgCO2e/t cement reductions from 731 in 2022 to 520 by 2030, a 29% reduction. 7. **Shipping**: Scope 1 emissions under the Revised IMO Strategy (Minimum and Striving scenarios) show a Portfolio Climate Alignment Score (%) baseline of 14.1 in 2022, with a striving target reduction of 18.3 percentage points. 8. **Commercial Aviation**: Scope 1 emissions under the MPP PRU scenario aim for a Portfolio Climate Alignment Score (%) reduction of 1.3 percentage points from 2023 to 2030. The table also includes total loan commitments (€ bn) for each sector, ranging from 0.3 to 12.4.
  • - Environmental target: The objective of driving climate risk-management is linked to the disclosed carbon reduction targets for defined carbon intensive sectors that were published when setting of CO2 reduction target pathways for key industries. This metrics measures performance against the published pathway plus an allowed deviation (risk appetite). - Social target: The objective of increasing gender diversity in accordance with the 2 German Gender Quota Law (Zweites Führungspositionen-Gesetzt - FüPoG II) focuses on female representation on the two levels below the Management Board (MB-1) and Management Board (MB-2) positions, which combates discrimination within the Management Board succession pipeline as well as to promote equal opportunity.
  • ## Environmental information Climate change ### Net-zero targets and forward portfolio pathways Oil and Gas, MtCO2 of financed emissions (Scope 3) 25.0 20.0 19.2 18.0 15.0 10.0 5.0 0.0 2021 2024 2030 2040 2050 Automotive, gCO2/vkm (Scope 3) 200 180 160 162 140 120 100 80 77 60 40 20 0 2021 2024 2030 2040 2050 Coal Mining, MtCO2 of financed emissions (Scope 3) 9.0 8.0 7.0 6.0 5.0 4.6 4.0 3.0 4.0 2.0 1.0 0.0 2022 2024 2030 2040 2050 Shipping (Striving), Climate Alignment Score (%) (Scope 1) 25 20 19.7 15 10 5 0 -5 -10 -15 -20 -25 '22 '23 2030 2040 2050 Deutsche Bank portfolio metric Deutsche Bank portfolio target Power Generation, kgCO2e/MWh (Scope 1) 450 400 350 300 312 250 200 150 100 124 50 0 2021 2024 2030 2040 2050 Steel, kgCO2e/t of steel produced (Scope 1 and 2) 1,600 1,400 1,200 1,234 1,000
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta información sobre la **exposición crediticia** y las **emisiones financiadas** del libro de préstamos corporativos y bienes raíces residenciales al 31 de diciembre de 2024. 1. **Exposición total a préstamos corporativos por industria**: - Total: **€117.7 mil millones** en préstamos pendientes (100% del total) y **€290.3 mil millones** en compromisos totales. - Principales sectores: - **Manufactura e Ingeniería**: €9.8 mil millones pendientes (8.3%), emisiones financiadas Scope 1&2: 1.0 MtCO2e/año. - **Automotriz**: €7.0 mil millones pendientes (5.9%), Scope 1&2: 0.6 MtCO2e/año. - **Petróleo y Gas**: €5.6 mil millones pendientes (4.8%), Scope 1&2: 9.9 MtCO2e/año. - **Servicios Públicos**: €5.2 mil millones pendientes (4.4%), Scope 1&2: 8.1 MtCO2e/año. 2. **Préstamos asegurados por bienes raíces**: - Total: **€240.6 mil millones** (100%), de los cuales **€171.5 mil millones** (71.3%) están asegurados por bienes raíces residenciales y **€69.1 mil millones** (28.7%) por bienes raíces no residenciales. - En la UE: **€166.4 mil millones** (97%), destacando Alemania con **€153.2 mil millones** (92.1%). 3. **Calidad de datos PCAF**: Las puntuaciones de calidad de datos (5 = más baja) varían entre sectores, con valores entre 2.2 y 4.8. 4. **Objetivos net-zero**: Se incluyen sectores como **Petróleo y Gas (Upstream)**, **Generación de Energía**, **Automotriz (vehículos ligeros)**, **Acero**, **Minería de Carbón**, y **Cemento**, con compromisos totales y emisiones financiadas detalladas. 5. **Exclusiones**: Los préstamos securitizados de aviación están excluidos debido a la imposibilidad de aplicar el estándar PCAF.
  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla muestra la exposición de préstamos corporativos por tipo de pérdida de naturaleza al 31 de diciembre de 2023, con datos en € bn y porcentajes del portafolio. Los tipos de pérdida de naturaleza incluyen: "Water depletion" (17.3 € bn, 17.1% del portafolio, 2.2 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 12.7% de estos), "Terrestrial biodiversity and habitat loss" (11.6 € bn, 11.5% del portafolio, 4.6 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 39.2% de estos), "Ecosystem degradation from waste and pollution" (9.2 € bn, 9.1% del portafolio, 5.5 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 60.2% de estos), y "Marine ecosystem degradation" (6.4 € bn, 6.3% del portafolio, 4.7 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 74.0% de estos). La exposición total de préstamos corporativos por industria es de 101.2 € bn, representando el 100% del portafolio, sin datos específicos identificados a nivel de cliente.
  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta datos relacionados con activos sostenibles ambientalmente y KPIs de rendimiento, inversión (CapEx) y cobertura, con referencia al 31 de diciembre de 2023. Los encabezados incluyen: "Total environmentally sustainable assets (in € m)", "Turnover KPIs", "CapEx KPIs", "% coverage (over total assets)", "% of assets excluded from the numerator of the GAR (Article 7(2) and (3) and Section 1.1.2. of Annex V)", y "% of assets excluded from the denominator of the GAR (Article 7(1) and Section 1.2.4 of Annex V)". Los activos sostenibles totales alcanzaron 490 millones de euros, con un GAR (flow) de 1,259 millones. Los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 0.2 y 0.4 respectivamente, con una cobertura del 17.6% sobre el total de activos. El porcentaje de activos excluidos del numerador del GAR fue del 82.4%, mientras que los excluidos del denominador fueron "N/M". En la categoría "Trading book", los valores son "N/A". En "Financial guarantees", los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 153 y 374 respectivamente, con valores de 0.5 y 1.3. Para "Assets under Management", los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 8,635 y 16,857 respectivamente, con valores de 0.8 y 1.6. Finalmente, en "Fees and commissions income", los valores son "N/A".
  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta datos en FTE al 31 de diciembre de 2023, desglosados por regiones: Alemania, Europa excluyendo Alemania, América, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África, y el Total. 1. **Número de empleados**: Alemania tiene 36,195, Europa excluyendo Alemania 18,103, América 8,232, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,601, con un total de 90,130. 2. **Número de empleados permanentes**: Alemania cuenta con 35,822, Europa excluyendo Alemania 18,066, América 8,232, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,584, sumando un total de 89,703. 3. **Número de empleados temporales**: Alemania tiene 373, Europa excluyendo Alemania 37, América no tiene empleados temporales, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 17, con un total de 427. 4. **Número de empleados con horas no garantizadas**: No hay empleados en esta categoría en ninguna región. 5. **Número de empleados (repetido)**: Alemania tiene 36,195, Europa excluyendo Alemania 18,103, América 8,232, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,601, con un total de 90,130. 6. **Número de empleados a tiempo completo**: Alemania cuenta con 28,686, Europa excluyendo Alemania 17,386, América 8,212, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,585, sumando un total de 81,869. 7. **Número de empleados a tiempo parcial**: Alemania tiene 7,509, Europa excluyendo Alemania 717, América 20, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 16, con un total de 8,261. ### END TABLE

Les objectifs de réduction des gaz à effet de serre (GES) pour Deutsche Bank sont définis pour plusieurs secteurs d'activité et différenciés par Scope 1, 2 et 3. Voici un résumé des valeurs et objectifs disponibles:

  1. Réductions Absolues de GES:

    • Scope 3 pour le secteur Pétrole et Gaz (Upstream) : Les émissions financées devraient diminuer de 23.4 MtCO2/y en 2021 à 18.0 MtCO2/y en 2030, soit une réduction de 23%.
    • Scope 1 pour le secteur de la Génération d'Énergie : Les émissions devraient se réduire de 396 kgCO2e/MWh en 2021 à 124 kgCO2e/MWh en 2030, soit une réduction de 69%.

  2. Réductions en Pourcentage:

    • Scope 3 pour le secteur Automobile (véhicules légers) : Les émissions devraient baisser de 190 gCO2/vkm en 2021 à 77 gCO2/vkm en 2030, soit une réduction de 59%.
    • Scope 1 et 2 pour le secteur Acier : Les émissions devraient diminuer de 1,519 kgCO2e/t d'acier en 2021 à 1,004 kgCO2e/t en 2030, soit une réduction de 34%.

  3. Réductions d'Intensité Monétaire:

    • Les détails spécifiques sur les réductions d'intensité monétaire ne sont pas fournis dans les documents disponibles.

  4. Conformité avec les Scénarios Alignés sur l'Accord de Paris:

    • Les réductions sont alignées sur le scénario NZE (Net Zero Emissions) de l'AIE (Agence Internationale de l'Énergie), ce qui est conforme aux objectifs de l'Accord de Paris pour limiter le réchauffement climatique.

  5. Années de Référence et Années Cibles:

    • Les années de référence varient par secteur, majoritairement 2021 ou 2022, avec des objectifs principalement fixés pour 2030.

  6. Méthodologie de Fixation des Objectifs:

    • La méthodologie inclut l'utilisation de scénarios de l'AIE et d'alignement climatique basé sur des scores d'alignement climatique de portefeuille.

Les informations précises sur les méthodologies supplémentaires ou les cibles de réduction en intensité monétaire ne sont pas fournies dans les documents disponibles.

The conversion of the relative or physical intensity metrics sectoral targets into absolute reductions of GHG emissions (ex.   • continues to further devel op them. Next to the Chief Sustainability Office, an additional enabler are ESG expert teams in the bank’s business divisions and infrastructure functions that foster the implementation of Deutsche Bank’s sustainability strategy and allow for a swift respo nse to emerging business opportunities and potential risks. In the years ahead, Deutsche Bank aims to broaden the scope of decarbonization, i.e., progressing from financed emissions to financed and facilitated emissions and capturing opportunities in the bank’s private clients’ assets under management. Moreover, De utsche Bank focuses on incorporating nature and biodiversity as well as just transition, which means to address the challenges of transitioning for developing economies. To operationalize its commitments, the bank is further developing the Initial Transition Plan as tools, methodologies and continues to further devel op them. To operationalize its commitments, the bank is further developing the Initial Transition Plan as tools, methodologies and
  • to 289e of the German Commercial Code (HGB). As the European Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) was not transposed into German law as of December 31, 2024, the bank applied the European Sustainability Reporting Standards (ESRS) as reporting framework as allowed by Section 315c (3) HGB in conjunction with Section 289d HGB and, on that basis, discloses governance, strategy, impact, risk and opportunity management, metrics and targets for material sustainability matters. In addition, the Sustainability Statement complies with the disclosure obligations under Article 8 (1) and (3) of the Taxonomy Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2020/852) and the respective specifications in Articles 4 and 10 (5) of the associated Disclosures de legated Act (Delegated Regulation (EU) 2021/2178). The Sustainability Statement was prepared on a consolidated basis and the scope of consolidation is the same as for the to 289e of the German Commercial Code (HGB).   • commitment as found in the Risk Report section of Deutsche Bank’s Annual Report. As of year -end 2024, loans at amortized cost and irre vocable and revocable lending commitment were € 484.6 billion and € 269.7 billion respectively. – If corporate lending is reported under the bank’s underwriting policy as a position to be de -risked via the capital markets then such corporate lending is excluded from the Net Zero Target Framework – Corporate lending is identified according to Deutsche Bank’s internal sectoral classifications.   • Strategy ESRS 2 SBM -3 Deutsche Bank is committed to protecting its clients, society, and its own assets by taking an active role in the prevention, detection, and reporting of financial crime. Recognizing the material threats posed by financial crime, the Anti -Financial Crime f unction has defined a uniform strategy across financial crime risk prevention, detection, and reporting to ensure the highest level of protection for Deutsche Bank’s clients and stakeholders, while also supporting sustainable business practices. The Anti -Financial Crime strategy focuses on remediation, simplification, and consolidation of processes, and evolving the AFC Program across the areas of risk appetite, risk assessment, policy, training, assurance and reporting. The strategy serves to accelerate de cision -making around financial crime risks, enforce consistent standards, and foster Strategy ESRS 2 SBM -3 Deutsche Bank is committed to protecting its clients, society, and its own assets by taking an active role in the prevention, detection, and reporting of financial crime. Recognizing the material threats posed by financial crime, the Anti -Financial Crime f unction has defined a uniform strategy across financial crime risk prevention, detection, and reporting to ensure the highest level of protection for Deutsche Bank’s clients and stakeholders, while also supporting sustainable business practices. The Anti -Financial Crime strategy focuses on remediation, simplification, and consolidation of processes, and evolving the AFC Program across the areas of risk appetite, risk assessment, policy, training, assurance and reporting. The strategy serves to accelerate de cision -making around financial crime risks, enforce consistent standards, and foster
E1-122

Quelles sont les émissions de gaz à effet de serre liées à la Catégorie 15 du GHG Protocol : émissions financées ?



Pour répondre à cette question, veuillez :
Distinguer, si possible, les secteurs d'activité, emplacements géographiques ou le type d'actifs financés.
Indiquer les émissions financées provenant du portefeuille des investissements disponibles.
Distinguer le type de financement (investissement, prêt, etc.).
Veuillez noter que si l'entreprise étudiée n'a pas inclus cette catégorie dans son inventaire des émissions.
Dans ce cas, merci de préciser que cette information n'est pas disponible et la raison pour laquelle elle n'est pas disponible.

Je ne peux pas fournir d'informations spécifiques sur les émissions de gaz à effet de serre liées à la Catégorie 15 du GHG Protocol : émissions financées, car les documents fournis ne contiennent pas de données précises sur cette catégorie. Toutefois, il est mentionné que les émissions financées incluent des émissions de Scope 3, qui peuvent varier en fonction des secteurs d'activité et des types d'actifs financés. Les émissions financées sont calculées en utilisant des données spécifiques aux clients et des facteurs d'émission de substitution, conformément à la norme PCAF.

Si l'entreprise étudiée n'a pas inclus cette catégorie dans son inventaire des émissions, cela pourrait être dû à des limitations dans la disponibilité des données ou à des choix méthodologiques.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • - The remaining factor is client portfolio effects which contributed to increases of 1.9 MtCO2e/y for Scope 1 and 2 financed emissions and 20.0 MtCO2e/y for Scope 3 financed emissions - The remaining factor is client portfolio effects which contributed to increases of 1.9 MtCO2e/y for Scope 1 and 2 financed emissions and 20.0 MtCO2e/y for Scope 3 financed emissions
  • - Client-purchased offsets (certificates based on GHG reductions, permits, and/or avoidance schemes) are not taken into account in financed emissions calculations - Client-purchased offsets (certificates based on GHG reductions, permits, and/or avoidance schemes) are not taken into account in financed emissions calculations
  • - Scope 3 financed emissions estimates are expected to remain volatile due to factors outside of the bank's control such as: (i) the evolution of clients' EVIC, as well as (ii) the inclusion of total expected lifetime emissions from products sold which are significantly higher in sectors related to manufacturing activities, for example - Differences in Scope 3 financed emissions estimates can arise for the Oil and Gas and Coal Mining sectors between the bank's 'Financed Emissions: Scope 3 Category 15' versus the Net-Zero Target Framework. This can be explained by: (i) different coverage of Scope 3 categories; or (ii) different coverage of sub-sectors; or (iii) differences in Scope 3 emission factor estimates due to differing approaches in terms of methodology and/or dataset - Scope 3 financed emissions estimates are expected to remain volatile due to factors outside of the bank's control such as: (i) the evolution of clients' EVIC, as well as (ii) the inclusion of total expected lifetime emissions from products sold which are significantly higher in sectors related to manufacturing activities, for example - Differences in Scope 3 financed emissions estimates can arise for the Oil and Gas and Coal Mining sectors between the bank's 'Financed Emissions: Scope 3 Category 15' versus the Net-Zero Target Framework. This can be explained by: (i) different coverage of Scope 3 categories; or (ii) different coverage of sub-sectors; or (iii) differences in Scope 3 emission factor estimates due to differing approaches in terms of methodology and/or dataset
  • Oil and Gas (Upstream): Scope 3 financed emissions stood at 19.2 MtCO2/y as of year-end 2024, 4% higher year-on-year but 18% below the 2021 baseline and below the NZ target pathway when linearly interpolating between 2021 and 2030. The temporary effects seen in the first year (year-end 2022) which led to a sharp decline in financed emissions are now being partially reversed as expected. Since target inception, the overall financed emissions reduced in line with the linear reduction pathway implied by the 2030 net zero target. Total loan commitments marginally increased year-on-year from € 9.4 billion to € 9.6 billion. The year-on-year increase in financed emissions can be explained by three factors: (i) client emission factors (tCO2/€ m) which led to an increase of 1.9 MtCO2/y; (ii) active management of the portfolio which led to a decrease of 0.8 MtCO2/y; and (iii) loan exposure FX translation effects from 2022 to 2023 predominantly driven by U.S. dollar depreciating versus the euro Oil and Gas (Upstream): Scope 3 financed emissions stood at 19.2 MtCO2/y as of year-end 2024, 4% higher year-on-year but 18% below the 2021 baseline and below the NZ target pathway when linearly interpolating between 2021 and 2030. The temporary effects seen in the first year (year-end 2022) which led to a sharp decline in financed emissions are now being partially reversed as expected. Since target inception, the overall financed emissions reduced in line with the linear reduction pathway implied by the 2030 net zero target. Total loan commitments marginally increased year-on-year from € 9.4 billion to € 9.6 billion. The year-on-year increase in financed emissions can be explained by three factors: (i) client emission factors (tCO2/€ m) which led to an increase of 1.9 MtCO2/y; (ii) active management of the portfolio which led to a decrease of 0.8 MtCO2/y; and (iii) loan exposure FX translation effects from 2022 to 2023 predominantly driven by U.S. dollar depreciating versus the euro
  • ### ESRS E1-6 The financed emissions calculations follow the Partnership for Carbon Accounting Financials ("PCAF") Standard as detailed in the Methodological Notes in this section and are in line with the recommendations of the Task Force on Climate- related Financial Disclosures (see their Guidance on Metrics, Targets, and Transition Plans). Financed emissions calculations are based on disclosed Scope 1, 2, and 3 emissions of Deutsche Bank's clients. Such emission data is sourced from third-party providers, and if client-level data is not available, proxy data is used. This data is mapped to the bank's loan commitments and clients' EVIC to calculate financed emissions at the client and portfolio levels. For selected mortgage and commercial real estate portfolios, emissions are estimated using proxies which are based on Energy Performance Certificate ratings and internal methodologies. ### ESRS E1-6 The financed emissions calculations follow the Partnership for Carbon Accounting Financials ("PCAF") Standard as detailed in the Methodological Notes in this section and are in line with the recommendations of the Task Force on Climate- related Financial Disclosures (see their Guidance on Metrics, Targets, and Transition Plans). Financed emissions calculations are based on disclosed Scope 1, 2, and 3 emissions of Deutsche Bank's clients. Such emission data is sourced from third-party providers, and if client-level data is not available, proxy data is used. This data is mapped to the bank's loan commitments and clients' EVIC to calculate financed emissions at the client and portfolio levels. For selected mortgage and commercial real estate portfolios, emissions are estimated using proxies which are based on Energy Performance Certificate ratings and internal methodologies.
  • ## Environmental information Climate change - The financed emissions figures rely on client-specific data as well as proxy emissions factors. Scope 1 and 2 client- specific emissions data is sourced from MSCI and is always reported data from the client. Scope 3 client-specific emissions data is sourced from MSCI and can be either reported or estimated using MSCI's proprietary logic. Scope 1 and 2 proxy emission factors are sourced from PCAF and use the 2019 Exiobase dataset (Exiobase v3.7, base year 2015) version as recommended by PCAF given these proxies were used in the baseline reference year. Scope 3 proxy emission factors are internally built sector-country averages based on client-specific emissions data (reported and estimated) from MSCI - Enterprise Value including cash (EVIC) is used as the denominator of the PCAF attribution factor and sourced from MSCI ## Environmental information Climate change - The financed emissions figures rely on client-specific data as well as proxy emissions factors. Scope 1 and 2 client- specific emissions data is sourced from MSCI and is always reported data from the client. Scope 3 client-specific emissions data is sourced from MSCI and can be either reported or estimated using MSCI's proprietary logic. Scope 1 and 2 proxy emission factors are sourced from PCAF and use the 2019 Exiobase dataset (Exiobase v3.7, base year 2015) version as recommended by PCAF given these proxies were used in the baseline reference year. Scope 3 proxy emission factors are internally built sector-country averages based on client-specific emissions data (reported and estimated) from MSCI - Enterprise Value including cash (EVIC) is used as the denominator of the PCAF attribution factor and sourced from MSCI
  • - The Oil and Gas (Upstream) sector follows a Scope 3 End Use financed emission approach which is expressed as MtCO2/y and covers upstream activities only. Oil and gas production values are converted into emissions by using combustion constants from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Per the PCAF approach, the denominator of the Attribution Factor is EVIC or total assets. The bank expects the Oil and Gas Scope 3 End Use financed emissions to remain volatile due to factors outside of its control such as the evolution of clients' EVIC or total assets which are key inputs into the financed emissions calculation. In order to reduce volatility, the latest (year-end 2024) loan exposure data is converted to EUR-equivalent loan exposures using 2023 FX rates such that is consistent with the bank's latest Scope 3 emission factors. The decarbonization pathway is calibrated from the IEA NZE (2021) datasets 272 - The Oil and Gas (Upstream) sector follows a Scope 3 End Use financed emission approach which is expressed as MtCO2/y and covers upstream activities only. Oil and gas production values are converted into emissions by using combustion constants from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Per the PCAF approach, the denominator of the Attribution Factor is EVIC or total assets. The bank expects the Oil and Gas Scope 3 End Use financed emissions to remain volatile due to factors outside of its control such as the evolution of clients' EVIC or total assets which are key inputs into the financed emissions calculation. In order to reduce volatility, the latest (year-end 2024) loan exposure data is converted to EUR-equivalent loan exposures using 2023 FX rates such that is consistent with the bank's latest Scope 3 emission factors. The decarbonization pathway is calibrated from the IEA NZE (2021) datasets 272
  • - For Scope 1 and 2 financed emissions, due to the general rise of Enterprise Values (including Cash) (EVICs) from 2022 to 2023, client-specific emission factors decreased which led to a financed emissions reduction of 1.4 MtCO2e/y. For Scope 3 financed emissions, the same effect also led to a financed emissions reduction of 2.1 MtCO2e/y - Data quality improved year-on-year which led to a financed emissions decrease of 0.1 MtCO2e/y for Scope 1 and 2 and an increase of 8.7 MtCO2e/y for Scope 3 financed emissions - Year-on-year FX translation effects of euro-equivalent loan exposures led to a financed emissions increase of 0.9 MtCO2e/y and 9.2 MtCO2e/y for Scope 1 and 2 versus Scope 3 financed emissions, respectively. This is due to the U.S. dollar strengthening against the euro between year-end 2023 and year-end 2024 - For Scope 1 and 2 financed emissions, due to the general rise of Enterprise Values (including Cash) (EVICs) from 2022 to 2023, client-specific emission factors decreased which led to a financed emissions reduction of 1.4 MtCO2e/y.
