Je ne sais pas. Les documents fournis ne contiennent pas d'informations spécifiques sur la manière dont le plan de transition pour l'atténuation des risques climatiques est intégré dans la stratégie commerciale globale et la planification financière de Deutsche Bank.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • The orderly and progressive execution of the bank's sustainability strategy, including net-zero targets, growth in sustainable and transition financing, greater integration of nature into the bank's risk frameworks, as well as client, product, and regional strategies, is key to mitigate credit and reputational risk impacts over the long term. More information on the scenario analysis, its scope, time horizon, and the scenarios used is reported in the "Impact, risk and opportunity management - Process to identify and assess material climate-related risks: the scenarios" sub-chapter.
  • ### Transition plan for climate change mitigation Deutsche Bank's initial transition plan for climate change mitigation is described in detail in the "Transition Plan" sub- chapter as part of the "Climate Change" chapter of this Sustainability Statement.
  • ## Environmental information Climate change ### Climate and environmental risk management framework Climate and environmental risk management framework Risk identification and materiality assessment Integration into risk type frameworks and processes Scenario analysis and stress testing Risk metrics, targets and integration in appetite Materiality assessment Group Risk identification process Integration into frameworks and processes for the management of: Scenario analysis across climate-transition, climate- physical and nature risk drivers Financed emissions and exposure to carbon-related assets Transition, Physical and nature risks assessments - Credit risk Integration of climate transition and physical risks in internal stress testing framework Net zero targets and pathways - Market risk - Liquidity risk - Non-financial risk
  • ### Implementation of the bank's overall climate and environmental risk management framework The management of climate and environmental risks is embedded within the bank's overall risk management framework. The ongoing development of the climate and environmental risk framework is integrated into one of the Group's Key Deliverables (Change-The-Bank (CTB) priorities) overseen by the Sustainability Strategy Steering Committee. The framework has four key elements: (i) risk identification and materiality assessment; (ii) integration into risk type frameworks and processes; (iii) scenario analysis and stress testing; and (iv) integration into risk appetite via utilization of a range of risk metrics and targets. 266
  • Climate-related risks are managed within the existing market risk framework and treated as a price trigger, in the same way as market events such as central bank announcements or earnings announcements. Market risk monitors and reports internally "highly carbon intensive" exposures (as per Deutsche Bank's climate risk taxonomy) and financed emissions in its traded credit portfolio. The report provides granular views required for the management of exposures, and the top exposures are reported to the Enterprise Risk Committee on a quarterly basis. Furthermore, a weekly climate stress scenario to assess transition and physical risks in the trading book portfolio is embedded into the bank's market risk appetite framework.
  • ### Climate Physical Risks :selected: :selected: Transition risks can arise from the transition towards a low-carbon economy. Examples include: Physical risks can arise from more frequent and severe extreme weather events ("acute") and gradual changes in the environment ("chronic") due to a changing climate. - Strategic risks such as potential loss of revenues from the withdrawal of financing to high-emitting counterparties - Credit risks from defaults or deterioration of credit ratings of clients unable to adapt their business models - Credit risks from defaults of clients directly/indirectly impacted by these events and depreciation of collateral values - Credit risks (collateral values) from depreciation of asset values driven by energy efficiency issues/CO2 pricing - Market risks from short-term market volatility as a result of physical risk events or fundamental re-pricing of asset values in regions/sectors impacted by chronic negative events
  • Credit risk shocks are modelled as credit rating migrations leading to shifts in the probability of default of clients affected, which in turn increase their expected credit losses. For instance, extreme weather-related events can affect a borrower's own operations and value chain, and can result in loss of revenue, increased capital needs, insurance costs, and liabilities. For transition risks, increases in credit losses are expected for carbon-intensive corporates under scenarios of decarbonization of the economy where their product is of decreasing relevance and they have failed to adapt their business model. The strategic and reputational risk assessment captures the impact on revenues and costs arising from climate and environmental risks. The analysis on strategic risks relates to the exposure identified as vulnerable in the climate transition, climate physical and nature risk scenarios. The main sources of strategic risks identified for the bank are three-fold:
  • - Potential reputational and litigation risks should the bank be seen as a negative outlier relative to peers in terms of the execution of its sustainability commitments - Potential for operational risk impacts from physical risk events In the long term, cumulative impacts are higher across all risk types and scenarios. Across the higher transition scenarios, a broader range of clients are impacted and the potential deterioration in portfolio credit quality becomes more pronounced. Revenue attrition (strategic risk) and potential reputational impacts are also higher. Physical risks drive losses in the low transition risk scenarios, materially impacting operational, credit, strategic and reputational risks. The disorderly transition scenario yields the highest losses across all scenarios as clients face punitive carbon taxes and related policies with limited time to adapt.
  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla muestra la exposición de préstamos corporativos por tipo de pérdida de naturaleza al 31 de diciembre de 2023, con datos en € bn y porcentajes del portafolio. Los tipos de pérdida de naturaleza incluyen: "Water depletion" (17.3 € bn, 17.1% del portafolio, 2.2 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 12.7% de estos), "Terrestrial biodiversity and habitat loss" (11.6 € bn, 11.5% del portafolio, 4.6 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 39.2% de estos), "Ecosystem degradation from waste and pollution" (9.2 € bn, 9.1% del portafolio, 5.5 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 60.2% de estos), y "Marine ecosystem degradation" (6.4 € bn, 6.3% del portafolio, 4.7 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 74.0% de estos). La exposición total de préstamos corporativos por industria es de 101.2 € bn, representando el 100% del portafolio, sin datos específicos identificados a nivel de cliente.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta información sobre la **exposición crediticia** y las **emisiones financiadas** del libro de préstamos corporativos y bienes raíces residenciales al 31 de diciembre de 2024. 1. **Exposición total a préstamos corporativos por industria**: - Total: **€117.7 mil millones** en préstamos pendientes (100% del total) y **€290.3 mil millones** en compromisos totales. - Principales sectores: - **Manufactura e Ingeniería**: €9.8 mil millones pendientes (8.3%), emisiones financiadas Scope 1&2: 1.0 MtCO2e/año. - **Automotriz**: €7.0 mil millones pendientes (5.9%), Scope 1&2: 0.6 MtCO2e/año. - **Petróleo y Gas**: €5.6 mil millones pendientes (4.8%), Scope 1&2: 9.9 MtCO2e/año. - **Servicios Públicos**: €5.2 mil millones pendientes (4.4%), Scope 1&2: 8.1 MtCO2e/año. 2. **Préstamos asegurados por bienes raíces**: - Total: **€240.6 mil millones** (100%), de los cuales **€171.5 mil millones** (71.3%) están asegurados por bienes raíces residenciales y **€69.1 mil millones** (28.7%) por bienes raíces no residenciales. - En la UE: **€166.4 mil millones** (97%), destacando Alemania con **€153.2 mil millones** (92.1%). 3. **Calidad de datos PCAF**: Las puntuaciones de calidad de datos (5 = más baja) varían entre sectores, con valores entre 2.2 y 4.8. 4. **Objetivos net-zero**: Se incluyen sectores como **Petróleo y Gas (Upstream)**, **Generación de Energía**, **Automotriz (vehículos ligeros)**, **Acero**, **Minería de Carbón**, y **Cemento**, con compromisos totales y emisiones financiadas detalladas. 5. **Exclusiones**: Los préstamos securitizados de aviación están excluidos debido a la imposibilidad de aplicar el estándar PCAF.

  • assets of the bank’s clients. The mitigation of these negative impacts and risks is an integral part of the bank’s strategy and business model. The main components of this strategy are the following: – Its transition plan; – Its sectoral decarbonization targets and pathways for climate change mitigation (both addressed in separate sections of this chapter); and – The monitoring and management of risk concentrations (e.g., through Early Warning Indicators) and the incorporation of climate and environmental risks into the bank’s Risk Management frameworks for both climate change mitigation and adaptation Resilience of the bank ESRS E1 -1 related to ESRS 2 SBM -3 The bank uses scenario analysis and stress testing to assess the materiality of climate and environmental risks across the short -, medium - and long term, and test the business resilience against them. 261 Deutsche Bank Environmental information Annual Report 2024 Climate change assets of the bank’s clients.   • Management, and Con sumer Finance (with nature scenarios only applied to portfolios identified as high risk for nature). With respect to climate risk, the drivers considered were transition risks (e.g. arising from policy, technology, and behavio ral changes), and physical risks arising from acute (i.e. extreme weather events) and chronic (i.e. gradual changes in the climate/ environment) drivers. With respect to nature risk (other environmental risks), the bank considered drivers of nature loss arising from (i) terrestrial biodiversity and habitat loss, (ii) water depletion, (iii) ecosystem degradation from waste and pollution and (iv) marine ecosystem degradation (from marine ecosystem use). The analysis of how these factors drive each relevant risk type - namely credit, strategic and reputational, market, liquidity, and operational risks - was tailored to their specificities, as described in the following paragraphs. Management, and Con sumer Finance (with nature scenarios only applied to portfolios identified as high risk for nature). With respect to climate risk, the drivers considered were transition risks (e.g. arising from policy, technology, and behavio ral changes), and physical risks arising from acute (i.e. extreme weather events) and chronic (i.e. gradual changes in the climate/ environment) drivers. With respect to nature risk (other environmental risks), the bank considered drivers of nature loss arising from (i) terrestrial biodiversity and habitat loss, (ii) water depletion, (iii) ecosystem degradation from waste and pollution and (iv) marine ecosystem degradation (from marine ecosystem use). The analysis of how these factors drive each relevant risk type - namely credit, strategic and reputational, market, liquidity, and operational risks - was tailored to their specificities, as described in the following paragraphs.
  • adaptation through its double materiality assessment process described in the “Double materiality assessment” chapter of this Sustainability Statement. These negative impacts from the financing activities of the bank and its portfolio of clients (downstream value chain), should they materialize, would likely only manifest themselves in the longer -term (more than 5 years). For climate change mitigation, potential material negative impacts to the environment and society were identified in relation to: – Financing or investing in clients or assets in high carbon -emitting industries without credible transition plans, which could in turn lead to increases in GHG emissions – Restricting lending to clients in high carbon -emitting industries which, as a consequence, could reduce the availability of financial resources needed by these companies for the implementation of their transition strategies adaptation through its double materiality assessment process described in the “Double materiality assessment” chapter of this Sustainability Statement.   • price projections and emissions pathways from the Carbon Risk Real Estate Monitor for commercial real estate loans; – For physical risk: Collateral devaluations informed by S&P’s financial impacts for both residential mortgages and commercial real estate loans The stress testing methodology for market risk estimates net stressed P&L losses in the bonds and equity trading book, tested in the short - and medium - term in a disorderly transition scenario. The stress testing methodology for strategic risks covers all clients in scope of the net zero targets and models foregone revenues resulting from a) the phase -out of Oil & Gas and Coal clients in line with the net zero pathways as well as b) the phase out of clients that are not able/willing to transition across the other net zero sectors (i.e., those identified as having no net zero targets). Liquidity stress is tested, for both transition and physical risks: price projections and emissions pathways from the Carbon Risk Real Estate Monitor for commercial real estate loans; – For physical risk: Collateral devaluations informed by S&P’s financial impacts for both residential mortgages and commercial real estate loans The stress testing methodology for market risk estimates net stressed P&L losses in the bonds and equity trading book, tested in the short - and medium - term in a disorderly transition scenario. The stress testing methodology for strategic risks covers all clients in scope of the net zero targets and models foregone revenues resulting from a) the phase -out of Oil & Gas and Coal clients in line with the net zero pathways as well as b) the phase out of clients that are not able/willing to transition across the other net zero sectors (i.e., those identified as having no net zero targets). Liquidity stress is tested, for both transition and physical risks:
  • collateral valua tion. Climate and environmental risks are incorporated into the credit approval process for corporate clients via enhanced due diligence requirements. New loan requests above selected tenor and rating -based thresholds to corporate clients in carbon -intensive sec tors as well as those in sectors vulnerable to climate -physical and nature (or “other environmental”) risks require a dedicated risk assessment from the Front Office and review by Credit Risk Management. As part of the internal credit rating process, climate and other environmental risks must be assessed and, where deemed material, documented. For corporate clients, this assessment is supported by: – Transition risk scorecards which use externally sourced data to assess the clients’ historical performance in terms of their GHG emissions, the scope and governance of climate commitments of clients versus their peers collateral valua tion. Climate and environmental risks are incorporated into the credit approval process for corporate clients via enhanced due diligence requirements. New loan requests above selected tenor and rating -based thresholds to corporate clients in carbon -intensive sec tors as well as those in sectors vulnerable to climate -physical and nature (or “other environmental”) risks require a dedicated risk assessment from the Front Office and review by Credit Risk Management. As part of the internal credit rating process, climate and other environmental risks must be assessed and, where deemed material, documented. For corporate clients, this assessment is supported by: – Transition risk scorecards which use externally sourced data to assess the clients’ historical performance in terms of their GHG emissions, the scope and governance of climate commitments of clients versus their peers
  • control environment based on the perf ormance of the individual divisions, including critical and overdue findings, but also cultural issues such as self -identified risk acceptance. Overall, the objective underlines the importance for Deutsche Bank to combat economic crime and prevent money la undering activities, as well as staying compliant with regulatory requirements and to foster a healthy corporate culture. 199 Deutsche Bank General information Annual Report 2024 Governance The LTI objectives will be assessed at the end of the assessment period in 2026 against the following targets and limits: Level of approval The Supervisory Board is responsible for the decisions on the design of the compensation system as well as for setting the individual compensation amounts and procedures for awarding the compensation.   • and employee acquisition and maintenance. Such a culture concerns professional integrity, engagement with workforce about impacts, and channels to r aise concerns including whistleblower procedures. Therefore, the bank has robust Speak - Up and Raise a Concern procedures and channels to support the core element of trust. Speak Up and Raise a Concern impact behaviors and drive the bank’s aspirational cult ure, with positive impacts such as increased ethical conduct and alignment to the aspirational culture of the bank, which are considered as very likely to materialize in the short term. A la ck of trust, Speak -Up and Raise a Concern procedures and channels on the other hand have been assessed as very likely to negatively impact the society by damaging confidence in the financial system and imposing costs to society on a short - term basis. Risks caused by unethical behavior and missing aspirational culture can include the loss of trust in the and employee acquisition and maintenance.   • continues to further devel op them. Next to the Chief Sustainability Office, an additional enabler are ESG expert teams in the bank’s business divisions and infrastructure functions that foster the implementation of Deutsche Bank’s sustainability strategy and allow for a swift respo nse to emerging business opportunities and potential risks. In the years ahead, Deutsche Bank aims to broaden the scope of decarbonization, i.e., progressing from financed emissions to financed and facilitated emissions and capturing opportunities in the bank’s private clients’ assets under management. Moreover, De utsche Bank focuses on incorporating nature and biodiversity as well as just transition, which means to address the challenges of transitioning for developing economies. To operationalize its commitments, the bank is further developing the Initial Transition Plan as tools, methodologies and continues to further devel op them.   • valuation, monitoring , and review over the life of the loan. Deutsche Bank’s underwriting standards require real estate collateral to be appropriately insured against relevant risks including applicable natural hazards. In some countries, supplemental insurance against natural hazards is provided by the government. The European residential real estate portfolio amounted to € 166.4 billion at year -end 2024. Residential mortgages for private clients in Germany represent approximately 92% of this amount and around 1.2 million German private residences financed by loans secured by immovable properties are insured appropriately against relevant risks including applicable natural hazards. The insurance cover by real estate owners is monitored and complemented or substituted by De utsche Bank´s own insurance. In addition, new valuations and re -valuations require the identification of material environmental physical and transition valuation, monitoring , and review over the life of the loan. Residential mortgages for private clients in Germany represent approximately 92% of this amount and around 1.2 million German private residences financed by loans secured by immovable properties are insured appropriately against relevant risks including applicable natural hazards. The insurance cover by real estate owners is monitored and complemented or substituted by De utsche Bank´s own insurance. In addition, new valuations and re -valuations require the identification of material environmental physical and transition
S1-121

Quelle est la répartition par sexe, exprimée en pourcentage, au niveau de l'encadrement supérieur de l'entreprise ?

Pour répondre à cette question, merci de fournir :
Le pourcentage de femmes occupant des postes d'encadrement supérieur.
Le pourcentage d'hommes occupant des postes d'encadrement supérieur.


Si possible, inclure des données comparatives sur l'évolution de cette répartition au fil des années.

La répartition par sexe au niveau de l'encadrement supérieur de l'entreprise est la suivante :

Pourcentage de femmes occupant des postes d'encadrement supérieur :

  • En 2024, le pourcentage de femmes occupant des postes d'encadrement supérieur (Managing Directors, Directors, Vice Presidents) était de 33.0%.
  • En 2023, ce pourcentage était de 32.3%.

Pourcentage d'hommes occupant des postes d'encadrement supérieur :

  • En 2024, étant donné que le pourcentage de femmes était de 33.0%, le pourcentage d'hommes occupant ces postes était de 67.0%.
  • En 2023, avec un pourcentage de femmes de 32.3%, le pourcentage d'hommes était de 67.7%.

Évolution :

  • Il y a eu une légère augmentation de la représentation des femmes dans les postes d'encadrement supérieur, passant de 32.3% en 2023 à 33.0% en 2024. Par conséquent, la représentation des hommes a légèrement diminué de 67.7% en 2023 à 67.0% en 2024.

Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • ### Summary of the Table The table outlines goals and results for the representation of women across various levels within the organization, with data for Dec 31, 2024 (Goal and Result) and Dec 31, 2023 (Result). - **Level**: - **Management Board level -1 (headcount, in %)**: The goal for Dec 31, 2024 is 30.0%, with a result of 28.9%. The result for Dec 31, 2023 was 20.0%. - **Management Board level -2 (headcount, in %)**: The goal for Dec 31, 2024 is 30.0%, with a result of 28.3%. The result for Dec 31, 2023 was 27.6%. - **Senior Corporate Titles**: - **Managing Directors, Directors, Vice Presidents (headcount, in %)**: The goal for Dec 31, 2024 is 35.0%, with a result of 33.0%. The result for Dec 31, 2023 was 32.3%. The goals for Dec 31, 2024 align with the German Gender Quota Law (FüPoG II) and reflect December 2025 targets. and

Permanent employees account for 89,442, distributed as 40,113 Female, 49,323 Male, 4 Other, and 2 Not reported. Temporary employees total 311, with 180 Female and 131 Male; no data is reported for Other or Not reported categories. Non-guaranteed hours employees are not reported across all categories. The "Number of full-time employees" totals 81,842, with 33,443 Female, 48,393 Male, 4 Other, and 2 Not reported.   • ### Gender diversity table summary: The table titled "Female employees by Corporate Title (headcount, in %)" presents data for Dec 31, 2024, and Dec 31, 2023. It includes the following corporate titles: Managing Directors, Directors, Vice Presidents, Assistant Vice Presidents and Associates, Non-Officers, and Total female employees. For Managing Directors, the percentage of female employees was 22.8% in 2024 and 22.3% in 2023. Among Directors, the percentages were 28.8% in 2024 and 28.0% in 2023. Female Vice Presidents accounted for 35.6% in 2024 and 34.8% in 2023. Assistant Vice Presidents and Associates had 42.3% in 2024 and 41.9% in 2023. Non-Officers had the highest representation, with 59.6% in 2024 and 59.0% in 2023. The total percentage of female employees across all corporate titles was 46.5% in 2024 and 46.3% in 2023. Note that numbers may not add up due to rounding, and corporate titles for Postbank (including subsidiaries) are technically derived. and

  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta información sobre la **exposición crediticia** y las **emisiones financiadas** del libro de préstamos corporativos y bienes raíces residenciales al 31 de diciembre de 2024. 1. **Exposición total a préstamos corporativos por industria**: - Total: **€117.7 mil millones** en préstamos pendientes (100% del total) y **€290.3 mil millones** en compromisos totales. - Principales sectores: - **Manufactura e Ingeniería**: €9.8 mil millones pendientes (8.3%), emisiones financiadas Scope 1&2: 1.0 MtCO2e/año. - **Automotriz**: €7.0 mil millones pendientes (5.9%), Scope 1&2: 0.6 MtCO2e/año. - **Petróleo y Gas**: €5.6 mil millones pendientes (4.8%), Scope 1&2: 9.9 MtCO2e/año. - **Servicios Públicos**: €5.2 mil millones pendientes (4.4%), Scope 1&2: 8.1 MtCO2e/año. 2. **Préstamos asegurados por bienes raíces**: - Total: **€240.6 mil millones** (100%), de los cuales **€171.5 mil millones** (71.3%) están asegurados por bienes raíces residenciales y **€69.1 mil millones** (28.7%) por bienes raíces no residenciales. - En la UE: **€166.4 mil millones** (97%), destacando Alemania con **€153.2 mil millones** (92.1%). 3. **Calidad de datos PCAF**: Las puntuaciones de calidad de datos (5 = más baja) varían entre sectores, con valores entre 2.2 y 4.8. 4. **Objetivos net-zero**: Se incluyen sectores como **Petróleo y Gas (Upstream)**, **Generación de Energía**, **Automotriz (vehículos ligeros)**, **Acero**, **Minería de Carbón**, y **Cemento**, con compromisos totales y emisiones financiadas detalladas. 5. **Exclusiones**: Los préstamos securitizados de aviación están excluidos debido a la imposibilidad de aplicar el estándar PCAF. and

  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta datos en FTE al 31 de diciembre de 2023, desglosados por regiones: Alemania, Europa excluyendo Alemania, América, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África, y el Total. 1. **Número de empleados**: Alemania tiene 36,195, Europa excluyendo Alemania 18,103, América 8,232, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,601, con un total de 90,130. 2. **Número de empleados permanentes**: Alemania cuenta con 35,822, Europa excluyendo Alemania 18,066, América 8,232, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,584, sumando un total de 89,703. 3. **Número de empleados temporales**: Alemania tiene 373, Europa excluyendo Alemania 37, América no tiene empleados temporales, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 17, con un total de 427. 4. **Número de empleados con horas no garantizadas**: No hay empleados en esta categoría en ninguna región. 5. **Número de empleados (repetido)**: Alemania tiene 36,195, Europa excluyendo Alemania 18,103, América 8,232, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,601, con un total de 90,130. 6. **Número de empleados a tiempo completo**: Alemania cuenta con 28,686, Europa excluyendo Alemania 17,386, América 8,212, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,585, sumando un total de 81,869. 7. **Número de empleados a tiempo parcial**: Alemania tiene 7,509, Europa excluyendo Alemania 717, América 20, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 16, con un total de 8,261. ### END TABLE and

Je ne peux pas fournir de réponse précise concernant la répartition par sexe au niveau de l'encadrement supérieur de l'entreprise, car les documents fournis ne contiennent pas d'informations spécifiques sur le pourcentage d'hommes occupant des postes d'encadrement supérieur. Cependant, voici les informations disponibles sur les femmes occupant des postes d'encadrement supérieur :

  • Au 31 décembre 2024, les femmes représentaient 22,8% des Managing Directors, 28,8% des Directors, et 35,6% des Vice Presidents (Contexte Num-2).
  • En 2023, ces pourcentages étaient respectivement de 22,3% pour les Managing Directors, 28,0% pour les Directors, et 34,8% pour les Vice Presidents (Contexte Num-2).

Les documents fournis n'indiquent pas explicitement le pourcentage d'hommes occupant ces postes, mais on peut en déduire que c'est le complément au pourcentage des femmes.

  • ### Summary of the Table The table outlines goals and results for the representation of women across various levels within the organization, with data for Dec 31, 2024 (Goal and Result) and Dec 31, 2023 (Result). - **Level**: - **Management Board level -1 (headcount, in %)**: The goal for Dec 31, 2024 is 30.0%, with a result of 28.9%. The result for Dec 31, 2023 was 20.0%. - **Management Board level -2 (headcount, in %)**: The goal for Dec 31, 2024 is 30.0%, with a result of 28.3%. The result for Dec 31, 2023 was 27.6%. - **Senior Corporate Titles**: - **Managing Directors, Directors, Vice Presidents (headcount, in %)**: The goal for Dec 31, 2024 is 35.0%, with a result of 33.0%. The result for Dec 31, 2023 was 32.3%. The goals for Dec 31, 2024 align with the German Gender Quota Law (FüPoG II) and reflect December 2025 targets.
  • ### Employees by contract type, broken down by gender (Dec 31, 2024) The table provides data in FTE on employees categorized by gender (Female, Male, Other, Not reported) and contract type. The "Number of employees" totals 89,753, with 40,293 Female, 49,454 Male, 4 Other, and 2 Not reported. Permanent employees account for 89,442, distributed as 40,113 Female, 49,323 Male, 4 Other, and 2 Not reported. Temporary employees total 311, with 180 Female and 131 Male; no data is reported for Other or Not reported categories. Non-guaranteed hours employees are not reported across all categories. The "Number of full-time employees" totals 81,842, with 33,443 Female, 48,393 Male, 4 Other, and 2 Not reported. Part-time employees total 7,911, distributed as 6,850 Female and 1,061 Male; no data is reported for Other or Not reported categories.
  • ### Gender diversity table summary: The table titled "Female employees by Corporate Title (headcount, in %)" presents data for Dec 31, 2024, and Dec 31, 2023. It includes the following corporate titles: Managing Directors, Directors, Vice Presidents, Assistant Vice Presidents and Associates, Non-Officers, and Total female employees. For Managing Directors, the percentage of female employees was 22.8% in 2024 and 22.3% in 2023. Among Directors, the percentages were 28.8% in 2024 and 28.0% in 2023. Female Vice Presidents accounted for 35.6% in 2024 and 34.8% in 2023. Assistant Vice Presidents and Associates had 42.3% in 2024 and 41.9% in 2023. Non-Officers had the highest representation, with 59.6% in 2024 and 59.0% in 2023. The total percentage of female employees across all corporate titles was 46.5% in 2024 and 46.3% in 2023. Note that numbers may not add up due to rounding, and corporate titles for Postbank (including subsidiaries) are technically derived.

The column labels are "Share of employees (headcount)" for the years "Dec 31, 2024" and "Dec 31, 2023." The row labels are "Gender, in %," "Female," "Male," "Other1," "Not reported," and "Total Employees." For "Female," the share was 4.1% in 2024 and 4.0% in 2023. For "Male," the share remained constant at 2.4% for both years. "Other1" and "Not reported" categories had no data available ("-") for either year. The "Total Employees" percentage was 3.2% in 2024 and 3.1% in 2023.

In 2023, the share for "Female" was 41.8%, "Male" was 58.2%, "Other2" was 0%, and "Not reported" was 0%.

Los encabezados incluyen: "Total environmentally sustainable assets (in € m)", "Turnover KPIs", "CapEx KPIs", "% coverage (over total assets)", "% of assets excluded from the numerator of the GAR (Article 7(2) and (3) and Section 1.1.2. of Annex V)", y "% of assets excluded from the denominator of the GAR (Article 7(1) and Section 1.2.4 of Annex V)". La répartition par sexe au niveau de l'encadrement supérieur de l'entreprise est la suivante :

Pourcentage de femmes occupant des postes d'encadrement supérieur :

  • En 2024, le pourcentage de femmes occupant des postes d'encadrement supérieur (Managing Directors, Directors, Vice Presidents) était de 33.0%.
  • En 2023, ce pourcentage était de 32.3%.

Pourcentage d'hommes occupant des postes d'encadrement supérieur :

  • En 2024, étant donné que le pourcentage de femmes était de 33.0%, le pourcentage d'hommes occupant ces postes était de 67.0%.
  • En 2023, avec un pourcentage de femmes de 32.3%, le pourcentage d'hommes était de 67.7%.

Évolution :

  • Il y a eu une légère augmentation de la représentation des femmes dans les postes d'encadrement supérieur, passant de 32.3% en 2023 à 33.0% en 2024. Par conséquent, la représentation des hommes a légèrement diminué de 67.7% en 2023 à 67.0% en 2024.

  • Management Board membe rs. The unadjusted global Gender pay gap is defined as the difference of average hourly pay levels between female and male employees, expressed as percentage of the average hourly pay level of male employees. For 2024, the unadjusted global Gender pay gap was 38.8%. A regression analysis, that considers a number of objective factors such as seniority, business division and region, results in an adjusted Gender pay gap of 6.0%. Therefore, the underlying reason for the unadjusted global Gender pay gap is primarily linke d to the lower representation of women in senior and highly remunerated roles and in higher cost locations. To drive structural change and get more women into senior roles, Deutsche Bank continues to make progress on its 35 by 25 gender diversity goal and initiatives, as described in the “Diversity, equity and inclusion” sub -chapter of the “Own Management Board membe rs. The unadjusted global Gender pay gap is defined as the difference of average hourly pay levels between female and male employees, expressed as percentage of the average hourly pay level of male employees. For 2024, the unadjusted global Gender pay gap was 38.8%. A regression analysis, that considers a number of objective factors such as seniority, business division and region, results in an adjusted Gender pay gap of 6.0%. Therefore, the underlying reason for the unadjusted global Gender pay gap is primarily linke d to the lower representation of women in senior and highly remunerated roles and in higher cost locations. To drive structural change and get more women into senior roles, Deutsche Bank continues to make progress on its 35 by 25 gender diversity goal and initiatives, as described in the “Diversity, equity and inclusion” sub -chapter of the “Own
  • 40%). This met the statutory requirement of 30% for publicly listed and codetermined German companies pursuant to gender quota legislation th at took effect in 2015. At year -end 2024, two out of ten or 20% of Management Board members were women (2023: one out of nine or 11%). The current German Gender Quota Law (Zweites Führungspositionen -Gesetz, FüPoG II) requires appointing at least one woman and one man to a Managem ent Board with more than three members. With Rebecca Short and, as of July 1, 2024, Laura Padovani on the Management Board the bank satisfied this requirement as of December 31, 2024. Legal requirements and results for the representation of women Dec 31, 2024 Dec 31, 2023 Requirement Result Result Level Supervisory Board (headcount, in %)1 30.0 35.0 40.0 Management Board (headcount)2 1 2 1 1 Reflects requirement of German Gender Quota Law (Erstes Führungspositionen -Gesetz, FüPoG I) 40%). This met the statutory requirement of 30% for publicly listed and codetermined German companies pursuant to gender quota legislation th at took effect in 2015. At year -end 2024, two out of ten or 20% of Management Board members were women (2023: one out of nine or 11%). The current German Gender Quota Law (Zweites Führungspositionen -Gesetz, FüPoG II) requires appointing at least one woman and one man to a Managem ent Board with more than three members. With Rebecca Short and, as of July 1, 2024, Laura Padovani on the Management Board the bank satisfied this requirement as of December 31, 2024. Legal requirements and results for the representation of women Dec 31, 2024 Dec 31, 2023 Requirement Result Result Level Supervisory Board (headcount, in %)1 30.0 35.0 40.0 Management Board (headcount)2 1 2 1 1 Reflects requirement of German Gender Quota Law (Erstes Führungspositionen -Gesetz, FüPoG I)
  • provide a pipeline of senior women to enable the bank to fulfill its statutory requirements. The bank aims to have women represent at least 35% of its Managing Director, Director, and Vice President population globally by 2025 (business divisions and infrastructure functions excluding Asset Management), known as ’35 by 25’. This goal also forms part of the key performance indicators on the Bal anced Scorecard assessing the Management Board and Group Management Committee. In 2021, the goal was publicly announced after consultation with the Supervisory Board which includes employee representatives among others. The goal was based on workforce data modeling and assumptions on the female share in hiring, promotion and turnover using 2020 data as a baseline. The 35 by 25 program is sponsored and actively supported by the Management Board and Group Management Committee. Since 2023, each of the bank's d ecision -making provide a pipeline of senior women to enable the bank to fulfill its statutory requirements. This goal also forms part of the key performance indicators on the Bal anced Scorecard assessing the Management Board and Group Management Committee. In 2021, the goal was publicly announced after consultation with the Supervisory Board which includes employee representatives among others. The goal was based on workforce data modeling and assumptions on the female share in hiring, promotion and turnover using 2020 data as a baseline. The 35 by 25 program is sponsored and actively supported by the Management Board and Group Management Committee. Since 2023, each of the bank's d ecision -making
  • Strategy ESRS 2 SBM -3 Deutsche Bank is committed to protecting its clients, society, and its own assets by taking an active role in the prevention, detection, and reporting of financial crime. Recognizing the material threats posed by financial crime, the Anti -Financial Crime f unction has defined a uniform strategy across financial crime risk prevention, detection, and reporting to ensure the highest level of protection for Deutsche Bank’s clients and stakeholders, while also supporting sustainable business practices. The Anti -Financial Crime strategy focuses on remediation, simplification, and consolidation of processes, and evolving the AFC Program across the areas of risk appetite, risk assessment, policy, training, assurance and reporting. The strategy serves to accelerate de cision -making around financial crime risks, enforce consistent standards, and foster Strategy ESRS 2 SBM -3 Deutsche Bank is committed to protecting its clients, society, and its own assets by taking an active role in the prevention, detection, and reporting of financial crime. Recognizing the material threats posed by financial crime, the Anti -Financial Crime f unction has defined a uniform strategy across financial crime risk prevention, detection, and reporting to ensure the highest level of protection for Deutsche Bank’s clients and stakeholders, while also supporting sustainable business practices. The Anti -Financial Crime strategy focuses on remediation, simplification, and consolidation of processes, and evolving the AFC Program across the areas of risk appetite, risk assessment, policy, training, assurance and reporting. The strategy serves to accelerate de cision -making around financial crime risks, enforce consistent standards, and foster
  • continues to further devel op them. Next to the Chief Sustainability Office, an additional enabler are ESG expert teams in the bank’s business divisions and infrastructure functions that foster the implementation of Deutsche Bank’s sustainability strategy and allow for a swift respo nse to emerging business opportunities and potential risks. In the years ahead, Deutsche Bank aims to broaden the scope of decarbonization, i.e., progressing from financed emissions to financed and facilitated emissions and capturing opportunities in the bank’s private clients’ assets under management. Moreover, De utsche Bank focuses on incorporating nature and biodiversity as well as just transition, which means to address the challenges of transitioning for developing economies. To operationalize its commitments, the bank is further developing the Initial Transition Plan as tools, methodologies and continues to further devel op them.   • valuation, monitoring , and review over the life of the loan. Deutsche Bank’s underwriting standards require real estate collateral to be appropriately insured against relevant risks including applicable natural hazards. In some countries, supplemental insurance against natural hazards is provided by the government. The European residential real estate portfolio amounted to € 166.4 billion at year -end 2024. Residential mortgages for private clients in Germany represent approximately 92% of this amount and around 1.2 million German private residences financed by loans secured by immovable properties are insured appropriately against relevant risks including applicable natural hazards. The insurance cover by real estate owners is monitored and complemented or substituted by De utsche Bank´s own insurance. In addition, new valuations and re -valuations require the identification of material environmental physical and transition valuation, monitoring , and review over the life of the loan. Residential mortgages for private clients in Germany represent approximately 92% of this amount and around 1.2 million German private residences financed by loans secured by immovable properties are insured appropriately against relevant risks including applicable natural hazards. The insurance cover by real estate owners is monitored and complemented or substituted by De utsche Bank´s own insurance. In addition, new valuations and re -valuations require the identification of material environmental physical and transition
  • to 289e of the German Commercial Code (HGB). As the European Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) was not transposed into German law as of December 31, 2024, the bank applied the European Sustainability Reporting Standards (ESRS) as reporting framework as allowed by Section 315c (3) HGB in conjunction with Section 289d HGB and, on that basis, discloses governance, strategy, impact, risk and opportunity management, metrics and targets for material sustainability matters. In addition, the Sustainability Statement complies with the disclosure obligations under Article 8 (1) and (3) of the Taxonomy Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2020/852) and the respective specifications in Articles 4 and 10 (5) of the associated Disclosures de legated Act (Delegated Regulation (EU) 2021/2178). The Sustainability Statement was prepared on a consolidated basis and the scope of consolidation is the same as for the to 289e of the German Commercial Code (HGB). As the European Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) was not transposed into German law as of December 31, 2024, the bank applied the European Sustainability Reporting Standards (ESRS) as reporting framework as allowed by Section 315c (3) HGB in conjunction with Section 289d HGB and, on that basis, discloses governance, strategy, impact, risk and opportunity management, metrics and targets for material sustainability matters. In addition, the Sustainability Statement complies with the disclosure obligations under Article 8 (1) and (3) of the Taxonomy Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2020/852) and the respective specifications in Articles 4 and 10 (5) of the associated Disclosures de legated Act (Delegated Regulation (EU) 2021/2178). The Sustainability Statement was prepared on a consolidated basis and the scope of consolidation is the same as for the
S1-145

Renseignez le pourcentage total de salariés en situation de handicap.

Si possible, donnez des informations sur l'évolution de ce pourcentage au fil des années.

Le pourcentage total de salariés en situation de handicap était de 3.2% au 31 décembre 2024 et de 3.1% au 31 décembre 2023. Cela montre une légère augmentation de 0.1% du pourcentage de salariés en situation de handicap entre 2023 et 2024.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • ### Employees with disabilities by gender (summary) The table presents the percentage share of employees with disabilities by gender as of December 31, 2024, and December 31, 2023. The column labels are "Share of employees (headcount)" for the years "Dec 31, 2024" and "Dec 31, 2023." The row labels are "Gender, in %," "Female," "Male," "Other1," "Not reported," and "Total Employees." For "Female," the share was 4.1% in 2024 and 4.0% in 2023. For "Male," the share remained constant at 2.4% for both years. "Other1" and "Not reported" categories had no data available ("-") for either year. The "Total Employees" percentage was 3.2% in 2024 and 3.1% in 2023. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    0 1 2
    Gender, in % Share of employees (headcount)
    Dec 31, 2024 Dec 31, 20232
    Female 4.1 4.0
    Male 2.4 2.4
    Other1 - -
    Not reported - -
    Total Employees 3.2 3.1
  • The bank's ability to measure the number of employees with disabilities depends on voluntary self-disclosure and is limited by data protection laws, e.g., the European General Data Protection Regulation. Additionally, due to continuing social stigma, many individuals choose not to share this information, even in locations where it is permissible for the bank to ask. As at year-end 2024, the bank employed 3,057 people with disabilities, thereof 1,820 female people with disabilities, and 1,237 male people with disabilities. In Germany, the bank employed 2,511 people with disabilities as at year-end 2024 (6.2% of the bank's headcount). Disclosure is based on Germany social code IX. The bank's ability to measure the number of employees with disabilities depends on voluntary self-disclosure and is limited by data protection laws, e.g., the European General Data Protection Regulation. Additionally, due to continuing social stigma, many individuals choose not to share this information, even in locations where it is permissible for the bank to ask. As at year-end 2024, the bank employed 3,057 people with disabilities, thereof 1,820 female people with disabilities, and 1,237 male people with disabilities. In Germany, the bank employed 2,511 people with disabilities as at year-end 2024 (6.2% of the bank's headcount). Disclosure is based on Germany social code IX.

    Rest of EU 2.6 1.6 0.1 5.0
    thereof: Outside of EU 5.1 3.0 N/A N/A

Le pourcentage total de salariés en situation de handicap à Deutsche Bank était de 3.2% au 31 décembre 2024 et de 3.1% au 31 décembre 2023. Cela indique une légère augmentation de 0.1 point de pourcentage d'une année à l'autre.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • ### Employees with disabilities by gender (summary) The table presents the percentage share of employees with disabilities by gender as of December 31, 2024, and December 31, 2023. The column labels are "Share of employees (headcount)" for the years "Dec 31, 2024" and "Dec 31, 2023." The row labels are "Gender, in %," "Female," "Male," "Other1," "Not reported," and "Total Employees." For "Female," the share was 4.1% in 2024 and 4.0% in 2023. For "Male," the share remained constant at 2.4% for both years. "Other1" and "Not reported" categories had no data available ("-") for either year. The "Total Employees" percentage was 3.2% in 2024 and 3.1% in 2023.
  • The bank's ability to measure the number of employees with disabilities depends on voluntary self-disclosure and is limited by data protection laws, e.g., the European General Data Protection Regulation. Additionally, due to continuing social stigma, many individuals choose not to share this information, even in locations where it is permissible for the bank to ask. As at year-end 2024, the bank employed 3,057 people with disabilities, thereof 1,820 female people with disabilities, and 1,237 male people with disabilities. In Germany, the bank employed 2,511 people with disabilities as at year-end 2024 (6.2% of the bank's headcount). Disclosure is based on Germany social code IX.
  • ### Summary of the Table The table provides data on employees in FTE as of Dec 31, 2023, categorized by gender (Female, Male, Other2, Not reported) and employment type. 1. **Number of employees**: Female (40,180), Male (49,945), Other2 (3), Not reported (2), Total (90,130). 2. **Number of permanent employees**: Female (39,920), Male (49,778), Other2 (3), Not reported (2), Total (89,703). 3. **Number of temporary employees**: Female (260), Male (167), Other2 (-), Not reported (-), Total (427). 4. **Number of non-guaranteed hours employees**: Female (0), Male (0), Other2 (0), Not reported (0), Total (0). 5. **Number of full-time employees**: Female (33,031), Male (48,832), Other2 (3), Not reported (2), Total (81,869). 6. **Number of part-time employees**: Female (7,149), Male (1,113), Other2 (-), Not reported (-), Total (8,261).
  • ### Employees by contract type, broken down by gender (Dec 31, 2024) The table provides data in FTE on employees categorized by gender (Female, Male, Other, Not reported) and contract type. The "Number of employees" totals 89,753, with 40,293 Female, 49,454 Male, 4 Other, and 2 Not reported. Permanent employees account for 89,442, distributed as 40,113 Female, 49,323 Male, 4 Other, and 2 Not reported. Temporary employees total 311, with 180 Female and 131 Male; no data is reported for Other or Not reported categories. Non-guaranteed hours employees are not reported across all categories. The "Number of full-time employees" totals 81,842, with 33,443 Female, 48,393 Male, 4 Other, and 2 Not reported. Part-time employees total 7,911, distributed as 6,850 Female and 1,061 Male; no data is reported for Other or Not reported categories.
  • ### Completion rate for performance reviews by gender (2023-2024) The table presents the "Completion rate for performance reviews by gender" for the years 2024 and 2023. The "Gender, in %" column lists the categories: "Female," "Male," "Other1," and "Not reported." The "Share of employees (headcount)" column provides the completion rates for each gender category. - In 2024, the completion rates were: "Female" (88%), "Male" (92%), "Other1" (67%), and "Not reported" (100%). - In 2023, the completion rates were: "Female" (86%), "Male" (90%), "Other1" (75%), and "Not reported" (50%). - The "Total Employees" completion rate was 90% in 2024 and 88% in 2023. "Other1" refers to gender as specified by the employees themselves.
  • ### New employee hires by gender The table presents the "Share in %1" of new employee hires by gender for the years "2024" and "2023." The gender categories include "Female," "Male," "Other2," and "Not reported." In 2024, the share of "Female" hires was 47.7%, "Male" hires were 52.2%, "Other2" hires were 0%, and "Not reported" hires were 0.1%. In 2023, the share of "Female" hires was 44.1%, "Male" hires were 55.8%, "Other2" hires were 0%, and "Not reported" hires were 0%.
  • ### Entitled employees that took family related leave by gender in 2024 The table presents data on "Gender" and the "Number of entitled employees who took family related leave" alongside the "Share of entitled employees that took family related leave, in %." - For "Female," 9,596 employees took leave, representing 22.5%. - For "Male," 9,578 employees took leave, representing 19.3%. - For "Other1," no employees took leave, and the share is marked as "-". - For "Not reported," no employees took leave, and the share is marked as "-". - The "Total Employees" who took leave is 19,174, with a share of 20.7%.

It includes the following labels: "Coverage Rate," "Collective Bargaining Coverage," and "Social Dialogue." - **Coverage Rate**: - **0-19%**: Collective bargaining coverage includes "Employees - Non-EEA" for India. - **20-39%**: No data provided. - **40-59%**: Collective bargaining coverage includes "Employees - EEA" for Germany. - **60-79%**: No data provided. - **80-100%**: Social dialogue includes "Workplace representation (EEA only)" for Germany. The table focuses on regions with more than 50 employees representing over 10% of total employees.

  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta datos relacionados con activos sostenibles ambientalmente y KPIs de rendimiento, inversión (CapEx) y cobertura, con referencia al 31 de diciembre de 2023. Los encabezados incluyen: "Total environmentally sustainable assets (in € m)", "Turnover KPIs", "CapEx KPIs", "% coverage (over total assets)", "% of assets excluded from the numerator of the GAR (Article 7(2) and (3) and Section 1.1.2. of Annex V)", y "% of assets excluded from the denominator of the GAR (Article 7(1) and Section 1.2.4 of Annex V)". Los activos sostenibles totales alcanzaron 490 millones de euros, con un GAR (flow) de 1,259 millones. Los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 0.2 y 0.4 respectivamente, con una cobertura del 17.6% sobre el total de activos. El porcentaje de activos excluidos del numerador del GAR fue del 82.4%, mientras que los excluidos del denominador fueron "N/M". En la categoría "Trading book", los valores son "N/A". En "Financial guarantees", los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 153 y 374 respectivamente, con valores de 0.5 y 1.3. Para "Assets under Management", los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 8,635 y 16,857 respectivamente, con valores de 0.8 y 1.6. Finalmente, en "Fees and commissions income", los valores son "N/A".
  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla muestra la exposición de préstamos corporativos por tipo de pérdida de naturaleza al 31 de diciembre de 2023, con datos en € bn y porcentajes del portafolio. Los tipos de pérdida de naturaleza incluyen: "Water depletion" (17.3 € bn, 17.1% del portafolio, 2.2 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 12.7% de estos), "Terrestrial biodiversity and habitat loss" (11.6 € bn, 11.5% del portafolio, 4.6 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 39.2% de estos), "Ecosystem degradation from waste and pollution" (9.2 € bn, 9.1% del portafolio, 5.5 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 60.2% de estos), y "Marine ecosystem degradation" (6.4 € bn, 6.3% del portafolio, 4.7 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 74.0% de estos). La exposición total de préstamos corporativos por industria es de 101.2 € bn, representando el 100% del portafolio, sin datos específicos identificados a nivel de cliente.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta información sobre la **exposición crediticia** y las **emisiones financiadas** del libro de préstamos corporativos y bienes raíces residenciales al 31 de diciembre de 2024. 1. **Exposición total a préstamos corporativos por industria**: - Total: **€117.7 mil millones** en préstamos pendientes (100% del total) y **€290.3 mil millones** en compromisos totales. - Principales sectores: - **Manufactura e Ingeniería**: €9.8 mil millones pendientes (8.3%), emisiones financiadas Scope 1&2: 1.0 MtCO2e/año. - **Automotriz**: €7.0 mil millones pendientes (5.9%), Scope 1&2: 0.6 MtCO2e/año. - **Petróleo y Gas**: €5.6 mil millones pendientes (4.8%), Scope 1&2: 9.9 MtCO2e/año. - **Servicios Públicos**: €5.2 mil millones pendientes (4.4%), Scope 1&2: 8.1 MtCO2e/año. 2. **Préstamos asegurados por bienes raíces**: - Total: **€240.6 mil millones** (100%), de los cuales **€171.5 mil millones** (71.3%) están asegurados por bienes raíces residenciales y **€69.1 mil millones** (28.7%) por bienes raíces no residenciales. - En la UE: **€166.4 mil millones** (97%), destacando Alemania con **€153.2 mil millones** (92.1%). 3. **Calidad de datos PCAF**: Las puntuaciones de calidad de datos (5 = más baja) varían entre sectores, con valores entre 2.2 y 4.8. 4. **Objetivos net-zero**: Se incluyen sectores como **Petróleo y Gas (Upstream)**, **Generación de Energía**, **Automotriz (vehículos ligeros)**, **Acero**, **Minería de Carbón**, y **Cemento**, con compromisos totales y emisiones financiadas detalladas. 5. **Exclusiones**: Los préstamos securitizados de aviación están excluidos debido a la imposibilidad de aplicar el estándar PCAF.

Le pourcentage total de salariés en situation de handicap était de 3.2% au 31 décembre 2024 et de 3.1% au 31 décembre 2023. Cela montre une légère augmentation de 0.1% du pourcentage de salariés en situation de handicap entre 2023 et 2024.

  • Association of Sheltered Workgroups (Genossenschaft der Werkstätten, GDW) in Germany. In 2024, Deutsche Bank AG in Singapore was accredited with the Enabling Mark Platinum status by SGEnable, the predominant agency for disability and inclusion in Singapore. The bank’s ability to measure the number of employees with disabilities depends on voluntary self -disclosure and is limited by data protection laws, e.g., the European General Data Protection Regulation. Additionally, due to continuing social stigma, many individuals choose not to share this information, even in locations where it is permissible for the bank to ask. As at year -end 2024, the bank employed 3,057 people with disabilities, thereof 1,820 female people with disabilities, and 1,237 male people wit h disabilities. In Germany, the bank employed 2,511 people with disabilities as at year -end 2024 (6.2% of the bank’s headcount). Disclosure is based on Germany social code IX.   • Strategy ESRS 2 SBM -3 Deutsche Bank is committed to protecting its clients, society, and its own assets by taking an active role in the prevention, detection, and reporting of financial crime. Recognizing the material threats posed by financial crime, the Anti -Financial Crime f unction has defined a uniform strategy across financial crime risk prevention, detection, and reporting to ensure the highest level of protection for Deutsche Bank’s clients and stakeholders, while also supporting sustainable business practices. The Anti -Financial Crime strategy focuses on remediation, simplification, and consolidation of processes, and evolving the AFC Program across the areas of risk appetite, risk assessment, policy, training, assurance and reporting. The strategy serves to accelerate de cision -making around financial crime risks, enforce consistent standards, and foster Strategy ESRS 2 SBM -3 Deutsche Bank is committed to protecting its clients, society, and its own assets by taking an active role in the prevention, detection, and reporting of financial crime. Recognizing the material threats posed by financial crime, the Anti -Financial Crime f unction has defined a uniform strategy across financial crime risk prevention, detection, and reporting to ensure the highest level of protection for Deutsche Bank’s clients and stakeholders, while also supporting sustainable business practices. The Anti -Financial Crime strategy focuses on remediation, simplification, and consolidation of processes, and evolving the AFC Program across the areas of risk appetite, risk assessment, policy, training, assurance and reporting. The strategy serves to accelerate de cision -making around financial crime risks, enforce consistent standards, and foster
  • continues to further devel op them. Next to the Chief Sustainability Office, an additional enabler are ESG expert teams in the bank’s business divisions and infrastructure functions that foster the implementation of Deutsche Bank’s sustainability strategy and allow for a swift respo nse to emerging business opportunities and potential risks. In the years ahead, Deutsche Bank aims to broaden the scope of decarbonization, i.e., progressing from financed emissions to financed and facilitated emissions and capturing opportunities in the bank’s private clients’ assets under management. Moreover, De utsche Bank focuses on incorporating nature and biodiversity as well as just transition, which means to address the challenges of transitioning for developing economies. To operationalize its commitments, the bank is further developing the Initial Transition Plan as tools, methodologies and continues to further devel op them. Next to the Chief Sustainability Office, an additional enabler are ESG expert teams in the bank’s business divisions and infrastructure functions that foster the implementation of Deutsche Bank’s sustainability strategy and allow for a swift respo nse to emerging business opportunities and potential risks. In the years ahead, Deutsche Bank aims to broaden the scope of decarbonization, i.e., progressing from financed emissions to financed and facilitated emissions and capturing opportunities in the bank’s private clients’ assets under management. Moreover, De utsche Bank focuses on incorporating nature and biodiversity as well as just transition, which means to address the challenges of transitioning for developing economies. To operationalize its commitments, the bank is further developing the Initial Transition Plan as tools, methodologies and
  • valuation, monitoring , and review over the life of the loan. Deutsche Bank’s underwriting standards require real estate collateral to be appropriately insured against relevant risks including applicable natural hazards. In some countries, supplemental insurance against natural hazards is provided by the government. The European residential real estate portfolio amounted to € 166.4 billion at year -end 2024. Residential mortgages for private clients in Germany represent approximately 92% of this amount and around 1.2 million German private residences financed by loans secured by immovable properties are insured appropriately against relevant risks including applicable natural hazards. The insurance cover by real estate owners is monitored and complemented or substituted by De utsche Bank´s own insurance. In addition, new valuations and re -valuations require the identification of material environmental physical and transition valuation, monitoring , and review over the life of the loan. Deutsche Bank’s underwriting standards require real estate collateral to be appropriately insured against relevant risks including applicable natural hazards. In some countries, supplemental insurance against natural hazards is provided by the government. The European residential real estate portfolio amounted to € 166.4 billion at year -end 2024. Residential mortgages for private clients in Germany represent approximately 92% of this amount and around 1.2 million German private residences financed by loans secured by immovable properties are insured appropriately against relevant risks including applicable natural hazards. The insurance cover by real estate owners is monitored and complemented or substituted by De utsche Bank´s own insurance. In addition, new valuations and re -valuations require the identification of material environmental physical and transition
  • to 289e of the German Commercial Code (HGB). As the European Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) was not transposed into German law as of December 31, 2024, the bank applied the European Sustainability Reporting Standards (ESRS) as reporting framework as allowed by Section 315c (3) HGB in conjunction with Section 289d HGB and, on that basis, discloses governance, strategy, impact, risk and opportunity management, metrics and targets for material sustainability matters. In addition, the Sustainability Statement complies with the disclosure obligations under Article 8 (1) and (3) of the Taxonomy Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2020/852) and the respective specifications in Articles 4 and 10 (5) of the associated Disclosures de legated Act (Delegated Regulation (EU) 2021/2178). The Sustainability Statement was prepared on a consolidated basis and the scope of consolidation is the same as for the to 289e of the German Commercial Code (HGB). As the European Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) was not transposed into German law as of December 31, 2024, the bank applied the European Sustainability Reporting Standards (ESRS) as reporting framework as allowed by Section 315c (3) HGB in conjunction with Section 289d HGB and, on that basis, discloses governance, strategy, impact, risk and opportunity management, metrics and targets for material sustainability matters. In addition, the Sustainability Statement complies with the disclosure obligations under Article 8 (1) and (3) of the Taxonomy Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2020/852) and the respective specifications in Articles 4 and 10 (5) of the associated Disclosures de legated Act (Delegated Regulation (EU) 2021/2178). The Sustainability Statement was prepared on a consolidated basis and the scope of consolidation is the same as for the
S1-147

L'entreprise communique-t-elle toutes les informations contextuelles nécessaires pour comprendre les données relatives aux salariés en situation de handicap et la manière dont elles ont été compilées ?

nan

Je ne sais pas. Les informations fournies ne mentionnent pas spécifiquement la communication des données relatives aux salariés en situation de handicap ou la manière dont elles ont été compilées.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • ### Zusammenfassung der Tabelle: Die Tabelle aus dem **Deutsche Bank Annual Report 2024** listet die **Standards und Offenlegungsanforderungen** (Spalte 0), die **Beschreibung der Offenlegungsanforderung** (Spalte 1), das zugehörige Kapitel der **Nachhaltigkeitserklärung** (Spalte 2) und die **Seitenzahl** (Spalte 3). 1. **ESRS S1-4** behandelt Maßnahmen zu wesentlichen Auswirkungen auf die eigene Belegschaft sowie deren Risiken und Chancen, mit Fokus auf Diversität, Gleichberechtigung und ethnische Vielfalt (Seite 310). 2. **ESRS S1-5** umfasst Ziele zur Bewältigung negativer Auswirkungen und Förderung positiver Effekte, einschließlich Feedbackkultur, Geschlechter- und ethnischer Vielfalt (Seiten 291, 306, 307, 310). 3. **ESRS S1-6** beschreibt die Eigenschaften der Mitarbeiter und Nicht-Mitarbeiter der Deutschen Bank, einschließlich Einstellung und Fluktuation (Seiten 293, 296). 4. **ESRS S1-8** behandelt Tarifverhandlungen und sozialen Dialog (Seite 300). 5. **ESRS S1-9** fokussiert sich auf Diversitätsmetriken wie Geschlechter- und Altersdiversität (Seiten 307, 309). 6. **ESRS S4** und **ESRS S4-1** befassen sich mit Verbrauchern und Endnutzern, einschließlich Datenschutz, Kundenzentrierung und Beschwerdemanagement (Seiten 214, 313, 316, 317, 319, 346). 7. **ESRS S4-2** beschreibt Prozesse zur Einbindung von Verbrauchern und Endnutzern in Bezug auf Auswirkungen (Seiten 313, 316, 317, 319). 8. **ESRS S4-3** behandelt Prozesse zur Behebung negativer Auswirkungen und Kanäle für Verbraucher und Endnutzer, um Anliegen zu äußern (Seiten 313, 316). and

  • ## Social Information Own workforce New employees can voluntarily and anonymously evaluate the hiring process via the New Joiner Survey conducted after 30 and 90 days, as described in the sub-chapter "Processes to remediate negative impacts and channels for own workforce to raise concerns" of the "Own workforce" chapter. Deutsche Bank's HR function reviews this feedback to monitor the quality of their processes to continually improve the hiring process. Where legally permitted, the bank also uses any voluntary demographic information (e.g., age, gender, sexual orientation, ethnicity) to help make those processes more inclusive and to identify potential risks and impacts on specific groups and derive actions if required. The bank's global Off-boarding Policy defines a globally consistent minimum set of requirements for off-boarding members of its own workforce who are leaving the bank and for the handling of movers. It is approved by the Global Head of HR and reviewed annually. ## Social Information Own workforce New employees can voluntarily and anonymously evaluate the hiring process via the New Joiner Survey conducted after 30 and 90 days, as described in the sub-chapter "Processes to remediate negative impacts and channels for own workforce to raise concerns" of the "Own workforce" chapter. Deutsche Bank's HR function reviews this feedback to monitor the quality of their processes to continually improve the hiring process. Where legally permitted, the bank also uses any voluntary demographic information (e.g., age, gender, sexual orientation, ethnicity) to help make those processes more inclusive and to identify potential risks and impacts on specific groups and derive actions if required. The bank's global Off-boarding Policy defines a globally consistent minimum set of requirements for off-boarding members of its own workforce who are leaving the bank and for the handling of movers. It is approved by the Global Head of HR and reviewed annually.
  • ### Zusammenfassung der Tabelle Die Tabelle listet die "Standards and disclosure requirements" (Spalte 0), die "Disclosure requirement description" (Spalte 1), die zugehörigen Kapitel der "Sustainability Statement" (Spalte 2) und die Seitenzahlen (Spalte 3) im **Deutsche Bank Annual Report 2024** auf. 1. **ESRS S1-13**: Bezieht sich auf "Training and skills development metrics" und wird in den Kapiteln "Working conditions - Talent development" (Seite 300) und "Working conditions - Performance and reward" (Seite 303) behandelt. 2. **ESRS S1-15**: Thematisiert "Work-life balance metrics" im Kapitel "Working conditions - Work-life balance" auf Seite 304. 3. **ESRS S1-16**: Umfasst "Compensation metrics (pay gap and total compensation)" in den Kapiteln "Working conditions - Performance and reward" (Seite 304) und "Diversity, equity and inclusion - Gender diversity" (Seite 309). 4. **ESRS S1-17**: Behandelt "Incidents, complaints and severe human rights impacts" im Kapitel "Diversity, equity and inclusion - Incidents and complaints" auf Seite 311. 5. **ESRS S1-2**: Diskutiert "Processes for engaging with own workers and workers' representatives about impacts" im Kapitel "Processes for engaging with own workforce and workers' representatives about impacts" auf Seite 289. 6. **ESRS S1-3**: Thematisiert "Processes to remediate negative impacts and channels for own workers to raise concerns" auf den Seiten 287 und 290. 7. **ESRS S1-4**: Bezieht sich auf "Taking action on material impacts on own workforce" und wird in mehreren Kapiteln behandelt, darunter "Processes to remediate negative impacts and channels for own workforce to raise concerns - Employee feedback culture" (Seite 291), "Workforce management" (Seite 292), "Working conditions" (Seite 299), "Working conditions - Work-life balance" (Seite 305) und "Diversity, equity and inclusion" (Seite 306). Die Tabelle bietet eine detaillierte Übersicht über die Einhaltung der Offenlegungsanforderungen gemäß den ESRS-Standards im Bericht. and

  • The Sustainability Statement complies with the ESRS disclosure requirements as listed in the ESRS content index of this report. In addition, the Sustainability Statement also contains disclosures stemming from other EU legislations as included in the "Table of datapoints deriving from other EU Legislations". Furthermore, specific material topics for which there is no topic specific ESRS are subject to ESRS 2 "General Disclosures". Metrics and targets for these topics are reported according to the generally accepted sustainability reporting standards of the Global Reporting Initiative (GRI) as allowed by ESRS 1 - General requirements. This finds application with respect to the following entity-specific topics: - Data Protection: GRI 404-2, GRI G4 FS4 and GRI 418-1 - Information Security: GRI 404-2 - Tax: GRI 207-4 The Sustainability Statement complies with the ESRS disclosure requirements as listed in the ESRS content index of this report. In addition, the Sustainability Statement also contains disclosures stemming from other EU legislations as included in the "Table of datapoints deriving from other EU Legislations". Furthermore, specific material topics for which there is no topic specific ESRS are subject to ESRS 2 "General Disclosures". Metrics and targets for these topics are reported according to the generally accepted sustainability reporting standards of the Global Reporting Initiative (GRI) as allowed by ESRS 1 - General requirements. This finds application with respect to the following entity-specific topics: - Data Protection: GRI 404-2, GRI G4 FS4 and GRI 418-1 - Information Security: GRI 404-2 - Tax: GRI 207-4
  • ## Social Information Own workforce ### ESRS S1-4, ESRS 2 MDR-A ## Social Information Own workforce ### ESRS S1-4, ESRS 2 MDR-A
  • Die Tabelle mit dem Titel "Additional information Table of all the datapoints deriving from other EU legislation" aus dem Deutsche Bank Annual Report 2024 enthält folgende Informationen: 1. Die Spaltenüberschriften sind: "Disclosure requirement and related datapoint", "SFDR 1 reference 1", "Pillar 3 1 reference 2", "Benchmark Regulation 3 and EU Climate Law 4 reference" und "Sustainability Statement chapter". 2. Die Zeilen umfassen verschiedene ESRS-Anforderungen, darunter ESRS 2 - SBM 3 - E4 (Absätze 16 (b) und (c)), ESRS E4-2 (Absätze 24 (b), (c) und (d)), ESRS E5-5 (Absätze 37 (d) und 39), sowie ESRS 2- SBM3 - S1 (Absätze 14 (f) und (g)). 3. Die meisten Einträge in der Spalte "Sustainability Statement chapter" sind als "Not material" gekennzeichnet. 4. Einige spezifische ESRS-Anforderungen, wie ESRS S1-1 (Absätze 20, 21, 22 und 23) und ESRS S1-3 (Absatz 32 (c)), beziehen sich auf Themen wie Menschenrechte, Arbeitsunfälle und Beschwerdemechanismen. 5. Die zugehörigen Indikatornummern sind in der Spalte "SFDR 1 reference 1" angegeben, z. B. "Indicator number 10 Table #2 of Annex 1" oder "Indicator number 9 Table #3". 6. Für ESRS S1-1 (Absatz 21) wird auf die Delegierte Verordnung (EU) 2020/1816, Anhang II, in der Spalte "Benchmark Regulation 3 and EU Climate Law 4 reference" verwiesen. 7. Die Kapitel im "Sustainability Statement" umfassen Themen wie "Own workforce - Impact, risk and opportunity management, metrics and targets" und "Working conditions - Work-life balance". 8. Die Tabelle enthält keine Daten für die Spalte "Pillar 3 1 reference 2". 9. Die Tabelle hebt die Verbindung zwischen ESRS-Anforderungen und EU-Gesetzgebung hervor. 10. Die Tabelle dient als Übersicht über die Offenlegungsanforderungen und deren Relevanz für die Nachhaltigkeitsberichterstattung. and

  • ### Zusammenfassung der Tabelle aus dem Deutsche Bank Geschäftsbericht 2024: Die Tabelle listet Offenlegungsanforderungen und zugehörige Datenpunkte gemäß EU-Vorschriften auf. Die Spalten sind wie folgt benannt: "Disclosure requirement and related datapoint", "SFDR 1 reference 1", "Pillar 3 1 reference 2", "Benchmark Regulation 3 and EU Climate Law 4 reference" und "Sustainability Statement chapter". Die Jahre und Verweise umfassen unter anderem die Delegierte Verordnung (EU) 2020/1816 und 2020/1818. 1. **ESRS S1-16** behandelt den unbereinigten Gender-Pay-Gap (Absatz 97 (a)) und das übermäßige CEO-Gehälter-Verhältnis (Absatz 97 (b)), mit Bezug auf Indikatoren aus Tabelle #1 und #3 von Anhang I. Die Nachhaltigkeitskapitel umfassen Diversität, Gleichheit und Inklusion. 2. **ESRS S1-17** bezieht sich auf Diskriminierungsvorfälle (Absatz 103 (a)) und die Nichtbeachtung der UNGPs und OECD-Leitlinien (Absatz 104 (a)), mit Verweisen auf Indikatoren aus Tabelle #1 und #3 von Anhang I sowie EU-Verordnungen. 3. **ESRS 2-SBM3** adressiert Kinderarbeit oder Zwangsarbeit in der Wertschöpfungskette (Absatz 11 (b)), mit Indikatoren aus Tabelle #3 von Anhang I, jedoch als "nicht wesentlich" eingestuft. 4. **ESRS S2-1** umfasst Menschenrechtspolitiken (Absatz 17), Wertschöpfungskettenrichtlinien (Absatz 18) und Sorgfaltspflichten (Absatz 19), mit Indikatoren aus Tabelle #1 und #3 von Anhang I, ebenfalls als "nicht wesentlich" eingestuft. 5. **ESRS S2-4** und **ESRS S3-4** behandeln Menschenrechtsfragen und Vorfälle in der Wertschöpfungskette (Absatz 36), mit Indikatoren aus Tabelle #3 von Anhang I, ebenfalls als "nicht wesentlich" eingestuft. 6. **ESRS S4-1** bezieht sich auf Richtlinien für Verbraucher und Endnutzer (Absatz 16), mit Indikatoren aus Tabelle #1 und #3 von Anhang I, und ist im Kapitel zu Kundenorientierung und Beschwerdemanagement aufgeführt. and

  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta información sobre la **exposición crediticia** y las **emisiones financiadas** del libro de préstamos corporativos y bienes raíces residenciales al 31 de diciembre de 2024. 1. **Exposición total a préstamos corporativos por industria**: - Total: **€117.7 mil millones** en préstamos pendientes (100% del total) y **€290.3 mil millones** en compromisos totales. - Principales sectores: - **Manufactura e Ingeniería**: €9.8 mil millones pendientes (8.3%), emisiones financiadas Scope 1&2: 1.0 MtCO2e/año. - **Automotriz**: €7.0 mil millones pendientes (5.9%), Scope 1&2: 0.6 MtCO2e/año. - **Petróleo y Gas**: €5.6 mil millones pendientes (4.8%), Scope 1&2: 9.9 MtCO2e/año. - **Servicios Públicos**: €5.2 mil millones pendientes (4.4%), Scope 1&2: 8.1 MtCO2e/año. 2. **Préstamos asegurados por bienes raíces**: - Total: **€240.6 mil millones** (100%), de los cuales **€171.5 mil millones** (71.3%) están asegurados por bienes raíces residenciales y **€69.1 mil millones** (28.7%) por bienes raíces no residenciales. - En la UE: **€166.4 mil millones** (97%), destacando Alemania con **€153.2 mil millones** (92.1%). 3. **Calidad de datos PCAF**: Las puntuaciones de calidad de datos (5 = más baja) varían entre sectores, con valores entre 2.2 y 4.8. 4. **Objetivos net-zero**: Se incluyen sectores como **Petróleo y Gas (Upstream)**, **Generación de Energía**, **Automotriz (vehículos ligeros)**, **Acero**, **Minería de Carbón**, y **Cemento**, con compromisos totales y emisiones financiadas detalladas. 5. **Exclusiones**: Los préstamos securitizados de aviación están excluidos debido a la imposibilidad de aplicar el estándar PCAF. and

  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla muestra la exposición de préstamos corporativos por tipo de pérdida de naturaleza al 31 de diciembre de 2023, con datos en € bn y porcentajes del portafolio. Los tipos de pérdida de naturaleza incluyen: "Water depletion" (17.3 € bn, 17.1% del portafolio, 2.2 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 12.7% de estos), "Terrestrial biodiversity and habitat loss" (11.6 € bn, 11.5% del portafolio, 4.6 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 39.2% de estos), "Ecosystem degradation from waste and pollution" (9.2 € bn, 9.1% del portafolio, 5.5 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 60.2% de estos), y "Marine ecosystem degradation" (6.4 € bn, 6.3% del portafolio, 4.7 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 74.0% de estos). La exposición total de préstamos corporativos por industria es de 101.2 € bn, representando el 100% del portafolio, sin datos específicos identificados a nivel de cliente. and

Los activos sostenibles totales alcanzaron 490 millones de euros, con un GAR (flow) de 1,259 millones. Los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 0.2 y 0.4 respectivamente, con una cobertura del 17.6% sobre el total de activos. El porcentaje de activos excluidos del numerador del GAR fue del 82.4%, mientras que los excluidos del denominador fueron "N/M". En la categoría "Trading book", los valores son "N/A". En "Financial guarantees", los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 153 y 374 respectivamente, con valores de 0.5 y 1.3. Para "Assets under Management", los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 8,635 y 16,857 respectivamente, con valores de 0.8 y 1.6. Finalmente, en "Fees and commissions income", los valores son "N/A". and
