  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta datos en FTE al 31 de diciembre de 2023, desglosados por regiones: Alemania, Europa excluyendo Alemania, América, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África, y el Total. 1. **Número de empleados**: Alemania tiene 36,195, Europa excluyendo Alemania 18,103, América 8,232, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,601, con un total de 90,130. 2. **Número de empleados permanentes**: Alemania cuenta con 35,822, Europa excluyendo Alemania 18,066, América 8,232, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,584, sumando un total de 89,703. 3. **Número de empleados temporales**: Alemania tiene 373, Europa excluyendo Alemania 37, América no tiene empleados temporales, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 17, con un total de 427. 4. **Número de empleados con horas no garantizadas**: No hay empleados en esta categoría en ninguna región. 5. **Número de empleados (repetido)**: Alemania tiene 36,195, Europa excluyendo Alemania 18,103, América 8,232, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,601, con un total de 90,130. 6. **Número de empleados a tiempo completo**: Alemania cuenta con 28,686, Europa excluyendo Alemania 17,386, América 8,212, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,585, sumando un total de 81,869. 7. **Número de empleados a tiempo parcial**: Alemania tiene 7,509, Europa excluyendo Alemania 717, América 20, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 16, con un total de 8,261. ### END TABLE and

Je ne sais pas. Le contexte fourni ne donne pas suffisamment d'informations sur la manière dont les données relatives aux salariés en situation de handicap ont été compilées ou communiquées par l'entreprise.

Sources Pypdf :
  • ### Zusammenfassung der Tabelle: Die Tabelle aus dem **Deutsche Bank Annual Report 2024** listet die **Standards und Offenlegungsanforderungen** (Spalte 0), die **Beschreibung der Offenlegungsanforderung** (Spalte 1), das zugehörige Kapitel der **Nachhaltigkeitserklärung** (Spalte 2) und die **Seitenzahl** (Spalte 3). 1. **ESRS S1-4** behandelt Maßnahmen zu wesentlichen Auswirkungen auf die eigene Belegschaft sowie deren Risiken und Chancen, mit Fokus auf Diversität, Gleichberechtigung und ethnische Vielfalt (Seite 310). 2. **ESRS S1-5** umfasst Ziele zur Bewältigung negativer Auswirkungen und Förderung positiver Effekte, einschließlich Feedbackkultur, Geschlechter- und ethnischer Vielfalt (Seiten 291, 306, 307, 310). 3. **ESRS S1-6** beschreibt die Eigenschaften der Mitarbeiter und Nicht-Mitarbeiter der Deutschen Bank, einschließlich Einstellung und Fluktuation (Seiten 293, 296). 4. **ESRS S1-8** behandelt Tarifverhandlungen und sozialen Dialog (Seite 300). 5. **ESRS S1-9** fokussiert sich auf Diversitätsmetriken wie Geschlechter- und Altersdiversität (Seiten 307, 309). 6. **ESRS S4** und **ESRS S4-1** befassen sich mit Verbrauchern und Endnutzern, einschließlich Datenschutz, Kundenzentrierung und Beschwerdemanagement (Seiten 214, 313, 316, 317, 319, 346). 7. **ESRS S4-2** beschreibt Prozesse zur Einbindung von Verbrauchern und Endnutzern in Bezug auf Auswirkungen (Seiten 313, 316, 317, 319). 8. **ESRS S4-3** behandelt Prozesse zur Behebung negativer Auswirkungen und Kanäle für Verbraucher und Endnutzer, um Anliegen zu äußern (Seiten 313, 316).
  • ## Social Information Own workforce New employees can voluntarily and anonymously evaluate the hiring process via the New Joiner Survey conducted after 30 and 90 days, as described in the sub-chapter "Processes to remediate negative impacts and channels for own workforce to raise concerns" of the "Own workforce" chapter. Deutsche Bank's HR function reviews this feedback to monitor the quality of their processes to continually improve the hiring process. Where legally permitted, the bank also uses any voluntary demographic information (e.g., age, gender, sexual orientation, ethnicity) to help make those processes more inclusive and to identify potential risks and impacts on specific groups and derive actions if required. The bank's global Off-boarding Policy defines a globally consistent minimum set of requirements for off-boarding members of its own workforce who are leaving the bank and for the handling of movers. It is approved by the Global Head of HR and reviewed annually.
  • ### Zusammenfassung der Tabelle Die Tabelle listet die "Standards and disclosure requirements" (Spalte 0), die "Disclosure requirement description" (Spalte 1), die zugehörigen Kapitel der "Sustainability Statement" (Spalte 2) und die Seitenzahlen (Spalte 3) im **Deutsche Bank Annual Report 2024** auf. 1. **ESRS S1-13**: Bezieht sich auf "Training and skills development metrics" und wird in den Kapiteln "Working conditions - Talent development" (Seite 300) und "Working conditions - Performance and reward" (Seite 303) behandelt. 2. **ESRS S1-15**: Thematisiert "Work-life balance metrics" im Kapitel "Working conditions - Work-life balance" auf Seite 304. 3. **ESRS S1-16**: Umfasst "Compensation metrics (pay gap and total compensation)" in den Kapiteln "Working conditions - Performance and reward" (Seite 304) und "Diversity, equity and inclusion - Gender diversity" (Seite 309). 4. **ESRS S1-17**: Behandelt "Incidents, complaints and severe human rights impacts" im Kapitel "Diversity, equity and inclusion - Incidents and complaints" auf Seite 311. 5. **ESRS S1-2**: Diskutiert "Processes for engaging with own workers and workers' representatives about impacts" im Kapitel "Processes for engaging with own workforce and workers' representatives about impacts" auf Seite 289. 6. **ESRS S1-3**: Thematisiert "Processes to remediate negative impacts and channels for own workers to raise concerns" auf den Seiten 287 und 290. 7. **ESRS S1-4**: Bezieht sich auf "Taking action on material impacts on own workforce" und wird in mehreren Kapiteln behandelt, darunter "Processes to remediate negative impacts and channels for own workforce to raise concerns - Employee feedback culture" (Seite 291), "Workforce management" (Seite 292), "Working conditions" (Seite 299), "Working conditions - Work-life balance" (Seite 305) und "Diversity, equity and inclusion" (Seite 306). Die Tabelle bietet eine detaillierte Übersicht über die Einhaltung der Offenlegungsanforderungen gemäß den ESRS-Standards im Bericht.
  • The Sustainability Statement complies with the ESRS disclosure requirements as listed in the ESRS content index of this report. In addition, the Sustainability Statement also contains disclosures stemming from other EU legislations as included in the "Table of datapoints deriving from other EU Legislations". Furthermore, specific material topics for which there is no topic specific ESRS are subject to ESRS 2 "General Disclosures". Metrics and targets for these topics are reported according to the generally accepted sustainability reporting standards of the Global Reporting Initiative (GRI) as allowed by ESRS 1 - General requirements. This finds application with respect to the following entity-specific topics: - Data Protection: GRI 404-2, GRI G4 FS4 and GRI 418-1 - Information Security: GRI 404-2 - Tax: GRI 207-4
  • ## Social Information Own workforce ### ESRS S1-4, ESRS 2 MDR-A
  • Die Tabelle mit dem Titel "Additional information Table of all the datapoints deriving from other EU legislation" aus dem Deutsche Bank Annual Report 2024 enthält folgende Informationen: 1. Die Spaltenüberschriften sind: "Disclosure requirement and related datapoint", "SFDR 1 reference 1", "Pillar 3 1 reference 2", "Benchmark Regulation 3 and EU Climate Law 4 reference" und "Sustainability Statement chapter". 2. Die Zeilen umfassen verschiedene ESRS-Anforderungen, darunter ESRS 2 - SBM 3 - E4 (Absätze 16 (b) und (c)), ESRS E4-2 (Absätze 24 (b), (c) und (d)), ESRS E5-5 (Absätze 37 (d) und 39), sowie ESRS 2- SBM3 - S1 (Absätze 14 (f) und (g)). 3. Die meisten Einträge in der Spalte "Sustainability Statement chapter" sind als "Not material" gekennzeichnet. 4. Einige spezifische ESRS-Anforderungen, wie ESRS S1-1 (Absätze 20, 21, 22 und 23) und ESRS S1-3 (Absatz 32 (c)), beziehen sich auf Themen wie Menschenrechte, Arbeitsunfälle und Beschwerdemechanismen. 5. Die zugehörigen Indikatornummern sind in der Spalte "SFDR 1 reference 1" angegeben, z. B. "Indicator number 10 Table #2 of Annex 1" oder "Indicator number 9 Table #3". 6. Für ESRS S1-1 (Absatz 21) wird auf die Delegierte Verordnung (EU) 2020/1816, Anhang II, in der Spalte "Benchmark Regulation 3 and EU Climate Law 4 reference" verwiesen. 7. Die Kapitel im "Sustainability Statement" umfassen Themen wie "Own workforce - Impact, risk and opportunity management, metrics and targets" und "Working conditions - Work-life balance". 8. Die Tabelle enthält keine Daten für die Spalte "Pillar 3 1 reference 2". 9. Die Tabelle hebt die Verbindung zwischen ESRS-Anforderungen und EU-Gesetzgebung hervor. 10. Die Tabelle dient als Übersicht über die Offenlegungsanforderungen und deren Relevanz für die Nachhaltigkeitsberichterstattung.
  • ### Zusammenfassung der Tabelle aus dem Deutsche Bank Geschäftsbericht 2024: Die Tabelle listet Offenlegungsanforderungen und zugehörige Datenpunkte gemäß EU-Vorschriften auf. Die Spalten sind wie folgt benannt: "Disclosure requirement and related datapoint", "SFDR 1 reference 1", "Pillar 3 1 reference 2", "Benchmark Regulation 3 and EU Climate Law 4 reference" und "Sustainability Statement chapter". Die Jahre und Verweise umfassen unter anderem die Delegierte Verordnung (EU) 2020/1816 und 2020/1818. 1. **ESRS S1-16** behandelt den unbereinigten Gender-Pay-Gap (Absatz 97 (a)) und das übermäßige CEO-Gehälter-Verhältnis (Absatz 97 (b)), mit Bezug auf Indikatoren aus Tabelle #1 und #3 von Anhang I. Die Nachhaltigkeitskapitel umfassen Diversität, Gleichheit und Inklusion. 2. **ESRS S1-17** bezieht sich auf Diskriminierungsvorfälle (Absatz 103 (a)) und die Nichtbeachtung der UNGPs und OECD-Leitlinien (Absatz 104 (a)), mit Verweisen auf Indikatoren aus Tabelle #1 und #3 von Anhang I sowie EU-Verordnungen. 3. **ESRS 2-SBM3** adressiert Kinderarbeit oder Zwangsarbeit in der Wertschöpfungskette (Absatz 11 (b)), mit Indikatoren aus Tabelle #3 von Anhang I, jedoch als "nicht wesentlich" eingestuft. 4. **ESRS S2-1** umfasst Menschenrechtspolitiken (Absatz 17), Wertschöpfungskettenrichtlinien (Absatz 18) und Sorgfaltspflichten (Absatz 19), mit Indikatoren aus Tabelle #1 und #3 von Anhang I, ebenfalls als "nicht wesentlich" eingestuft. 5. **ESRS S2-4** und **ESRS S3-4** behandeln Menschenrechtsfragen und Vorfälle in der Wertschöpfungskette (Absatz 36), mit Indikatoren aus Tabelle #3 von Anhang I, ebenfalls als "nicht wesentlich" eingestuft. 6. **ESRS S4-1** bezieht sich auf Richtlinien für Verbraucher und Endnutzer (Absatz 16), mit Indikatoren aus Tabelle #1 und #3 von Anhang I, und ist im Kapitel zu Kundenorientierung und Beschwerdemanagement aufgeführt.
  • ## Social Information Own workforce
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta información sobre la **exposición crediticia** y las **emisiones financiadas** del libro de préstamos corporativos y bienes raíces residenciales al 31 de diciembre de 2024. 1. **Exposición total a préstamos corporativos por industria**: - Total: **€117.7 mil millones** en préstamos pendientes (100% del total) y **€290.3 mil millones** en compromisos totales. - Principales sectores: - **Manufactura e Ingeniería**: €9.8 mil millones pendientes (8.3%), emisiones financiadas Scope 1&2: 1.0 MtCO2e/año. - **Automotriz**: €7.0 mil millones pendientes (5.9%), Scope 1&2: 0.6 MtCO2e/año. - **Petróleo y Gas**: €5.6 mil millones pendientes (4.8%), Scope 1&2: 9.9 MtCO2e/año. - **Servicios Públicos**: €5.2 mil millones pendientes (4.4%), Scope 1&2: 8.1 MtCO2e/año. 2. **Préstamos asegurados por bienes raíces**: - Total: **€240.6 mil millones** (100%), de los cuales **€171.5 mil millones** (71.3%) están asegurados por bienes raíces residenciales y **€69.1 mil millones** (28.7%) por bienes raíces no residenciales. - En la UE: **€166.4 mil millones** (97%), destacando Alemania con **€153.2 mil millones** (92.1%). 3. **Calidad de datos PCAF**: Las puntuaciones de calidad de datos (5 = más baja) varían entre sectores, con valores entre 2.2 y 4.8. 4. **Objetivos net-zero**: Se incluyen sectores como **Petróleo y Gas (Upstream)**, **Generación de Energía**, **Automotriz (vehículos ligeros)**, **Acero**, **Minería de Carbón**, y **Cemento**, con compromisos totales y emisiones financiadas detalladas. 5. **Exclusiones**: Los préstamos securitizados de aviación están excluidos debido a la imposibilidad de aplicar el estándar PCAF.

Je ne sais pas. Les informations fournies ne mentionnent pas spécifiquement la communication des données relatives aux salariés en situation de handicap ou la manière dont elles ont été compilées.

  • minimize and/or a ppropriately mitigate any conflicts of interest the bank may encounter when providing products or services. The variable components of senior management’s compensation plans are carefully designed to establish appropriate incentives, particularly in relati on to conduct and adherence to the bank’s values and beliefs. At Private Bank, each loan application includes an analysis of the clients’ situation in order to protect the clients, mainly retail clients, from over -indebtedness. The bank’s loan processes, and staff training reflect this legal requirement. The bank takes a variety of steps to mitigate hardship in conjunction with nonperforming loans. The bank notifies clients early if they fail to repay loans or repay late. The bank’s loan processes, and staff training reflect this legal requirement. The bank takes a variety of steps to mitigate hardship in conjunction with nonperforming loans. The bank notifies clients early if they fail to repay loans or repay late.   • and employee acquisition and maintenance. Such a culture concerns professional integrity, engagement with workforce about impacts, and channels to r aise concerns including whistleblower procedures. Therefore, the bank has robust Speak - Up and Raise a Concern procedures and channels to support the core element of trust. Speak Up and Raise a Concern impact behaviors and drive the bank’s aspirational cult ure, with positive impacts such as increased ethical conduct and alignment to the aspirational culture of the bank, which are considered as very likely to materialize in the short term. A la ck of trust, Speak -Up and Raise a Concern procedures and channels on the other hand have been assessed as very likely to negatively impact the society by damaging confidence in the financial system and imposing costs to society on a short - term basis. Risks caused by unethical behavior and missing aspirational culture can include the loss of trust in the and employee acquisition and maintenance. S1-172

Quel est l'écart de rémunération entre les femmes et les hommes au sein de l'entreprise, en tenant compte des données pour l'année de référence ainsi que pour les deux années antérieures, si ces informations ont déjà été publiées dans le passé ?

nan

Je suis désolé, mais les informations concernant l'écart de rémunération entre les femmes et les hommes ne sont pas fournies dans les documents disponibles.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • ### Completion rate for performance reviews by gender (2023-2024) The table presents the "Completion rate for performance reviews by gender" for the years 2024 and 2023. The "Gender, in %" column lists the categories: "Female," "Male," "Other1," and "Not reported." The "Share of employees (headcount)" column provides the completion rates for each gender category. - In 2024, the completion rates were: "Female" (88%), "Male" (92%), "Other1" (67%), and "Not reported" (100%). - In 2023, the completion rates were: "Female" (86%), "Male" (90%), "Other1" (75%), and "Not reported" (50%). - The "Total Employees" completion rate was 90% in 2024 and 88% in 2023. "Other1" refers to gender as specified by the employees themselves. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    0 1 2
    Gender, in % Share of employees (headcount)
    2024 2023
    Female 88 86
    Male 92 90
    Other1 67 75
    Not reported 100 50
    Total Employees 90 88
  • ### Employee turnover by gender The table presents the "Share in %1" of employee turnover by gender for the years "2024" and "2023." The rows include "Female," "Male," "Other2," and "Not reported." In 2024, the share for "Female" was 43.9%, "Male" was 56.1%, "Other2" was 0%, and "Not reported" was 0%. In 2023, the share for "Female" was 41.8%, "Male" was 58.2%, "Other2" was 0%, and "Not reported" was 0%. and

  • ### Summary of the Table The table outlines goals and results for the representation of women across various levels within the organization, with data for Dec 31, 2024 (Goal and Result) and Dec 31, 2023 (Result). - **Level**: - **Management Board level -1 (headcount, in %)**: The goal for Dec 31, 2024 is 30.0%, with a result of 28.9%. The result for Dec 31, 2023 was 20.0%. - **Management Board level -2 (headcount, in %)**: The goal for Dec 31, 2024 is 30.0%, with a result of 28.3%. The result for Dec 31, 2023 was 27.6%. - **Senior Corporate Titles**: - **Managing Directors, Directors, Vice Presidents (headcount, in %)**: The goal for Dec 31, 2024 is 35.0%, with a result of 33.0%. The result for Dec 31, 2023 was 32.3%. The goals for Dec 31, 2024 align with the German Gender Quota Law (FüPoG II) and reflect December 2025 targets. and

  • ### Employees with disabilities by gender (summary) The table presents the percentage share of employees with disabilities by gender as of December 31, 2024, and December 31, 2023. The column labels are "Share of employees (headcount)" for the years "Dec 31, 2024" and "Dec 31, 2023." The row labels are "Gender, in %," "Female," "Male," "Other1," "Not reported," and "Total Employees." For "Female," the share was 4.1% in 2024 and 4.0% in 2023. For "Male," the share remained constant at 2.4% for both years. "Other1" and "Not reported" categories had no data available ("-") for either year. The "Total Employees" percentage was 3.2% in 2024 and 3.1% in 2023. and

  • ### Employees by contract type, broken down by gender (Dec 31, 2024) The table provides data in FTE on employees categorized by gender (Female, Male, Other, Not reported) and contract type. The "Number of employees" totals 89,753, with 40,293 Female, 49,454 Male, 4 Other, and 2 Not reported. Permanent employees account for 89,442, distributed as 40,113 Female, 49,323 Male, 4 Other, and 2 Not reported. Temporary employees total 311, with 180 Female and 131 Male; no data is reported for Other or Not reported categories. Non-guaranteed hours employees are not reported across all categories. The "Number of full-time employees" totals 81,842, with 33,443 Female, 48,393 Male, 4 Other, and 2 Not reported. Part-time employees total 7,911, distributed as 6,850 Female and 1,061 Male; no data is reported for Other or Not reported categories. and

  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta información sobre la **exposición crediticia** y las **emisiones financiadas** del libro de préstamos corporativos y bienes raíces residenciales al 31 de diciembre de 2024. 1. **Exposición total a préstamos corporativos por industria**: - Total: **€117.7 mil millones** en préstamos pendientes (100% del total) y **€290.3 mil millones** en compromisos totales. - Principales sectores: - **Manufactura e Ingeniería**: €9.8 mil millones pendientes (8.3%), emisiones financiadas Scope 1&2: 1.0 MtCO2e/año. - **Automotriz**: €7.0 mil millones pendientes (5.9%), Scope 1&2: 0.6 MtCO2e/año. - **Petróleo y Gas**: €5.6 mil millones pendientes (4.8%), Scope 1&2: 9.9 MtCO2e/año. - **Servicios Públicos**: €5.2 mil millones pendientes (4.4%), Scope 1&2: 8.1 MtCO2e/año. 2. **Préstamos asegurados por bienes raíces**: - Total: **€240.6 mil millones** (100%), de los cuales **€171.5 mil millones** (71.3%) están asegurados por bienes raíces residenciales y **€69.1 mil millones** (28.7%) por bienes raíces no residenciales. - En la UE: **€166.4 mil millones** (97%), destacando Alemania con **€153.2 mil millones** (92.1%). 3. **Calidad de datos PCAF**: Las puntuaciones de calidad de datos (5 = más baja) varían entre sectores, con valores entre 2.2 y 4.8. 4. **Objetivos net-zero**: Se incluyen sectores como **Petróleo y Gas (Upstream)**, **Generación de Energía**, **Automotriz (vehículos ligeros)**, **Acero**, **Minería de Carbón**, y **Cemento**, con compromisos totales y emisiones financiadas detalladas. 5. **Exclusiones**: Los préstamos securitizados de aviación están excluidos debido a la imposibilidad de aplicar el estándar PCAF. and

  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta datos relacionados con activos sostenibles ambientalmente y KPIs de rendimiento, inversión (CapEx) y cobertura, con referencia al 31 de diciembre de 2023. Los activos sostenibles totales alcanzaron 490 millones de euros, con un GAR (flow) de 1,259 millones. Los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 0.2 y 0.4 respectivamente, con una cobertura del 17.6% sobre el total de activos. El porcentaje de activos excluidos del numerador del GAR fue del 82.4%, mientras que los excluidos del denominador fueron "N/M". En la categoría "Trading book", los valores son "N/A". En "Financial guarantees", los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 153 y 374 respectivamente, con valores de 0.5 y 1.3. Para "Assets under Management", los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 8,635 y 16,857 respectivamente, con valores de 0.8 y 1.6.   • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta datos al 31 de diciembre de 2023 sobre activos sostenibles ambientalmente y KPIs relacionados. Las etiquetas incluyen "Total environmentally sustainable assets (in € m)", "Turnover KPIs", "CapEx KPIs", "% coverage (over total assets)", "% of assets excluded from the numerator of the GAR (Article 7(2) and (3) and Section 1.1.2. of Annex V)", y "% of assets excluded from the denominator of the GAR (Article 7(1) and Section 1.2.4 of Annex V)". En la fila "Main KPI", el "Green asset ratio (GAR) stock" muestra valores de 7,546 millones de euros para "Turnover" y 8,928 millones de euros para "CapEx". Los KPIs de "Turnover" y "CapEx" son 1.3 y 1.5, respectivamente. El porcentaje de cobertura sobre activos totales es 44.2%. Además, el porcentaje de activos excluidos del numerador del GAR es 26.2%, mientras que el porcentaje de activos excluidos del denominador del GAR es 55.8%. and

Je ne dispose pas d'informations complètes pour toutes les années demandées. Cependant, pour l'année 2024, l'écart global de rémunération non ajusté entre les femmes et les hommes chez Deutsche Bank était de 38.8%. Pour l'année 2023, dans le contexte du Royaume-Uni, l'écart de rémunération médian horaire a diminué de 24.9% en 2022 à 24.3% en 2023. Si vous avez besoin de données pour d'autres années ou régions spécifiques, celles-ci ne sont pas fournies dans le contexte disponible.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • ### Completion rate for performance reviews by gender (2023-2024) The table presents the "Completion rate for performance reviews by gender" for the years 2024 and 2023. The "Gender, in %" column lists the categories: "Female," "Male," "Other1," and "Not reported." The "Share of employees (headcount)" column provides the completion rates for each gender category. - In 2024, the completion rates were: "Female" (88%), "Male" (92%), "Other1" (67%), and "Not reported" (100%). - In 2023, the completion rates were: "Female" (86%), "Male" (90%), "Other1" (75%), and "Not reported" (50%). - The "Total Employees" completion rate was 90% in 2024 and 88% in 2023. "Other1" refers to gender as specified by the employees themselves.
  • ### Employee turnover by gender The table presents the "Share in %1" of employee turnover by gender for the years "2024" and "2023." The rows include "Female," "Male," "Other2," and "Not reported." In 2024, the share for "Female" was 43.9%, "Male" was 56.1%, "Other2" was 0%, and "Not reported" was 0%. In 2023, the share for "Female" was 41.8%, "Male" was 58.2%, "Other2" was 0%, and "Not reported" was 0%.
  • ### END TABLE 1 Gender as specified by the employees themselves 2 Prior year's comparatives aligned to presentation in the current year
  • ### Summary of the Table The table outlines goals and results for the representation of women across various levels within the organization, with data for Dec 31, 2024 (Goal and Result) and Dec 31, 2023 (Result). - **Level**: - **Management Board level -1 (headcount, in %)**: The goal for Dec 31, 2024 is 30.0%, with a result of 28.9%. The result for Dec 31, 2023 was 20.0%. - **Management Board level -2 (headcount, in %)**: The goal for Dec 31, 2024 is 30.0%, with a result of 28.3%. The result for Dec 31, 2023 was 27.6%. - **Senior Corporate Titles**: - **Managing Directors, Directors, Vice Presidents (headcount, in %)**: The goal for Dec 31, 2024 is 35.0%, with a result of 33.0%. The result for Dec 31, 2023 was 32.3%. The goals for Dec 31, 2024 align with the German Gender Quota Law (FüPoG II) and reflect December 2025 targets.
  • ### Employees with disabilities by gender (summary) The table presents the percentage share of employees with disabilities by gender as of December 31, 2024, and December 31, 2023. The column labels are "Share of employees (headcount)" for the years "Dec 31, 2024" and "Dec 31, 2023." The row labels are "Gender, in %," "Female," "Male," "Other1," "Not reported," and "Total Employees." For "Female," the share was 4.1% in 2024 and 4.0% in 2023. For "Male," the share remained constant at 2.4% for both years. "Other1" and "Not reported" categories had no data available ("-") for either year. The "Total Employees" percentage was 3.2% in 2024 and 3.1% in 2023.
  • ### Employees by contract type, broken down by gender (Dec 31, 2024) The table provides data in FTE on employees categorized by gender (Female, Male, Other, Not reported) and contract type. The "Number of employees" totals 89,753, with 40,293 Female, 49,454 Male, 4 Other, and 2 Not reported. Permanent employees account for 89,442, distributed as 40,113 Female, 49,323 Male, 4 Other, and 2 Not reported. Temporary employees total 311, with 180 Female and 131 Male; no data is reported for Other or Not reported categories. Non-guaranteed hours employees are not reported across all categories. The "Number of full-time employees" totals 81,842, with 33,443 Female, 48,393 Male, 4 Other, and 2 Not reported. Part-time employees total 7,911, distributed as 6,850 Female and 1,061 Male; no data is reported for Other or Not reported categories.
  • ### Employees by gender In 2024, gender distribution remains almost stable. In 2024 female share was 46.5% (2023: 46.3%). In 2024 male share was 53.5% (2023: 53.7%).
  • ### Summary of the Table The table provides data on employees in FTE as of Dec 31, 2023, categorized by gender (Female, Male, Other2, Not reported) and employment type. 1. **Number of employees**: Female (40,180), Male (49,945), Other2 (3), Not reported (2), Total (90,130). 2. **Number of permanent employees**: Female (39,920), Male (49,778), Other2 (3), Not reported (2), Total (89,703). 3. **Number of temporary employees**: Female (260), Male (167), Other2 (-), Not reported (-), Total (427). 4. **Number of non-guaranteed hours employees**: Female (0), Male (0), Other2 (0), Not reported (0), Total (0). 5. **Number of full-time employees**: Female (33,031), Male (48,832), Other2 (3), Not reported (2), Total (81,869). 6. **Number of part-time employees**: Female (7,149), Male (1,113), Other2 (-), Not reported (-), Total (8,261).
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta información sobre la **exposición crediticia** y las **emisiones financiadas** del libro de préstamos corporativos y bienes raíces residenciales al 31 de diciembre de 2024. 1. **Exposición total a préstamos corporativos por industria**: - Total: **€117.7 mil millones** en préstamos pendientes (100% del total) y **€290.3 mil millones** en compromisos totales. - Principales sectores: - **Manufactura e Ingeniería**: €9.8 mil millones pendientes (8.3%), emisiones financiadas Scope 1&2: 1.0 MtCO2e/año. - **Automotriz**: €7.0 mil millones pendientes (5.9%), Scope 1&2: 0.6 MtCO2e/año. - **Petróleo y Gas**: €5.6 mil millones pendientes (4.8%), Scope 1&2: 9.9 MtCO2e/año. - **Servicios Públicos**: €5.2 mil millones pendientes (4.4%), Scope 1&2: 8.1 MtCO2e/año. 2. **Préstamos asegurados por bienes raíces**: - Total: **€240.6 mil millones** (100%), de los cuales **€171.5 mil millones** (71.3%) están asegurados por bienes raíces residenciales y **€69.1 mil millones** (28.7%) por bienes raíces no residenciales. - En la UE: **€166.4 mil millones** (97%), destacando Alemania con **€153.2 mil millones** (92.1%). 3. **Calidad de datos PCAF**: Las puntuaciones de calidad de datos (5 = más baja) varían entre sectores, con valores entre 2.2 y 4.8. 4. **Objetivos net-zero**: Se incluyen sectores como **Petróleo y Gas (Upstream)**, **Generación de Energía**, **Automotriz (vehículos ligeros)**, **Acero**, **Minería de Carbón**, y **Cemento**, con compromisos totales y emisiones financiadas detalladas. 5. **Exclusiones**: Los préstamos securitizados de aviación están excluidos debido a la imposibilidad de aplicar el estándar PCAF.

Las etiquetas incluyen "Total environmentally sustainable assets (in € m)", "Turnover KPIs", "CapEx KPIs", "% coverage (over total assets)", "% of assets excluded from the numerator of the GAR (Article 7(2) and (3) and Section 1.1.2. of Annex V)", y "% of assets excluded from the denominator of the GAR (Article 7(1) and Section 1.2.4 of Annex V)". Je suis désolé, mais les informations concernant l'écart de rémunération entre les femmes et les hommes ne sont pas fournies dans les documents disponibles.


Afficher les sources Azure
Sources Azure :
  • right direction, it has provided further resources for the businesses and infrastructure functions to effectively utilize these tools and create a fair, transparent and sustainable environment. The bank has disclosed to the public or reported to the regulators on the unadjusted Gender pay gap for a number of years in countries where there is an existing legislative requirement. For example, in the United Kingdom, the bank published its seventh Ge nder pay gap Report in March 2024. Progress has been made with the median hourly pay gap decreasing from 24.9% in 2022 to 24.3% in 2023 and the median bonus pay gap narrowed from 41.3% to 38.8%. In addition, the bank voluntarily published its ethnicity pay gap in the United Kingdom for the fourth time. For the reporting year 2024, Deutsche Bank reported its unadjusted global Gender pay gap globally for the first time to understand the extent of the gap in the pay between women and men amongst the bank’s employees globally including right direction, it has provided further resources for the businesses and infrastructure functions to effectively utilize these tools and create a fair, transparent and sustainable environment. The bank has disclosed to the public or reported to the regulators on the unadjusted Gender pay gap for a number of years in countries where there is an existing legislative requirement. For example, in the United Kingdom, the bank published its seventh Ge nder pay gap Report in March 2024. Progress has been made with the median hourly pay gap decreasing from 24.9% in 2022 to 24.3% in 2023 and the median bonus pay gap narrowed from 41.3% to 38.8%. In addition, the bank voluntarily published its ethnicity pay gap in the United Kingdom for the fourth time. For the reporting year 2024, Deutsche Bank reported its unadjusted global Gender pay gap globally for the first time to understand the extent of the gap in the pay between women and men amongst the bank’s employees globally including

  • Management Board membe rs. The unadjusted global Gender pay gap is defined as the difference of average hourly pay levels between female and male employees, expressed as percentage of the average hourly pay level of male employees. For 2024, the unadjusted global Gender pay gap was 38.8%. A regression analysis, that considers a number of objective factors such as seniority, business division and region, results in an adjusted Gender pay gap of 6.0%. Therefore, the underlying reason for the unadjusted global Gender pay gap is primarily linke d to the lower representation of women in senior and highly remunerated roles and in higher cost locations. To drive structural change and get more women into senior roles, Deutsche Bank continues to make progress on its 35 by 25 gender diversity goal and initiatives, as described in the “Diversity, equity and inclusion” sub -chapter of the “Own Management Board membe rs. The unadjusted global Gender pay gap is defined as the difference of average hourly pay levels between female and male employees, expressed as percentage of the average hourly pay level of male employees. For 2024, the unadjusted global Gender pay gap was 38.8%. A regression analysis, that considers a number of objective factors such as seniority, business division and region, results in an adjusted Gender pay gap of 6.0%. Therefore, the underlying reason for the unadjusted global Gender pay gap is primarily linke d to the lower representation of women in senior and highly remunerated roles and in higher cost locations. To drive structural change and get more women into senior roles, Deutsche Bank continues to make progress on its 35 by 25 gender diversity goal and initiatives, as described in the “Diversity, equity and inclusion” sub -chapter of the “Own
  • required to formally document th is. The bank tracks progress through responses to the annual People Survey on employee achievement of career goals. For Deutsche Bank Group, the completion rate for performance reviews remained at a high level in 2024. Completion rate for performance reviews by gender Gender, in % Share of employees (headcount) 2024 2023 Female 88 86 Male 92 90 Other1 67 75 Not reported 100 50 Total Employees 90 88 1 Gender as specified by the employees themselves 304 Deutsche Bank Social Information Annual Report 2024 Own workforce Annual total remuneration ratio ESRS S1-16 The bank’s remuneration strategy rewards performance and contribution through an appropriate mix of fixed and variable remuneration. An employee’s fixed pay is determined using a mix of internal fixed pay data and external market data to ensure adherence t o legislation such as minimum wage requirements and alignment with peers. Variable compensation is required to formally document th is. The bank tracks progress through responses to the annual People Survey on employee achievement of career goals.   • awarded based on a variable compensation orientation framework and is closely linked to individual performance metrics, such as the delivery of business prio rities set at the beginning of the performance year, as well as conduct and behavior. The Annual total remuneration ratio compares the annual total remuneration of the highest paid employee to the median annual total remuneration for all employees (excluding the highest paid employee). The calculation reveals that the Annual total remunerat ion ratio is currently 237. The total remuneration ratio reflects the bank’s diverse operation across numerous geographies worldwide, covering four business divisions: Private Bank, Corporate and Investment Bank and Asset Management as well as operations a nd support functions. For the purposes of the calculation, the highest paid employee is not the CEO, demonstrating the diversity of the bank's activities and remuneration opportunities. Work -life balance ESRS S1 -15 awarded based on a variable compensation orientation framework and is closely linked to individual performance metrics, such as the delivery of business prio rities set at the beginning of the performance year, as well as conduct and behavior. The Annual total remuneration ratio compares the annual total remuneration of the highest paid employee to the median annual total remuneration for all employees (excluding the highest paid employee). The calculation reveals that the Annual total remunerat ion ratio is currently 237. The total remuneration ratio reflects the bank’s diverse operation across numerous geographies worldwide, covering four business divisions: Private Bank, Corporate and Investment Bank and Asset Management as well as operations a nd support functions. For the purposes of the calculation, the highest paid employee is not the CEO, demonstrating the diversity of the bank's activities and remuneration opportunities. Work -life balance ESRS S1 -15

  • Strategy ESRS 2 SBM -3 Deutsche Bank is committed to protecting its clients, society, and its own assets by taking an active role in the prevention, detection, and reporting of financial crime. Recognizing the material threats posed by financial crime, the Anti -Financial Crime f unction has defined a uniform strategy across financial crime risk prevention, detection, and reporting to ensure the highest level of protection for Deutsche Bank’s clients and stakeholders, while also supporting sustainable business practices. The Anti -Financial Crime strategy focuses on remediation, simplification, and consolidation of processes, and evolving the AFC Program across the areas of risk appetite, risk assessment, policy, training, assurance and reporting. The strategy serves to accelerate de cision -making around financial crime risks, enforce consistent standards, and foster Strategy ESRS 2 SBM -3 Deutsche Bank is committed to protecting its clients, society, and its own assets by taking an active role in the prevention, detection, and reporting of financial crime. Recognizing the material threats posed by financial crime, the Anti -Financial Crime f unction has defined a uniform strategy across financial crime risk prevention, detection, and reporting to ensure the highest level of protection for Deutsche Bank’s clients and stakeholders, while also supporting sustainable business practices. The Anti -Financial Crime strategy focuses on remediation, simplification, and consolidation of processes, and evolving the AFC Program across the areas of risk appetite, risk assessment, policy, training, assurance and reporting. The strategy serves to accelerate de cision -making around financial crime risks, enforce consistent standards, and foster
  • continues to further devel op them. Next to the Chief Sustainability Office, an additional enabler are ESG expert teams in the bank’s business divisions and infrastructure functions that foster the implementation of Deutsche Bank’s sustainability strategy and allow for a swift respo nse to emerging business opportunities and potential risks. In the years ahead, Deutsche Bank aims to broaden the scope of decarbonization, i.e., progressing from financed emissions to financed and facilitated emissions and capturing opportunities in the bank’s private clients’ assets under management. Moreover, De utsche Bank focuses on incorporating nature and biodiversity as well as just transition, which means to address the challenges of transitioning for developing economies. To operationalize its commitments, the bank is further developing the Initial Transition Plan as tools, methodologies and continues to further devel op them.   • valuation, monitoring , and review over the life of the loan. Deutsche Bank’s underwriting standards require real estate collateral to be appropriately insured against relevant risks including applicable natural hazards. In some countries, supplemental insurance against natural hazards is provided by the government. The European residential real estate portfolio amounted to € 166.4 billion at year -end 2024. Residential mortgages for private clients in Germany represent approximately 92% of this amount and around 1.2 million German private residences financed by loans secured by immovable properties are insured appropriately against relevant risks including applicable natural hazards. The insurance cover by real estate owners is monitored and complemented or substituted by De utsche Bank´s own insurance. In addition, new valuations and re -valuations require the identification of material environmental physical and transition valuation, monitoring , and review over the life of the loan.   • to 289e of the German Commercial Code (HGB). As the European Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) was not transposed into German law as of December 31, 2024, the bank applied the European Sustainability Reporting Standards (ESRS) as reporting framework as allowed by Section 315c (3) HGB in conjunction with Section 289d HGB and, on that basis, discloses governance, strategy, impact, risk and opportunity management, metrics and targets for material sustainability matters. In addition, the Sustainability Statement complies with the disclosure obligations under Article 8 (1) and (3) of the Taxonomy Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2020/852) and the respective specifications in Articles 4 and 10 (5) of the associated Disclosures de legated Act (Delegated Regulation (EU) 2021/2178). The Sustainability Statement was prepared on a consolidated basis and the scope of consolidation is the same as for the to 289e of the German Commercial Code (HGB). As the European Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) was not transposed into German law as of December 31, 2024, the bank applied the European Sustainability Reporting Standards (ESRS) as reporting framework as allowed by Section 315c (3) HGB in conjunction with Section 289d HGB and, on that basis, discloses governance, strategy, impact, risk and opportunity management, metrics and targets for material sustainability matters. In addition, the Sustainability Statement complies with the disclosure obligations under Article 8 (1) and (3) of the Taxonomy Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2020/852) and the respective specifications in Articles 4 and 10 (5) of the associated Disclosures de legated Act (Delegated Regulation (EU) 2021/2178). XX

Quel est le ratio de rémunération totale annuelle au sein de l'entreprise ? Quel est le montant total de la rémunération annuelle pour les employés (y compris les salaires, les primes, les avantages et autres compensations)



Pour répondre à cette question, merci de fournir :

Le montant total de la rémunération annuelle pour les employés (y compris les salaires, les primes, les avantages et autres compensations).
Des détails sur la méthodologie utilisée pour calculer ce ratio, y compris les critères pris en compte.
Si disponible, des informations sur l'évolution de ce ratio au fil des années, ainsi que des comparaisons avec des normes sectorielles ou des benchmarks.

Le ratio de rémunération totale annuelle au sein de l'entreprise est de 237. Ce ratio compare la rémunération totale annuelle du salarié le mieux payé avec la rémunération médiane annuelle totale de tous les employés, en excluant le salarié le mieux payé. La méthodologie utilisée pour calculer ce ratio inclut l'ensemble des rémunérations, c'est-à-dire les salaires fixes, les primes, les avantages et autres compensations. Le salarié le mieux payé dans ce contexte n'est pas le PDG, ce qui souligne la diversité des activités de la banque et des opportunités de rémunération.

Concernant le montant total de la rémunération annuelle pour les employés, le contexte fourni ne donne pas de chiffres spécifiques pour l'ensemble des salaires, primes, avantages et autres compensations.

Il n'y a pas d'informations spécifiques sur l'évolution de ce ratio au fil des années ou des comparaisons avec des normes sectorielles ou des benchmarks dans les documents fournis. Par conséquent, je ne suis pas en mesure de fournir ces détails.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • The Annual total remuneration ratio compares the annual total remuneration of the highest paid employee to the median annual total remuneration for all employees (excluding the highest paid employee). The calculation reveals that the Annual total remuneration ratio is currently 237. The total remuneration ratio reflects the bank's diverse operation across numerous geographies worldwide, covering four business divisions: Private Bank, Corporate and Investment Bank and Asset Management as well as operations and support functions. For the purposes of the calculation, the highest paid employee is not the CEO, demonstrating the diversity of the bank's activities and remuneration opportunities. The Annual total remuneration ratio compares the annual total remuneration of the highest paid employee to the median annual total remuneration for all employees (excluding the highest paid employee). The calculation reveals that the Annual total remuneration ratio is currently 237. The total remuneration ratio reflects the bank's diverse operation across numerous geographies worldwide, covering four business divisions: Private Bank, Corporate and Investment Bank and Asset Management as well as operations and support functions. For the purposes of the calculation, the highest paid employee is not the CEO, demonstrating the diversity of the bank's activities and remuneration opportunities.
  • ## Deutsche Bank Annual Report 2024 ### Annual total remuneration ratio ESRS S1-16 The bank's remuneration strategy rewards performance and contribution through an appropriate mix of fixed and variable remuneration. An employee's fixed pay is determined using a mix of internal fixed pay data and external market data to ensure adherence to legislation such as minimum wage requirements and alignment with peers. Variable compensation is awarded based on a variable compensation orientation framework and is closely linked to individual performance metrics, such as the delivery of business priorities set at the beginning of the performance year, as well as conduct and behavior. ## Deutsche Bank Annual Report 2024 ### Annual total remuneration ratio ESRS S1-16 The bank's remuneration strategy rewards performance and contribution through an appropriate mix of fixed and variable remuneration. An employee's fixed pay is determined using a mix of internal fixed pay data and external market data to ensure adherence to legislation such as minimum wage requirements and alignment with peers. Variable compensation is awarded based on a variable compensation orientation framework and is closely linked to individual performance metrics, such as the delivery of business priorities set at the beginning of the performance year, as well as conduct and behavior.

  • The compensation system for the Management Board consists of fixed and variable compensation components. The fixed compensation consists of base salary, fringe benefits and contributions to the company pension schemes. The variable compensation is divided into Short-Term Incentives (STI) and Long-Term Incentives (LTI). In the STI, three to five objectives for measuring individual and divisional performance over a period of one year are set in the beginning of the period and disclosed retrospectively. For LTI, four objectives, which are identical for all Management Board Members are set and disclosed ex ante. The STI is determined after one year, while the LTI is only determined after an assessment period of three years. The compensation system for the Management Board consists of fixed and variable compensation components. The fixed compensation consists of base salary, fringe benefits and contributions to the company pension schemes. The variable compensation is divided into Short-Term Incentives (STI) and Long-Term Incentives (LTI). In the STI, three to five objectives for measuring individual and divisional performance over a period of one year are set in the beginning of the period and disclosed retrospectively. For LTI, four objectives, which are identical for all Management Board Members are set and disclosed ex ante. The STI is determined after one year, while the LTI is only determined after an assessment period of three years.

Le ratio de rémunération totale annuelle au sein de l'entreprise, selon le contexte fourni, est de 237. Ce ratio compare la rémunération totale annuelle du salarié le mieux payé à la rémunération totale annuelle médiane de tous les autres employés, à l'exclusion de celui-ci. Ce calcul prend en compte la diversité des opérations de la banque à travers de nombreuses régions géographiques et couvre plusieurs divisions commerciales telles que la banque privée, la banque d'entreprises et d'investissement, la gestion d'actifs, ainsi que les fonctions de soutien.

En ce qui concerne le montant total de la rémunération annuelle pour les employés, le contexte ne fournit pas de chiffre exact pour l'ensemble des employés, mais mentionne que les coûts totaux de la main-d'œuvre pour 2024 étaient de 12,176 millions d'euros. Ce montant inclut les rémunérations et avantages pour les employés ainsi que les frais de service pour les contractuels, les intérimaires d'agences et les ressources informatiques externes.

La méthodologie utilisée pour calculer ce ratio repose sur l'orientation vers une compensation variable liée aux performances individuelles, telles que la réalisation des priorités commerciales définies au début de l'année de performance ainsi que la conduite et le comportement des employés.

Aucune information spécifique sur l'évolution de ce ratio au fil des années ou des comparaisons avec des normes sectorielles ou des benchmarks n'est fournie dans les documents disponibles.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • The Annual total remuneration ratio compares the annual total remuneration of the highest paid employee to the median annual total remuneration for all employees (excluding the highest paid employee). The calculation reveals that the Annual total remuneration ratio is currently 237. The total remuneration ratio reflects the bank's diverse operation across numerous geographies worldwide, covering four business divisions: Private Bank, Corporate and Investment Bank and Asset Management as well as operations and support functions. For the purposes of the calculation, the highest paid employee is not the CEO, demonstrating the diversity of the bank's activities and remuneration opportunities.
  • ## Deutsche Bank Annual Report 2024 ### Annual total remuneration ratio ESRS S1-16 The bank's remuneration strategy rewards performance and contribution through an appropriate mix of fixed and variable remuneration. An employee's fixed pay is determined using a mix of internal fixed pay data and external market data to ensure adherence to legislation such as minimum wage requirements and alignment with peers. Variable compensation is awarded based on a variable compensation orientation framework and is closely linked to individual performance metrics, such as the delivery of business priorities set at the beginning of the performance year, as well as conduct and behavior.
  • ### Summary of the Table The table provides data on employees in FTE as of Dec 31, 2023, categorized by gender (Female, Male, Other2, Not reported) and employment type. 1. **Number of employees**: Female (40,180), Male (49,945), Other2 (3), Not reported (2), Total (90,130). 2. **Number of permanent employees**: Female (39,920), Male (49,778), Other2 (3), Not reported (2), Total (89,703). 3. **Number of temporary employees**: Female (260), Male (167), Other2 (-), Not reported (-), Total (427). 4. **Number of non-guaranteed hours employees**: Female (0), Male (0), Other2 (0), Not reported (0), Total (0). 5. **Number of full-time employees**: Female (33,031), Male (48,832), Other2 (3), Not reported (2), Total (81,869). 6. **Number of part-time employees**: Female (7,149), Male (1,113), Other2 (-), Not reported (-), Total (8,261).
  • ### END TABLE 1 Compensation and benefits for employees plus service fees for contractors, agency temps and IT vendor resources The number of employees employed by the bank throughout the business year relates to 'Compensation and benefits' as the most representative number in this respect in the bank's financial statement.
  • ### Employees by contract type, broken down by gender (Dec 31, 2024) The table provides data in FTE on employees categorized by gender (Female, Male, Other, Not reported) and contract type. The "Number of employees" totals 89,753, with 40,293 Female, 49,454 Male, 4 Other, and 2 Not reported. Permanent employees account for 89,442, distributed as 40,113 Female, 49,323 Male, 4 Other, and 2 Not reported. Temporary employees total 311, with 180 Female and 131 Male; no data is reported for Other or Not reported categories. Non-guaranteed hours employees are not reported across all categories. The "Number of full-time employees" totals 81,842, with 33,443 Female, 48,393 Male, 4 Other, and 2 Not reported. Part-time employees total 7,911, distributed as 6,850 Female and 1,061 Male; no data is reported for Other or Not reported categories.
  • The compensation system for the Management Board consists of fixed and variable compensation components. The fixed compensation consists of base salary, fringe benefits and contributions to the company pension schemes. The variable compensation is divided into Short-Term Incentives (STI) and Long-Term Incentives (LTI). In the STI, three to five objectives for measuring individual and divisional performance over a period of one year are set in the beginning of the period and disclosed retrospectively. For LTI, four objectives, which are identical for all Management Board Members are set and disclosed ex ante. The STI is determined after one year, while the LTI is only determined after an assessment period of three years.
  • ### Completion rate for performance reviews by gender (2023-2024) The table presents the "Completion rate for performance reviews by gender" for the years 2024 and 2023. The "Gender, in %" column lists the categories: "Female," "Male," "Other1," and "Not reported." The "Share of employees (headcount)" column provides the completion rates for each gender category. - In 2024, the completion rates were: "Female" (88%), "Male" (92%), "Other1" (67%), and "Not reported" (100%). - In 2023, the completion rates were: "Female" (86%), "Male" (90%), "Other1" (75%), and "Not reported" (50%). - The "Total Employees" completion rate was 90% in 2024 and 88% in 2023. "Other1" refers to gender as specified by the employees themselves.
  • ### Employee turnover by gender The table presents the "Share in %1" of employee turnover by gender for the years "2024" and "2023." The rows include "Female," "Male," "Other2," and "Not reported." In 2024, the share for "Female" was 43.9%, "Male" was 56.1%, "Other2" was 0%, and "Not reported" was 0%. In 2023, the share for "Female" was 41.8%, "Male" was 58.2%, "Other2" was 0%, and "Not reported" was 0%.
  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla muestra la exposición de préstamos corporativos por tipo de pérdida de naturaleza al 31 de diciembre de 2023, con datos en € bn y porcentajes del portafolio. Los tipos de pérdida de naturaleza incluyen: "Water depletion" (17.3 € bn, 17.1% del portafolio, 2.2 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 12.7% de estos), "Terrestrial biodiversity and habitat loss" (11.6 € bn, 11.5% del portafolio, 4.6 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 39.2% de estos), "Ecosystem degradation from waste and pollution" (9.2 € bn, 9.1% del portafolio, 5.5 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 60.2% de estos), y "Marine ecosystem degradation" (6.4 € bn, 6.3% del portafolio, 4.7 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 74.0% de estos). La exposición total de préstamos corporativos por industria es de 101.2 € bn, representando el 100% del portafolio, sin datos específicos identificados a nivel de cliente.
  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta datos al 31 de diciembre de 2023 sobre activos sostenibles ambientalmente y KPIs relacionados. Las etiquetas incluyen "Total environmentally sustainable assets (in € m)", "Turnover KPIs", "CapEx KPIs", "% coverage (over total assets)", "% of assets excluded from the numerator of the GAR (Article 7(2) and (3) and Section 1.1.2. of Annex V)", y "% of assets excluded from the denominator of the GAR (Article 7(1) and Section 1.2.4 of Annex V)". En la fila "Main KPI", el "Green asset ratio (GAR) stock" muestra valores de 7,546 millones de euros para "Turnover" y 8,928 millones de euros para "CapEx". Los KPIs de "Turnover" y "CapEx" son 1.3 y 1.5, respectivamente. El porcentaje de cobertura sobre activos totales es 44.2%. Además, el porcentaje de activos excluidos del numerador del GAR es 26.2%, mientras que el porcentaje de activos excluidos del denominador del GAR es 55.8%.

Los encabezados incluyen: "Total environmentally sustainable assets (in € m)", "Turnover KPIs", "CapEx KPIs", "% coverage (over total assets)", "% of assets excluded from the numerator of the GAR (Article 7(2) and (3) and Section 1.1.2. of Annex V)", y "% of assets excluded from the denominator of the GAR (Article 7(1) and Section 1.2.4 of Annex V)".   • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta datos en FTE al 31 de diciembre de 2023, desglosados por regiones: Alemania, Europa excluyendo Alemania, América, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África, y el Total. 1. **Número de empleados**: Alemania tiene 36,195, Europa excluyendo Alemania 18,103, América 8,232, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,601, con un total de 90,130. 2. **Número de empleados permanentes**: Alemania cuenta con 35,822, Europa excluyendo Alemania 18,066, América 8,232, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,584, sumando un total de 89,703. 3. **Número de empleados temporales**: Alemania tiene 373, Europa excluyendo Alemania 37, América no tiene empleados temporales, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 17, con un total de 427. 4. **Número de empleados con horas no garantizadas**: No hay empleados en esta categoría en ninguna región. 5. **Número de empleados (repetido)**: Alemania tiene 36,195, Europa excluyendo Alemania 18,103, América 8,232, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,601, con un total de 90,130. 6. **Número de empleados a tiempo completo**: Alemania cuenta con 28,686, Europa excluyendo Alemania 17,386, América 8,212, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 27,585, sumando un total de 81,869. 7. **Número de empleados a tiempo parcial**: Alemania tiene 7,509, Europa excluyendo Alemania 717, América 20, Medio Oriente y Asia-Pacífico, África 16, con un total de 8,261. ### END TABLE

Le ratio de rémunération totale annuelle au sein de l'entreprise est de 237. Ce ratio compare la rémunération totale annuelle du salarié le mieux payé avec la rémunération médiane annuelle totale de tous les employés, en excluant le salarié le mieux payé. La méthodologie utilisée pour calculer ce ratio inclut l'ensemble des rémunérations, c'est-à-dire les salaires fixes, les primes, les avantages et autres compensations. Le salarié le mieux payé dans ce contexte n'est pas le PDG, ce qui souligne la diversité des activités de la banque et des opportunités de rémunération.

Concernant le montant total de la rémunération annuelle pour les employés, le contexte fourni ne donne pas de chiffres spécifiques pour l'ensemble des salaires, primes, avantages et autres compensations.

Il n'y a pas d'informations spécifiques sur l'évolution de ce ratio au fil des années ou des comparaisons avec des normes sectorielles ou des benchmarks dans les documents fournis. Par conséquent, je ne suis pas en mesure de fournir ces détails.

The Annual total remuneration ratio compares the annual total remuneration of the highest paid employee to the median annual total remuneration for all employees (excluding the highest paid employee). The calculation reveals that the Annual total remunerat ion ratio is currently 237. The total remuneration ratio reflects the bank’s diverse operation across numerous geographies worldwide, covering four business divisions: Private Bank, Corporate and Investment Bank and Asset Management as well as operations a nd support functions. For the purposes of the calculation, the highest paid employee is not the CEO, demonstrating the diversity of the bank's activities and remuneration opportunities.   • Structure of the Management Board compensation The Supervisory Board sets a target compensation for each Management Board member. In accordance with the recommendation of the German Corporate Governance Code, the Supervisory Board also determines the ratio of fixed compensation to variable compensation as well as the ratio of short to long -term variable compensation The compensation system for the Management Board consists of fixed and variable compensation components. The fixed compensation consists of base salary, fringe benefits and contributions to the company pension schemes. The variable compensation is divided into Short -Term Incentives (STI) and Long -Term Incentives (LTI). In the STI, three to five objectives for measuring individual and divisional performance over a period of one year are set in the beginning of the period and disclosed retrospectively.   • Hired global graduates 1,160 1,177 Hired vocational trainees1 376 547 1 Vocational trainees in Germany Human Capital Return on Investment (ROI) For the area of productivity Deutsche Bank calculates its Human Capital Return on Investment (ROI). This metric shows how effectively the investment in human capital is supporting the organization’s goal and is calculated based on the ratio of income/revenue to employment costs. The Human Capital ROI for 2024 was 60.7% (2023: 64.5%). The decrease in 2024 results from growth in compensation and benefits cost outpacing revenue growth. In 2024, total workforce costs increased by € 441 million to € 12,176 million (2023: € 11,735 million ). The increase was driven mainly by higher performance -related compensation, wage growth and increases in internal workforce related to the bank’s targeted investments as part of the bank’s Global Hausbank strategy, as well higher severance costs. The increase was driven mainly by higher performance -related compensation, wage growth and increases in internal workforce related to the bank’s targeted investments as part of the bank’s Global Hausbank strategy, as well higher severance costs. The
  • Strategy ESRS 2 SBM -3 Deutsche Bank is committed to protecting its clients, society, and its own assets by taking an active role in the prevention, detection, and reporting of financial crime. Recognizing the material threats posed by financial crime, the Anti -Financial Crime f unction has defined a uniform strategy across financial crime risk prevention, detection, and reporting to ensure the highest level of protection for Deutsche Bank’s clients and stakeholders, while also supporting sustainable business practices. The Anti -Financial Crime strategy focuses on remediation, simplification, and consolidation of processes, and evolving the AFC Program across the areas of risk appetite, risk assessment, policy, training, assurance and reporting. The strategy serves to accelerate de cision -making around financial crime risks, enforce consistent standards, and foster Strategy ESRS 2 SBM -3 Deutsche Bank is committed to protecting its clients, society, and its own assets by taking an active role in the prevention, detection, and reporting of financial crime. Recognizing the material threats posed by financial crime, the Anti -Financial Crime f unction has defined a uniform strategy across financial crime risk prevention, detection, and reporting to ensure the highest level of protection for Deutsche Bank’s clients and stakeholders, while also supporting sustainable business practices. The Anti -Financial Crime strategy focuses on remediation, simplification, and consolidation of processes, and evolving the AFC Program across the areas of risk appetite, risk assessment, policy, training, assurance and reporting. The strategy serves to accelerate de cision -making around financial crime risks, enforce consistent standards, and foster
  • continues to further devel op them. Next to the Chief Sustainability Office, an additional enabler are ESG expert teams in the bank’s business divisions and infrastructure functions that foster the implementation of Deutsche Bank’s sustainability strategy and allow for a swift respo nse to emerging business opportunities and potential risks. In the years ahead, Deutsche Bank aims to broaden the scope of decarbonization, i.e., progressing from financed emissions to financed and facilitated emissions and capturing opportunities in the bank’s private clients’ assets under management. Moreover, De utsche Bank focuses on incorporating nature and biodiversity as well as just transition, which means to address the challenges of transitioning for developing economies. To operationalize its commitments, the bank is further developing the Initial Transition Plan as tools, methodologies and continues to further devel op them.   • valuation, monitoring , and review over the life of the loan. Deutsche Bank’s underwriting standards require real estate collateral to be appropriately insured against relevant risks including applicable natural hazards. In some countries, supplemental insurance against natural hazards is provided by the government. The European residential real estate portfolio amounted to € 166.4 billion at year -end 2024. Residential mortgages for private clients in Germany represent approximately 92% of this amount and around 1.2 million German private residences financed by loans secured by immovable properties are insured appropriately against relevant risks including applicable natural hazards. The insurance cover by real estate owners is monitored and complemented or substituted by De utsche Bank´s own insurance. In addition, new valuations and re -valuations require the identification of material environmental physical and transition valuation, monitoring , and review over the life of the loan.   • to 289e of the German Commercial Code (HGB). As the European Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) was not transposed into German law as of December 31, 2024, the bank applied the European Sustainability Reporting Standards (ESRS) as reporting framework as allowed by Section 315c (3) HGB in conjunction with Section 289d HGB and, on that basis, discloses governance, strategy, impact, risk and opportunity management, metrics and targets for material sustainability matters. In addition, the Sustainability Statement complies with the disclosure obligations under Article 8 (1) and (3) of the Taxonomy Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2020/852) and the respective specifications in Articles 4 and 10 (5) of the associated Disclosures de legated Act (Delegated Regulation (EU) 2021/2178). The Sustainability Statement was prepared on a consolidated basis and the scope of consolidation is the same as for the to 289e of the German Commercial Code (HGB). As the European Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) was not transposed into German law as of December 31, 2024, the bank applied the European Sustainability Reporting Standards (ESRS) as reporting framework as allowed by Section 315c (3) HGB in conjunction with Section 289d HGB and, on that basis, discloses governance, strategy, impact, risk and opportunity management, metrics and targets for material sustainability matters. In addition, the Sustainability Statement complies with the disclosure obligations under Article 8 (1) and (3) of the Taxonomy Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2020/852) and the respective specifications in Articles 4 and 10 (5) of the associated Disclosures de legated Act (Delegated Regulation (EU) 2021/2178). S1-173

Quel est le ratio de la rémunération annuelle totale de la personne la mieux payée par rapport à la rémunération totale annuelle médiane de tous les salariés (à l'exclusion de la personne la mieux rémunérée) au sein de l'entreprise ?

nan

Le ratio de la rémunération annuelle totale de la personne la mieux payée par rapport à la rémunération totale annuelle médiane de tous les salariés (à l'exclusion de la personne la mieux rémunérée) au sein de l'entreprise est actuellement de 237.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • The Annual total remuneration ratio compares the annual total remuneration of the highest paid employee to the median annual total remuneration for all employees (excluding the highest paid employee). The calculation reveals that the Annual total remuneration ratio is currently 237. The total remuneration ratio reflects the bank's diverse operation across numerous geographies worldwide, covering four business divisions: Private Bank, Corporate and Investment Bank and Asset Management as well as operations and support functions. For the purposes of the calculation, the highest paid employee is not the CEO, demonstrating the diversity of the bank's activities and remuneration opportunities. The Annual total remuneration ratio compares the annual total remuneration of the highest paid employee to the median annual total remuneration for all employees (excluding the highest paid employee). The calculation reveals that the Annual total remuneration ratio is currently 237. The total remuneration ratio reflects the bank's diverse operation across numerous geographies worldwide, covering four business divisions: Private Bank, Corporate and Investment Bank and Asset Management as well as operations and support functions. For the purposes of the calculation, the highest paid employee is not the CEO, demonstrating the diversity of the bank's activities and remuneration opportunities.
  • ## Deutsche Bank Annual Report 2024 ### Annual total remuneration ratio ESRS S1-16 The bank's remuneration strategy rewards performance and contribution through an appropriate mix of fixed and variable remuneration. An employee's fixed pay is determined using a mix of internal fixed pay data and external market data to ensure adherence to legislation such as minimum wage requirements and alignment with peers. Variable compensation is awarded based on a variable compensation orientation framework and is closely linked to individual performance metrics, such as the delivery of business priorities set at the beginning of the performance year, as well as conduct and behavior. ## Deutsche Bank Annual Report 2024 ### Annual total remuneration ratio ESRS S1-16 The bank's remuneration strategy rewards performance and contribution through an appropriate mix of fixed and variable remuneration. An employee's fixed pay is determined using a mix of internal fixed pay data and external market data to ensure adherence to legislation such as minimum wage requirements and alignment with peers. Variable compensation is awarded based on a variable compensation orientation framework and is closely linked to individual performance metrics, such as the delivery of business priorities set at the beginning of the performance year, as well as conduct and behavior.
  • ### Facts and figures 2024 526 talent acceleration programs participants cross-divisional 38.8% global unadjusted gender pay gap (impacted by business model and geography) 1.76m total training hours 33% women in Corporate Titles Managing Director, Director, Vice President 67 net promoter score Private Bank Germany (after interaction) 69.89% culture pulse index (average favorability score) 67% commitment score according to the People Survey 53 net promoter score Asset Management (Top 170 clients) ### Facts and figures 2024 526 talent acceleration programs participants cross-divisional 38.8% global unadjusted gender pay gap (impacted by business model and geography) 1.76m total training hours 33% women in Corporate Titles Managing Director, Director, Vice President 67 net promoter score Private Bank Germany (after interaction) 69.89% culture pulse index (average favorability score) 67% commitment score according to the People Survey 53 net promoter score Asset Management (Top 170 clients)
  • For the reporting year 2024, Deutsche Bank reported its unadjusted global Gender pay gap globally for the first time to understand the extent of the gap in the pay between women and men amongst the bank's employees globally including Management Board members. The unadjusted global Gender pay gap is defined as the difference of average hourly pay levels between female and male employees, expressed as percentage of the average hourly pay level of male employees. For 2024, the unadjusted global Gender pay gap was 38.8%. For the reporting year 2024, Deutsche Bank reported its unadjusted global Gender pay gap globally for the first time to understand the extent of the gap in the pay between women and men amongst the bank's employees globally including Management Board members. The unadjusted global Gender pay gap is defined as the difference of average hourly pay levels between female and male employees, expressed as percentage of the average hourly pay level of male employees. For 2024, the unadjusted global Gender pay gap was 38.8%.
  • The bank has disclosed to the public or reported to the regulators on the unadjusted Gender pay gap for a number of years in countries where there is an existing legislative requirement. For example, in the United Kingdom, the bank published its seventh Gender pay gap Report in March 2024. Progress has been made with the median hourly pay gap decreasing from 24.9% in 2022 to 24.3% in 2023 and the median bonus pay gap narrowed from 41.3% to 38.8%. In addition, the bank voluntarily published its ethnicity pay gap in the United Kingdom for the fourth time. The bank has disclosed to the public or reported to the regulators on the unadjusted Gender pay gap for a number of years in countries where there is an existing legislative requirement. For example, in the United Kingdom, the bank published its seventh Gender pay gap Report in March 2024. Progress has been made with the median hourly pay gap decreasing from 24.9% in 2022 to 24.3% in 2023 and the median bonus pay gap narrowed from 41.3% to 38.8%. In addition, the bank voluntarily published its ethnicity pay gap in the United Kingdom for the fourth time.
  • ### Employee turnover by gender The table presents the "Share in %1" of employee turnover by gender for the years "2024" and "2023." The rows include "Female," "Male," "Other2," and "Not reported." In 2024, the share for "Female" was 43.9%, "Male" was 56.1%, "Other2" was 0%, and "Not reported" was 0%. In 2023, the share for "Female" was 41.8%, "Male" was 58.2%, "Other2" was 0%, and "Not reported" was 0%. and

    Not reported 0 0

  • ### Completion rate for performance reviews by gender (2023-2024) The table presents the "Completion rate for performance reviews by gender" for the years 2024 and 2023. The "Gender, in %" column lists the categories: "Female," "Male," "Other1," and "Not reported." The "Share of employees (headcount)" column provides the completion rates for each gender category. - In 2024, the completion rates were: "Female" (88%), "Male" (92%), "Other1" (67%), and "Not reported" (100%). - In 2023, the completion rates were: "Female" (86%), "Male" (90%), "Other1" (75%), and "Not reported" (50%). - The "Total Employees" completion rate was 90% in 2024 and 88% in 2023. "Other1" refers to gender as specified by the employees themselves. and

Los tipos de pérdida de naturaleza incluyen: "Water depletion" (17.3 € bn, 17.1% del portafolio, 2.2 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 12.7% de estos), "Terrestrial biodiversity and habitat loss" (11.6 € bn, 11.5% del portafolio, 4.6 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 39.2% de estos), "Ecosystem degradation from waste and pollution" (9.2 € bn, 9.1% del portafolio, 5.5 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 60.2% de estos), y "Marine ecosystem degradation" (6.4 € bn, 6.3% del portafolio, 4.7 € bn identificados a nivel de cliente, 74.0% de estos). La exposición total de préstamos corporativos por industria es de 101.2 € bn, representando el 100% del portafolio, sin datos específicos identificados a nivel de cliente. and

Las etiquetas incluyen "Total environmentally sustainable assets (in € m)", "Turnover KPIs", "CapEx KPIs", "% coverage (over total assets)", "% of assets excluded from the numerator of the GAR (Article 7(2) and (3) and Section 1.1.2. of Annex V)", y "% of assets excluded from the denominator of the GAR (Article 7(1) and Section 1.2.4 of Annex V)". En la fila "Main KPI", el "Green asset ratio (GAR) stock" muestra valores de 7,546 millones de euros para "Turnover" y 8,928 millones de euros para "CapEx". Los KPIs de "Turnover" y "CapEx" son 1.3 y 1.5, respectivamente. El porcentaje de cobertura sobre activos totales es 44.2%. Además, el porcentaje de activos excluidos del numerador del GAR es 26.2%, mientras que el porcentaje de activos excluidos del denominador del GAR es 55.8%. and

Los activos sostenibles totales alcanzaron 490 millones de euros, con un GAR (flow) de 1,259 millones. Los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 0.2 y 0.4 respectivamente, con una cobertura del 17.6% sobre el total de activos. El porcentaje de activos excluidos del numerador del GAR fue del 82.4%, mientras que los excluidos del denominador fueron "N/M". En la categoría "Trading book", los valores son "N/A". En "Financial guarantees", los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 153 y 374 respectivamente, con valores de 0.5 y 1.3. Para "Assets under Management", los KPIs de rotación y CapEx fueron de 8,635 y 16,857 respectivamente, con valores de 0.8 y 1.6. Finalmente, en "Fees and commissions income", los valores son "N/A". and
